HEADLINE: Times Square, With Ketchup; 
No Cloning, Lots of Razzle-Dazzle at New McDonald's

BYLINE:  By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
It is commonplace for new restaurants in New York to hire publicists, to have the tryout periods known as soft openings and to wallow in industrial materials, plasma screens and bare brick walls. So the surprise at the splashy 17,000-square-foot restaurant in Times Square that officially opens today with such pretensions (but without a red velvet rope) is the name over the door: McDonald's.
 The decor -- big on I-beams, rivets and brushed steel -- is a leap from the red and yellow plastic of the earlier McDonald's, and far from the mass fabrication of the restaurant's food. That's because the McDonald's corporation, once the enforcer of a clonelike 1950's uniformity, now takes a do-your-own-thing attitude about decoration. 
 Long gone are the days when historic towns worried about a McDonald's adapting and blending in. In Port Jefferson, N.Y., a McDonald's is tucked behind a dormered roof and coach lights. A McDonald's in Phoenix went with an Aztec theme, and included an original earthenware mosaic from Puebla, Mexico, of the Virgin of Guadalupe. And a McDonald's that opened last December in Orlando, Fla., hoped to attract older and wealthier patrons with its French provincial decor, tea-stained lighting, framed Impressionist reproductions, flower arrangements and marble-topped buffet.
In Times Square, where the neighbors sport neon walls beneath five-story television screens, fitting in means showing off. Thus a giant new marquee on West 42nd Street spells out McDonald's in 7,500 lights, more wattage than required by the 42nd Street Redevelopment Project. 
"You could get a sunburn standing under it," said Charles Morris Mount, the restaurant's designer.
The three-story interior of the restaurant is meant to look like the backstage of a Broadway theater, complete with theatrical light fixtures with "barn door" flaps and colored gels. And the 12-foot-wide doorway to this McDonald's will always remain open, in blazing heat and bitter cold, thanks to a million-B.T.U. curtain of air that will keep outside weather outside -- "unless there's a windstorm," said Irwin Kruger, 54, who owns this location and six others in Manhattan. (In case of foul weather, giant folding doors can be closed.) The restaurant, which has 300 seats, hopes to entice customers through the air curtain with the smell of fresh minidoughnuts made at a rate of 2,000 an hour by a machine visible from the street. 
Things have been rough in McDonaldland for several years. Too many fast-food competitors and a sagging economy have led to a poor outlook on earnings. (McDonald's stock has recently been trading at a seven-year low.) The company has settled suits over too-hot coffee and beef flavoring in its fries. Last year the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested eight people in connection with fraud in a McDonald's promotional Monopoly game. And last week the company recalled a pair of bobble-head figurines of football players because they contained lead paint.
As of last year, Subway sandwich shops had surpassed the number of McDonald's restaurants in the United States (perhaps that's because no one has yet invented the McDonald's Diet).
In an attempt to cover its bets, McDonald's has invested in some nonhamburger fast-food businesses, including Pret a Manger sandwich shops, Donato's pizza and Chipotle Mexican food. Nonetheless, with the right location and razzle-dazzle, a McDonald's can still be a gold mine. Mr. Kruger says that his six other McDonald's restaurants, all designed by Mr. Mount, earn considerably more than the $1.5 million average for American McDonald's sites. The 42nd Street location, he says, is on track to earn $5 million a year.
A born New Yorker, he put his new McDonald's in the landmark Candler Building, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, which has a historic connection to McDonald's official soft drink purveyor. The 23-story skyscraper was built in 1914 for the head of the Coca-Cola Company, Asa Candler, and once included the Sam H. Harris theater, where in 1922 John Barrymore and Tyrone Power Sr. performed in "Hamlet." 
Mr. Kruger and his designer knew that the restaurant materials would have to stand up to kicking toddlers, bored teenagers, umbrellas, briefcases and mischief. On top of this, they are offering what may be the most accessible new restrooms in the city, just steps from the 41st Street entrance. "They are heavily used, and convenient," said Mr. Kruger, whose restaurant has been open unofficially for weeks. "You see people hurrying in, and they have that look."
The restrooms have resilient porcelain pavers on the floor, and the mirrors are small rather than continuous, so damaged panels can be replaced inexpensively.
In a long corridor running from 42nd Street to 41st Street, plasma screen monitors above a Corian counter have been encased in brushed steel boxes and covered with a quarter-inch plate of clear Lexan. Music videos, movie trailers, clips from Broadway shows and historical tidbits will play on the monitors.
"You can hang on them, stand on them, they won't break," Mr. Kruger said.
In the front of the store, the walls were stripped back to bare brick and sealed. Soaring columns are clad in blue reflective glass tile. The walls in the corridor to 41st Street are covered in a gray vinyl called Lonseal that looks like diamond-plate subway grating. The material, much lighter than steel diamond plate, is used as flooring on Navy submarines, but Mr. Kruger said he thought it needed to be tested further. "We put it down on a driveway, and an employee ran his car over it," Mr. Kruger said. "We tried to gouge it with a knife and a couple of screwdrivers. I'm sure it will withstand the busy customer flow we're going to have."
The most prominent structural change was cutting away part of the second floor to create a space nearly 40 feet tall -- Beyer Blinder Belle is the architect -- and the building of twin staircases that climb three floors. (An elevator provides handicapped access, but escalators were deemed "too much like a mall," Mr. Mount said.)
The staircase railings were made of rebar, the twisted steel rods used to reinforce concrete. A mezzanine level has small tables and aluminum chairs made in Italy. At the top, near the windows on 42nd Street, are two communal tables, where 40 customers may dine together.
Down the road, Mr. Kruger said, why not send 10-second video postcards by computer to friends all over the world from the Times Square McDonald's? Why not offer space for PowerPoint presentations in a private dining room on the top floor? And what would Times Square be without entertainment? "It could be a lot of fun to find actors 'in transition' who've got outgoing personalities," Mr. Kruger said, "who could engage some of our customers in a karaoke moment."
With all the new buildings in Times Square, he said, foot traffic will only increase to the Port Authority bus terminal down the block. "There's Conde Nast and the new Boston Properties," he said. "We've got white collar, tourists, theatrical, blue collar. I'm thrilled to be in the location we're in."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Fed to Keep Rates Steady With Rare Dissenting Votes
The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, but two of its 12 voting members took the rare step of opposing the decision and instead backed an immediate rate cut.
 It was the first time since 1998 that two Fed policy makers have simultaneously broken ranks with Alan Greenspan, the chairman. The split decision was a clear indication that Fed officials, like economists generally, are divided over how to deal with the fears of further weakness in the economy. Page A1. 

Dynegy to Settle Civil Charges
Dynegy agreed to pay $3 million to settle civil Securities and Exchange Commission charges that the company had used a series of off-balance-sheet partnerships to doctor its financial statements and mislead investors. C6.

Xerox Shares Plummet on Inquiry
Investors sent shares of Xerox down 71 cents to $5.96, on reports that the United States attorney in Connecticut had started a criminal investigation into its accounting. Five months ago, Xerox paid $10 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission charge of fraudulent accounting. C13.

Federal Panel Backs Cancer Drug
An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of AstraZeneca's cancer drug Iressa despite concerns about the drug's effectiveness. C2.

Danco Laboratories, distributor of Mifeprex, the abortion-inducing pill once known as RU-486, said over 100,000 women in America had used the drug since November 2000. In that time, 2.6 million women had abortions. A1.

Airline Officials Make Their Case
Airline executives asked a House subcommittee to consider tax relief, reimbursement for security costs and an extension of terrorism insurance policies. Lawmakers said they were considering a bill this week. C12.

Deloitte Chief to Retire Next Year
James E. Copeland Jr., the chief executive of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, one of the four remaining large accounting firms, told his partners that he would step down next year. C4.

Companies Settle Asbestos Suits
Hundreds of corporations swept into a huge asbestos trial in West Virginia have settled claims brought by some 8,000 people over the last week, lawyers said. C12.

Executives Worried About Swaps
In Congressional testimony, current and former executives of Global Crossing and Qwest Communications indicated that people in the companies had qualms about swaps of fiber optic network capacity that are now at the heart of federal investigations. C4.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold hearings on a bill intended to spur the development of digital television. C7.

Vivendi Seen Focusing on Telecom
The chairman of Vivendi Universal, Jean-Rene Fourtou, left, intends to recommend to the board today that the company focus more on broadcasting and telecommunications and less on water supply and waste treatment operations, the chief of the water unit said. People close to Mr. Fourtou said this strategy meant reducing a stake in the water unit. World Business, Section W.

Hershey Promotes Its Flagship Bar
After the end of a bitter takeover battle that riveted Wall Street, Hershey Foods is talking to Main Street with a drastically different campaign for its flagship product.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Restaurant Chains Move to the City
Restaurant chains like Chili's are moving their quintessentially suburban businesses into urban areas and faux-urban town centers. The costs are higher but the chains are motivated to take risks as they follow population patterns. Commercial Real Estate. C9.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Teacher Shortages Are Usually a Myth

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
EDUCATION analysts often say the nation faces a looming teacher shortage. Growing enrollment and the retirement of baby-boom teachers will aggravate the need, as will a new federal law that bans unqualified teachers.
 But this year in New York City, the shortage mostly disappeared, despite the difficult conditions in many urban schools. Qualified teachers flocked to New York for starting salaries of $39,000 a year, up from $32,000 in 2001. Those with experience elsewhere started as high as $61,000. Certified teachers left parochial schools, the suburbs and other professions to work for the city. A slow economy helped by offering college graduates fewer options in the private sector. 
 New York's experience suggests there never was a shortage, only an unwillingness of qualified teachers to work at previous pay levels. This will come as no surprise to economists, who say that real shortages are rare in a market economy. At the right price, supply grows to meet demand. There might have been a temporary real shortage if there were no qualified teachers willing to work at any price. But this was never the case. 
Nationwide, only about two-thirds of new education graduates take teaching jobs. Of those who do teach, nearly one-third quit within five years. Although some may have been unsuited for the role, many leave education because they get better offers elsewhere. So there is a big pool of qualified teachers out there, ready to re-enter the profession when the price is right.
The shortage seems more real in some specialties: high school math and science, special and bilingual education and schools in high-poverty communities. But here too, there is no actual shortage.
Teachers in middle-class areas will move to disadvantaged schools if salaries in poor neighborhoods rise above suburban rates. The differential has to be big enough to compensate for the greater skill and dedication required. Professionals in other fields, including those with math and science degrees, will take up teaching if salaries in education are competitive. If apparent shortages remain, schools can raise salaries in shortage areas to induce college students to major in fields where lucrative teaching jobs beckon.
An impediment to this market solution is the tradition of paying all teachers on a common scale. This makes no economic sense. If it is harder to find high school math than English teachers, salaries for teaching math should rise. The gap should grow until the math shortage eases. Likewise, with a surplus of suburban elementary school teachers and a shortage of urban ones, urban schools should pay more than suburban ones until the supply is balanced.
Impeding this approach is how we typically finance schools. Urban districts often depend on property taxes for revenue and cannot raise salaries to compete with property-rich suburban neighbors. So federal and state subsidies for urban teacher salaries are needed.
Yet for three decades, urban school leaders in many states have pressed for such subsidies, with only inconsistent success. In New York, the candidates for governor, H. Carl McCall and Gov. George E. Pataki, are now sparring about whether to oppose a court decision that said the state had no constitutional duty to expand its subsidies for urban schools.
Another difficulty is the reluctance of teachers' unions to negotiate different pay for different specialties. Union leaders fear this will lead to bad feelings. But all social differentials can create bad feelings. In fact, that is the idea. If teachers in surplus areas feel badly enough, they will become certified in shortage areas.
Local, state and federal policies are taking small steps in this direction. New York City teachers can get a 15 percent bonus for work at the most difficult schools. The state has a program that provides an added $3,400 a year for such assignments.
Many states now subsidize the tuition of prospective teachers who agree to work in shortage areas. The federal government sells some housing at half-price to teachers who not only teach but live in poor neighborhoods. California gives certificates for a federal income tax credit to those who teach in shortage areas.
Bills now before Congress would give income tax credits to teachers in low-income schools. But the amounts are tiny ($1,000 in the Senate version, $2,000 in the House), too small to induce much growth in supply. The bills also do not provide incentives for teachers, other professionals and college students to switch fields to subject areas that are most in need.
But the bills take steps in the right direction. They acknowledge that a real shortage is mythical. If demand for teachers is bolstered with enough new dollars, supply will emerge to soak those dollars up.

PERSON: Mike Webster 

HEADLINE: Mike Webster, 50, Dies; Troubled Football Hall of Famer 

BYLINE:  By FRANK LITSKY 

 BODY:
Mike Webster, whose Hall of Fame pro football career was followed by more than a decade of physical and psychological turmoil apparently brought on by repeated blows to the head on the field, died yesterday in a Pittsburgh hospital. He was 50.
 The cause of death was a heart attack, the Pittsburgh Steelers said. Webster played center for 15 seasons (1974-88) for the Steelers and two seasons (1989-90) for the Kansas City Chiefs. In 1997, he was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, and in 2000 he was named to the National Football League's all-time team. 
 Webster was a pivotal player on the standout Steeler teams that captured four Super Bowl championships in the 1970's. He was an undersized 225-pound center at the University of Wisconsin who lingered in the N.F.L. draft until the fifth round, when he was selected by the Steelers. He transformed himself into a 260-pound tough-minded professional, a man known as Iron Mike who played bare-armed in freezing weather and helped set the tone for a Pittsburgh offense that included the future Hall of Famers Terry Bradshaw, Franco Harris, Lynn Swann and John Stallworth.
Of the 22 players who were part of all four Steeler Super Bowl teams, Webster was the last to leave and the first to die.
"I couldn't have been the player I was without him," Bradshaw said. "He was so smart, so prepared for everything we would face in a game. We all worked hard, but none as hard as Mike did."
Chuck Noll, his Steelers coach, said, "He was very smart, a great technician."
But Webster's transition to post-football life was filled with setbacks. He increasingly lived away from home, sometimes sleeping in his car. His marriage broke up. He lost money in bad investments. He was often reclusive.
In 1997, just before his Hall of Fame induction, his troubled life became public, and he told The Atlanta Journal and Constitution: "Because of all this publicity over my situation, people treat me like I'm dying or something. And I don't want their pity. Things in general, they're getting a lot better."
At the time, The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette reported that Webster was "homeless, unemployed, deep in debt, beset with medical ailments, lacking health insurance, in the midst of divorce, in the care of a psychiatrist and on medication, and involved in a complex lawsuit over real estate investments."
But Webster tried to reassure people that his life was not as damaged as it seemed. "I don't think it's anybody's business," he said of his problems. "I'm not destitute." And responding to reports that he had lived in his car for 18 months, he told The St. Petersburg Times:
"From time to time, yes, I did sleep in my car and stay in my car. There's a broad definition of what living out of your car is. And yes, I slept in a train station one time. I had some things to think through. I wasn't broke. I wasn't in danger. I was just out of gas, tired and exhausted, and that's as far as I got that day."
In 1999, Webster was charged with forging 19 prescriptions to obtain Ritalin, a stimulant mainly used for children with attention deficit hyperactivity. He said he was using the drug to treat brain damage caused by repeated head injuries that had led him to behave erratically.
Webster's doctors said that the concussions Webster had in his career had indeed damaged his frontal lobe, causing cognitive dysfunction, and that his attention span and concentration had been affected.
Webster also stated that in his playing days he had tried anabolic steroids -- illegal body-building substances that can cause health problems -- but he maintained they were not responsible for his condition.
"I am not seeking your pity or sympathy," he said at a news conference at the time. "I'm not seeking a pardon for my actions, and I'm not really asking for your understanding, even though grown men need understanding. But I do promise you this: No matter what happens, I will answer the charges."
During that same period, Dr. Fred Jay Krieg, a clinical psychologist, said Webster had "the football version of punch drunk."
"It doesn't get better," Krieg added. "You get more and more demented. It's sad."
In September 1999, Webster pleaded no contest to the forgery charges and was placed on probation for five years. Later, he was treated for depression and symptoms of congestive heart failure.
Two years ago, Webster's son Garrett moved from Wisconsin to live with him in Pittsburgh. The son, at 6 feet 9 inches and 340 pounds, is a high school senior and an offensive lineman on his football team.
"I have to take care of my dad," he said a week ago. "There will be some mornings he can't get up from the couch because he feels so terrible."
Webster's erratic habits and continued absences contributed to a breakup of his marriage, and his former wife, Pamela, said she had to sell their house and car and take a job as a cleaning woman.
Webster is also survived by two sons, Colin of Camp LeJeune, N.C., and Garrett; two daughters, Hillary and Brooke; two grandchildren; his father, William, of Harshaw, Wis.; two brothers, Reid and Joe Webster; and two sisters, Wendy and Jane Webster.
Michael L. Webster was born March 18, 1952, in Tomahawk, Wis., and was reared on a 640-acre potato farm. He didn't play high school ball until his junior year, but won a scholarship to Wisconsin. As a Steeler, he played in nine Pro Bowl games and 245 N.F.L. games, including 177 in a row. He earned $16,000 in his first season, $400,000 in his last.
When Webster was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame, he chose Bradshaw to present him. And Webster's acceptance speech was emotional and prophetic.
"You only fail if you don't finish the game," he said. "If you finish, you won. You have to measure by what you started out with, by what you overcome. Who wants to get to the end of their life and find out they haven't lived at all? You're going to fail -- I did -- but that's O.K. because in your life no one is keeping score. Just finish the game."

HEADLINE: Helping Haiti 

 BODY:
For the past two years, the international community has been in a terrible bind over Haiti. Results of the tainted May 2000 legislative elections were rejected by the opposition, and since then a combination of political gridlock and governmental abuse has sent the Haitians further into misery. The United States and other donors withheld contributions, hoping to spur President Jean-Bertrand Aristide into political and human rights reform and his opposition into negotiations with him. Neither he nor they have complied. 
 Now, in a shift born largely of exasperation, the Organization of American States, backed by Washington, has decided to unblock millions of dollars in aid on the condition that legislative elections be held next year. This is the right step, an effort to force the hand of both government and opposition while offering relief to the seven million people of a nation whose suffering knows no bounds. 
 The lives of the majority of the population defy the imagination of most Americans. Life expectancy is less than 50 years, and 55 percent of adults are illiterate. Access to potable water is rare in rural areas. Malnutrition is a leading cause of death among children under 4. Unemployment is near 70 percent. An estimated 80 percent of the population lives in abject poverty.
The elements of the worsening crisis in Haiti remain much the same as those eight years ago when American troops led an invasion to oust a military junta and restore Mr. Aristide, democratically elected, to power. There are fuel shortages, labor unrest, gangs of armed thugs roaming the street, crumbling infrastructure and political fractiousness. A recent World Bank study questioned whether the aid of the previous 15 years had made any difference in reducing poverty, blaming government mismanagement. The seeming intractability of Haiti's problems makes normalization of its relations with the United States and other nations, as well as with international development banks, no less pressing a concern. Outsiders are discovering that they may not be able to rescue Haiti. But carefully channeled international aid, conditioned on political reform, may help ease the Haitians' misery.

HEADLINE: Pataki Picks Up Pace While McCall Tries To Narrow Money Gap 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
With 41 days before the election and a comfortable lead in the polls, Gov. George E. Pataki is campaigning as if it were the final week, deploying supporters and negative ads to batter his Democratic opponent in a bid to effectively end the race before it really starts.
 While H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee, stays behind closed doors raising money and holding only one or two campaign events a day, Mr. Pataki has blitzed the trail, using his capacity as governor to sprinkle economic development money on the suburbs and upstate New York. 
 At the same time, in the drive to win him a third term, his campaign has gone on the attack, releasing its second negative ad of the race yesterday and rolling out the State Senate majority leader today for a campaign swing upstate to criticize Mr. McCall's record.
Mr. Pataki has often left it to his campaign aides to send scathing e-mail messages to the news media about Mr. McCall, but yesterday the governor himself mixed it up a bit during a news conference. He departed from usual practice and mentioned his opponent by name to denounce Mr. McCall's record as president of the New York City School Board in the early 1990's.
"I am very proud to compare my record to the record that Mr. McCall had when he was head of the New York City school system, when performance went down, dropouts went up, dollars in the classroom went down," Mr. Pataki said. 
In fact, the McCall camp says, some test scores went up, the dropout rate declined and spending per student increased. 
Analysts are divided over whether the governor is running smart or running scared, with some saying the approach reflects worry in his camp over Mr. McCall's potential to mount a serious challenge. 
Others ascribed it to the reputation of Mr. Pataki's strategists for cutthroat campaigning. After all, Mr. Pataki did broadcast a negative ad in 1998 about this time in mid-September, against Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic nominee, who never posed a serious threat. Mr. Pataki's strategists have said they are following the same plan, seeking to give voters the Pataki camp's impression of Mr. McCall before Mr. McCall can define himself.
Some Democratic consultants suggest that Mr. Pataki has underestimated Mr. McCall and is nervously watching the candidacy of Tom Golisano, the wealthy Independence Party candidate who has made the governor a target and threatens to spend tens of millions of dollars on television advertising. But they say Mr. Pataki's aggressive tactics are slowing whatever momentum Mr. McCall has sought to build.
"What you are seeing now is where the financial advantage of Pataki comes into play," said Josh Isay, a Democratic consultant who managed Andrew M. Cuomo's primary campaign against Mr. McCall. "McCall needs the money to do three things: to respond to Pataki's charges; to introduce himself to voters, which he really needs to do; and to paint a picture of the failures of the Pataki administration." 
"That," Mr. Isay added, "is an expensive proposition."
Mr. Pataki has about $20 million in campaign money, about 10 times as much as Mr. McCall.
Mr. McCall's aides said that he would broadcast new ads within the week and projected an air of calm, saying they had not seen evidence that Mr. Pataki's ads were being shown frequently.
"People are not seeing them," one adviser said.
Mr. McCall's advisers have said their internal polls show Mr. Pataki's lead narrowing to single digits; two public polls are expected in the next week.
Whether moved by polls or by the advice of his top strategists, Arthur Finkelstein and Kieran Mahoney, to take nothing for granted, Mr. Pataki has intensified his campaigning almost daily.
While Mr. McCall held just one event yesterday, to unveil a proposal at a Queens school to reduce class sizes and build more schools, Mr. Pataki held four, skipping from Albany to Westchester to New York City to Long Island.
Only one was billed as a campaign event, but Mr. Pataki's schedule typically includes a few official events that entail doling out grants for community centers, parks and business development that undeniably enhance his candidacy. Although he makes a number of such announcements in a given year, he has stepped up the pace in recent weeks.
On Monday, Mr. McCall criticized the grants as "election gimmicks," saying that they typically involved places in electoral battlegrounds like upstate and the suburbs. 
Mr. Pataki says he is just being governor. "We've been doing this for years," he said at a stop yesterday in Sleepy Hollow, where, to the applause of a group of elderly residents, he announced a $300,000 grant to renovate a park. This came after he appeared with local officials to announce a residential and commercial development on the riverfront site of a former General Motors auto plant.
At the same time, Mr. Pataki has sought to match Mr. McCall on Mr. McCall's signature issue, education.
Today, for instance, a day after Mr. McCall's appearance in Queens to call for more school construction, the governor is scheduled to be in the borough to dedicate a school. Also, after months of silence, he said this month that he disagreed with a court ruling that the state had no obligation to educate children beyond the eighth grade -- seeking to deflate Mr. McCall's "eight is not enough" campaign slogan.
Mr. Pataki has also generally tried to present a positive message on the stump while expanding the use of surrogates who bash Mr. McCall for him. Joseph L. Bruno, the leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate, is scheduled to make a swing upstate to discuss Mr. McCall's "record of failure" there, the campaign announced.
Mr. McCall, meanwhile, continues to interpret Mr. Pataki's aggressive campaigning as a sign of desperation. "I don't intend to run any negative ads" in response, he said.
Some Democrats are concerned about Mr. McCall's ability to strike back. "I think Pataki feels Team McCall does not have any money," said Richard Schrader, a Democratic strategist. "He can't get up on the air. Silence can be deadly."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
At Little Wofford, Big Challenges

BYLINE:  By JOE DRAPE

 BODY:
EARLY on, my father passed on a maxim well known to pool sharks and golf hustlers: never beat a man by more than you have to.
 I was reminded of this advice while looking at the college football menu for the weekend, which features the typical early-season nonconference mismatches: Texas at Tulane, South Florida at Oklahoma, Virginia Tech at Western Michigan, Rutgers at Tennessee. 
 One more week of the college football sharks looking for a breather and their marks seeking a payday. But one game in particular appeared to cry out for mercy: Wofford College at Maryland. 
How in the world was the smallest college in Division I-A and I-AA football -- with 1,100 students, Wofford's SAT average (1,236) is higher than its enrollment -- going to compete with Maryland, the defending Atlantic Coast Conference champion? Hitting the Web site for Wofford, a liberal arts college in Spartanburg, S.C., made me wince more.
Up came a couple of facts that were as curious as they were charming. First, after serving 28 years as Wofford's president, Dr. Joe Lesesne is now in his second season as the Terriers' tight ends coach. Second, wide receiver Isaac Goodpaster, last year's leading receiver with 25 catches, is legally blind with uncorrectable 20/200 vision.
Now, the $225,000 payday Wofford will receive for traveling to College Park goes a long way at a small college. And the Terriers are 3-0 and ranked No. 19 in this week's ESPN/USA Today Division I-AA poll. But is it worth the risk of a potentially humiliating defeat? 
"Need a game? Call 1-800-Wofford," Mark Cohen, the associate athletic director for media relations, said with a chuckle before explaining how the matchup came about and why the Terriers were equipped to take on the Terrapins (2-2).
Last winter Maryland was left with an open date when Troy State backed out of their game. As often happens, relationships interceded: Wofford's athletic director, Richard Johnson, and Maryland's coach, Ralph Friedgen, were at the Citadel at the same time in the 1970's. Friedgen was an assistant football coach, Johnson a basketball player.
Besides, Wofford had done this before. Last season it picked up Clemson and South Carolina at the 11th hour and played valiantly before losing to each by 38-14. Because there are only 550 men on campus, and Wofford has only 63 players on scholarship, compared with the 80 or so for Division I-A teams, a coach has to be crafty to compete.
Mike Ayers is. He is 84-72-1 in 15 years at Wofford. He runs a wingbone offense, a mix of the wishbone and the wing T.
Last week against Georgia Southern, a Southern Conference rival, Wofford ran 52 times for 269 yards in a 14-7 victory, one of the biggest in Wofford's 113 years of football. The Eagles have won or shared the last five conference titles and have won six Division I-AA national championships.
"They had a bunch of flags up there," Ayers said, referring to Georgia Southern's championship banners. "But as dumb as I am, I couldn't count all of them. But they had a mess of them."
Don't let Ayers fool you. He's a former Marine, a black belt in karate and an accomplished sketch artist who once worked on a garbage truck before deciding he wanted an education. In fact, the coach is so revered at Wofford that in 1998 an anonymous donor contributed $100,000 to establish the Mike Ayers Endowed Football Scholarship.
True to his nature, Ayers has put together an eclectic staff. Three of his five full-time assistants played at Wofford. Besides Dr. Lesesne, who decided he wanted to return to his first love after serving 28 years as Wofford's ninth president, Ayers's volunteer coaches are a 79-year-old veteran of the 101st Airborne and a former high school coach.
When Ayers calls his players difference makers, it has nothing to do with football. Wofford is demanding academically and was the only college in the nation to rank in the top 10 in all four categories in the 2000 N.C.A.A. Division I graduation rate report: overall student-athlete graduation rate as well as those for the football, men's basketball and women's basketball teams.
Last year's leading rusher, Ben Foster, doubled as the student body president and is entering medical school next fall. Last year's place-kicker, Darren Brown, was a Division I-AA all-American despite having been born without an arm below the left elbow. He is now in law school at the University of Texas.
"And Isaac Goodpaster," Ayers said. "He's lucky he doesn't run into the stadium with his eyesight. What we got here are not only student-athletes in the truest sense of the word, but guys who are used to overcoming challenges."
Goodpaster has Stargardt's disease, which is a macular degeneration of the cones in the middle of his eye. He does not drive. He labors to watch television. He relies on textbooks with enlarged print and audiotapes for course work. His condition will not get any worse, but his vision fluctuates from day to day. 
"In the middle of my eye everything is blurry; my peripheral vision is better but not good either," said Goodpaster, a senior from Mount Sterling, Ky. "I don't look straight into anything. I've had it all my life and never known anything else, so I've adapted and adjusted to things everybody else takes for granted. I may walk off a curb or bump into a corner of a wall, but that's about it."
How he catches a football has everything to do with preparation and running precise routes. Even though it is taxing, Goodpaster watches hours of film so he knows where a defender will be coming from when his number is called.
"I can't see the ball coming out of the quarterback's hand, but as it gets closer I see this big brown blur," he said. "It's about being in the right place at the right time and, fortunately, I have pretty good hands."
Against Georgia Southern, he caught a 20-yard pass on third-and-13 to keep the Terriers' game-winning drive alive. Last year, against Clemson, he made an acrobatic leap in the back of the end zone for a touchdown that briefly put Wofford up, 14-7.
At 6 feet 1 inch and 180 pounds, Goodpaster understands that games against teams like South Carolina, Clemson and Maryland are as close to the big time as he is going to get.
"I still do dream about playing in the N.F.L.," said Goodpaster, a 3.0 student in business economics. "But I also know not many teams are looking for a skinny, white receiver from a school that doesn't throw a lot. So this game means a lot. If we execute, we have a chance to beat them. If I didn't think that way, I wouldn't be playing football."
It appears that Goodpaster sees pretty well after all.
Wofford may not shock the world and upset Maryland, but the folks down in South Carolina are convincing when they say they have nothing to lose. Even if the Terrapins beat the Terriers by 10 touchdowns, they will not have beaten them at all.

HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PEOPLE LIVING IN POVERTY INCREASES IN U.S. 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The proportion of Americans living in poverty rose significantly last year, increasing for the first time in eight years, the Census Bureau reported today. At the same time, the bureau said that the income of middle-class households fell for the first time since the last recession ended, in 1991.
 The Census Bureau's annual report on income and poverty provided stark evidence that the weakening economy had begun to affect large segments of the population, regardless of race, region or class. Daniel H. Weinberg, chief of income and poverty statistics at the Census Bureau, said the recession that began in March 2001 had reduced the earnings of millions of Americans. 
 The report also suggested that the gap between rich and poor continued to grow. 
All regions except the Northeast experienced a decline in household income, the bureau reported. For blacks, it was the first significant decline in two decades; non-Hispanic whites saw a slight decline. Even the incomes of Asians and Pacific Islanders, a group that achieved high levels of prosperity in the 1990's, went down significantly last year. 
"The decline was widespread," Mr. Weinberg said.
The Census Bureau said the number of poor Americans rose last year to 32.9 million, an increase of 1.3 million, while the proportion living in poverty rose to 11.7 percent, from 11.3 percent in 2000. 
Median household income fell to $42,228 in 2001, a decline of $934 or 2.2 percent from the prior year. The number of households with income above the median is the same as the number below it.
A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income less than $18,104 last year. The official poverty levels, updated each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index, were $14,128 for a family of three, $11,569 for a married couple and $9,039 for an individual.
The bureau's report is likely to provide fodder for the Congressional campaigns. The White House said the increase in poverty resulted, in part, from an economic slowdown that began under President Bill Clinton. But Democrats said the data showed the failure of President Bush's economic policies and his tendency to neglect the economy.
Mr. Bush said today that he remained optimistic. "When you combine the productivity of the American people with low interest rates and low inflation, those are the ingredients for growth," Mr. Bush said. 
But Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said the administration should "start paying attention to the economic situation." Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, expressed amazement that Mr. Bush, after being in office for 20 months, was still blaming his predecessor.
Rudolph G. Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said: "The increase in poverty is most certainly a result of the recession. The slow recovery, the slow rate of growth, has been very disappointing. Whether that has a political impact this fall depends on whether the election hinges on national conditions or focuses on local issues."
Although the poverty rate, the proportion of the population living in poverty, rose four-tenths of a percentage point last year, it was still lower than in most of the last two decades. The poverty rate exceeded 12 percent every year from 1980 to 1998. As the economy grew from 1993 to 2000, the rate plunged, to 11.3 percent from 15.1 percent, and the poverty rolls were reduced by 7.7 million people, to 31.6 million.
The latest recession showed an unusual pattern, seeming to raise poverty rates among whites more than among minority groups, Mr. Weinberg said.
Increases in poverty last year were concentrated in the suburbs, in the South and among non-Hispanic whites, the Census Bureau said. Indeed, non-Hispanic whites were the only racial group for whom the poverty rate showed a significant increase, to 7.8 percent in 2001, from 7.4 percent in 2000.
Poverty rates for minority groups were once much higher. But last year, the bureau said, they remained "at historic lows" for blacks (22.7 percent), Hispanics (21.4 percent) and Asian Americans (10.2 percent).
With its usual caution, the Census Bureau said the data did not conclusively show a year-to-year increase in income inequality. But the numbers showed a clear trend in that direction over the last 15 years. 
The most affluent fifth of the population received half of all household income last year, up from 45 percent in 1985. The poorest fifth received 3.5 percent of total household income, down from 4 percent in 1985. Average income for the top 5 percent of households rose by $1,000 last year, to $260,464, but the average declined or stayed about the same for most other income brackets.
Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research institute, said, "The census data show that income inequality either set a record in 2001 or tied for the highest level on record."
Median earnings increased 3.5 percent for women last year, but did not change for men, so women gained relative to men. 
"The real median earnings of women age 15 and older who worked full time year-round increased for the fifth consecutive year, rising to $29,215 -- a 3.5 percent increase between 2000 and 2001," Mr. Weinberg said. The comparable figure for men was unchanged at $38,275. So the female-to-male earnings ratio reached a high of 0.76. The previous high was 0.74, first recorded in 1996.
Democrats said the data supported their contention that Congress should increase spending on social welfare programs, resisted by many Republicans. But Wade F. Horn, the administration's welfare director, said the number of poor children was much lower than in 1996, when Congress overhauled the welfare law to impose strict work requirements.
Of the 32.9 million poor people in the United States last year, 11.7 million were under 18, and 3.4 million were 65 or older. Poverty rates for children, 16.3 percent, and the elderly, 10.1 percent, were virtually unchanged from 2000. But the poverty rate for people 18 to 64 rose a half percentage point, to 10.1 percent.
Median household income for blacks fell last year by $1,025, or 3.4 percent, to $29,470. Median income of Hispanics, at $33,565, was virtually unchanged. But household income fell by 1.3 percent for non-Hispanic whites, to $46,305, and by 6.4 percent for Asian Americans, to $53,635.
The Census Bureau report also included these findings:
*There were 6.8 million poor families last year, up from 6.4 million in 2000. The poverty rate for families rose to 9.2 percent, from a 26-year low of 8.7 percent in 2000.
*The rate in the South rose to 13.5 percent, from 12.8 percent in 2000. The South is home to more than 40 percent of all the nation's poor, and it accounted for more than half of the national increase in the number of poor last year.
*The poverty rate for the suburbs rose to 8.2 percent last year, from 7.8 percent in 2000. The number of poor people in suburban areas rose by 700,000, to 12 million. There was virtually no change in the rates in central cities (16.5 percent) and outside metropolitan areas (14.2 percent). 
The bureau said the number of "severely poor" rose to 13.4 million last year, from 12.6 million in 2000. People are considered to be severely poor if their family incomes are less than half of the official poverty level.

HEADLINE: After Impasse, F.D.A. May Fill Top Job 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
President Bush intends to nominate Dr. Mark B. McClellan, a member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, to fill the long-vacant job of commissioner of food and drugs, administration officials said today.
 A physician and an economist who advises the president on health policy, Dr. McClellan, 39, is also the brother of the White House deputy press secretary, Scott McClellan. The nomination is expected as early as Wednesday. 
 Congressional aides said today that the Senate would probably confirm Dr. McClellan. That would end a long-running stalemate between the White House and Democrats on Capitol Hill over who should run the Food and Drug Administration, a vast agency that has had no commissioner since Mr. Bush took office 20 months ago.
Dr. McClellan, a native of Texas whose mother is a former mayor of Austin, is regarded as fairly apolitical -- he worked for the Treasury Department under President Bill Clinton in the late 1990's -- and is respected by those who know him as a good listener and someone who can compromise. 
"Mark is a genuine, thoughtful, decent, smart public official," said Ron Pollack, the executive director of Families USA, a group that has often been at odds with the Bush administration and Dr. McClellan. "Despite our disagreements, he has my utmost respect."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts and chairman of the Senate health committee, said Dr. McClellan "has impressive credentials both as a physician and as an economist."
But Dr. McClellan, who was an associate professor of both medicine and economics at Stanford University before joining the Bush administration last year, has little experience in running a large organization. His expertise is largely in health care economics, not regulatory matters of the sort handled by the food and drug agency.
"This is a large agency with a lot of different facets and aspects to it," said a Congressional aide. "There is a question about how much he knows about many of these crucial issues."
With a $1.6 billion budget, the F.D.A. has a reach that covers more than 20 percent of every consumer dollar spent in the United States. The agency, which monitors food safety and approves new drugs and vaccines, has taken on a growing role in national security since the terrorist attacks of last year.
Mr. Bush has been trying to fill the job for more than a year. In July 2001 he put forth the name of a biotechnology industry lawyer, Michael Astrue, but Senate Democrats complained Mr. Astrue was too close to industry.
This February, the administration floated the name of Dr. Alastair J. J. Wood, a drug safety expert at Vanderbilt University, but pharmaceutical executives complained that he would be too aggressive a regulator.
At that point the administration named a deputy commissioner, Dr. Lester Crawford, a veterinarian who is a food safety expert, to run the agency until a permanent chief could be found. Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, favored Dr. Crawford for the top job, but the White House was said to want a physician.
The impasse brought complaints from lawmakers, public interest groups and industry executives, who argued that the agency needed a leader. Last winter Scott McClellan, the deputy press secretary, said the White House was "well along in what has been an exhaustive search" and added, "The focus is on finding the best person."
But the selection process dragged on, in part because Dr. McClellan, who was already under consideration by this time, was not sure he wanted the job, said a person familiar with the search. 
Dr. McClellan, this person said, wanted to devote his attention to helping the White House formulate policy on such matters as prescription drug benefits for the elderly and reforming the nation's medical malpractice laws. But more recently, he decided he had accomplished his goals and was ready to move on.

HEADLINE: Cornucopia of New Statistics Shows City's Best and Worst 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued his report card for New York City's government yesterday, portraying it as having endured a difficult fiscal year, and at times even thriving. As a document, the report card, known as the Mayor's Management Report, said as much about Mr. Bloomberg, the manager, as it did about the city he steers.
 For years, his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, presented reporters with a semiannual tome of positive statistics about the city, chock-a-block with acronyms and asterisks and presented with great fanfare as proof that the city was reaching new heights under Mr. Giuliani's tutelage. 
 Yesterday's presentation, for the fiscal year ending June 30, was quite different. The book featured information on topics that included the cleanliness of streets, test scores at public high schools, and the number of people who receive welfare, statistics that this mayor, who made his fortune by making financial data accessible to anyone with one of his trademarked terminals, clearly enjoyed presenting in a new format. 
The feature the mayor seemed most excited about was a Web site that allows New Yorkers to view statistics about their neighborhoods, and to compare them with other areas of the city, at www.nyc.gov/mmr.
The report featured lots of data neatly packaged, minimal narrative and good art. (The cover image came from a brooding painting of the Brooklyn Bridge by the artist Samuel Halpert.) Indeed, Mr. Bloomberg seemed perplexed when reporters began to pepper him with questions about the substance of the report -- like why arrests for quality-of-life crimes were down, police overtime was up and some school test scores were improving. He preferred to dwell instead on the report's slick packaging and cool user-friendly features.
"There was never the sense of customer focus and customer service that I'm trying to instill, of saying, 'O.K., who's going to read this?' and making it as easy for them to read as possible," the mayor said as he unveiled the new report.
Yesterday's snapshot "shows that during one of the most difficult 12-month periods of our city's history, the performance of city agencies, for the most part, either remained stable or improved over the level of the previous fiscal year," Mr. Bloomberg said. "That is, I think, a remarkable achievement for both the Giuliani administration and the Bloomberg administration."
Indeed, despite the terrorist attack and the subsequent concentration of the city's leaders and police force on possible future threats last year, the city managed to hold its own in many key areas, and even improve some services. For instance, police response times to 911 calls fell sharply, to 7.2 minutes this year from 10.1 minutes the prior year, while the number of New Yorkers on public assistance fell 14 percent from the prior year.
However, there was deterioration in other areas. The percentage of clean streets dropped slightly, and the number of syphilis cases in the city nearly doubled, reflecting a national trend.
Police overtime escalated sharply, to $610 million last year from $338 million the year before. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said that much of the overtime was due to the terrorist attack and the ensuing heightened security.
The report at times painted a remarkable portrait of a city sustaining itself at a time when little was expected of local government. For instance, even as the city's medical examiner's office struggled with the task of identifying victims from the World Trade Center, 93 percent of the city's death certificates were processed within four hours of autopsy. Further, more DNA tests in sexual-assault cases were completed rapidly, largely as a result of new technology and staff members dedicated to that technique. And while many New Yorkers were focused on global issues of personal safety, the city managed to keep parks a wee bit cleaner and to hire more lifeguards last year.
For decades, the Mayor's Management Report has been a case of hunt and peck, with positive statistics presented gleefully and the bad news hidden. Jargon was plentiful. This was particularly true under the Giuliani administration, good-government groups groused. 
While the Bloomberg administration's report is far from comprehensive, those groups say, it is a notable improvement. 
"No mayor enjoys making it easy to find the problems in their administration," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer at the New York Public Interest Research Group. "But this time, when the mayor was asked about the actual details, he turned it over to his commissioners. It wasn't as important for him to defend the information as to just get it out there."
The online component of the report is meant to be user-friendly. After going to the Web site and clicking on "My Neighborhood Statistics," people will be invited to enter their addresses to see how their community boards do in terms of clean streets and noise complaints, how many public assistance recipients their communities have and how many of its public school teachers are certified.
With a little more clicking, they can get color-coded maps to see how their neighborhoods compare in those categories with other community boards around the city. 
While the Bloomberg administration did highlight its favorite statistics in the report in the short narratives of the departments, it did not hide unpleasant realities that have been unavailable in recent years. In a new statistic, it reported that only 58 percent of the restrooms at city parks were in service last year. 
The report graded the government on many of its bread-and-butter functions. 
Reported crime dropped in all major categories (the Police Department does not count the approximately 2,800 people killed in the World Trade Center attacks with other murder victims) and the number of civilian complaints filed against police officers dropped. The number of police officers fell as well, to 36,790, down from 40,285 in 2000.
The city won high marks for fixing broken street lights. The report said that the city responded to reports of broken traffic lights within 48 hours 99.3 percent of the time and to reports of faulty street lights within 10 days 96.9 percent of the time. 
The number of searches of inmates in the city's jails rose to 375,751 last year, up from 312,671 the year before, and the number of inmates slashed or stabbed dropped to 29, from 54 the prior year.
The mayor said that he would continue to update the data, and find better ways of displaying it, whether it was good news or bad news.
"There will be things that work well, there will be things that work poorly," he said. "Sometimes you will get lucky and it will come out good in spite of your actions, sometimes, no matter how hard you try, there will be circumstances that just prevent you from being successful. What we're talking about here is getting the numbers out."

HEADLINE: FED OPTS TO LEAVE RATES UNCHANGED 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave official interest rates unchanged, but 2 of its 12 voting members took the rare step of opposing the decision and instead backed an immediate rate cut.
 The split decision did little to calm the tumult on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at its lowest level in four years. But it was a clear indication that Fed officials, like economists generally, are divided over how to deal with the fears of further weakness in the economy and the uncertainty created by the prospect of war with Iraq. Page C1. 
 It was the first time since 1998 that two members of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee simultaneously broke ranks with Alan Greenspan, the chairman. While there is no indication that Mr. Greenspan's leadership or stature are at risk -- he left for Britain after the meeting to receive an honorary knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II on Thursday -- the dissents highlighted the unease in Washington and the markets about whether the economy is at risk of stalling again.
The vote left investors and analysts uncertain about the Fed's next step. It disappointed some investors, who had hoped the Fed would address the swoon in stock prices, declining consumer confidence and reluctance on the part of businesses to expand and invest.
But the willingness of two Fed members to call for lower rates today suggested to analysts that a rate cut would be on the agenda at the next Fed meeting, on Nov. 6, the day after Congressional elections, when any move the central bank might make would have fewer political implications. If economic indicators point to further weakness, many predicted, the Fed is likely to lower rates at that meeting.
Stock prices fell after the Fed's announcement, and then bounced up and down before closing mostly lower. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 189.02 points to end the day at 7,683.13, its lowest level since Oct. 1, 1998. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.76 points, to 1,182.17. 
The split within the Fed came as Democrats stepped up their efforts to turn attention from the possibility of war to the economy's problems and what they said was a failure of domestic leadership on the part of President Bush and his party.
"Statistic after statistic makes me think there is a real possibility for a double-dip recession," Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic majority leader, told reporters. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic minority leader in the House, said in a floor speech that the nation was suffering from a tumbling stock market, rising unemployment, a wave of corporate scandals and a plunge in consumer confidence.
But after a cabinet meeting at the White House, Mr. Bush said he was optimistic, adding, "When you combine the productivity of the American people with low interest rates and low inflation, those are the ingredients for growth."
The 10-to-2 vote by the Fed left its main interest rate, the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks, at 1.75 percent, its lowest level in more than 40 years. Many types of borrowing, including some home equity lines of credit and small-business loans, generally move in lock step with the Fed's rate. Rates on most mortgages and corporate borrowing are based on interest rates set in the bond market, where long-term rates are also at extremely low levels.
In a statement, the Fed said the economic risks "are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness," phrasing that the central bank uses to signal that it is open to a rate reduction if the outlook does not improve.
The Fed said the economy was growing "at a moderate pace," and it repeated that it saw the current level of rates as low enough to help spur activity in the long run.
But it suggested that its forecast for a gradual recovery was clouded by the economic risks associated with any war with Iraq, and that it was unclear when the economy might pick up.
"Over time, the current accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with still-robust underlying growth in productivity, should be sufficient to foster an improving business climate," the statement said. "However, considerable uncertainty persists about the extent and timing of the expected pickup in production and employment owing in part to the emergence of heightened geopolitical risks."
The two dissenters on today's vote were Edward M. Gramlich, a Fed governor, and Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. Mr. McTeer is known for his belief that the economy can grow at a robust pace without generating inflation. Today's dissent was his fourth in his 12 years.
Mr. Gramlich, by contrast, had not previously dissented since joining the Fed in 1997. Dissents by Fed governors, who serve alongside Mr. Greenspan in Washington, are considerably rarer than those by the regional bank presidents, who often stake out different positions from those held by Mr. Greenspan. 
The last dissent by a governor was in 1995. Since 1992 and 1993, when the Fed was routinely split, there have been only three cases, including today, when two or more members dissented from the majority vote.
The Fed cut the federal funds rate 4.75 percentage points last year in 11 separate moves, but it has been holding steady this year. Its policy has helped keep consumer spending robust by putting downward pressure on mortgage rates and encouraging automakers to offer low or no-interest financing on cars. But it is not clear that the low level of official rates is having much effect on the economy's biggest problems: overcapacity among manufacturers and reluctance by businesses of all kinds to invest in capital equipment. Nor has it done anything to reverse the long slide in stock prices.
Investors and analysts will now be watching closely for any signs that the Fed is inclined to cut rates at its meeting on Nov. 6 or, should the stock market continue to fall and unemployment tick up, before that.
"We're on a slippery slope to a Fed ease," said John Silvia, chief economist at Wachovia Securities. "I suspect that with the next Fed meeting right after the election, they're going to move unless they get better numbers from industrial production, orders and employment."
But other economists said the economy was healthy enough that there was no clear-cut case for further rate cuts.
"The economy's growing at like 3 percent," said Stephen G. Cecchetti, a former Fed official who is now an economics professor at Ohio State University in Columbus. "That may be a little disappointing relative to what we were seeing in the last half of the '90's, but it's nothing to sneer at."

HEADLINE: Oil's Effects on Africa 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "In Quietly Courting Africa, White House Likes Dowry" (front page, Sept. 19), about the increasing importance of African oil to the United States' supply, does not mention the likely negative impact of this increased production on the people of Africa. 
 Several recent academic studies confirm that countries whose economies are dependent on oil exports show exceptionally low living standards; exceptionally high rates of child mortality, malnutrition and income inequality; low rates of literacy and life expectancy; and unusually high rates of corruption, authoritarian government, military spending and civil war. 
Oil production, once viewed as a road to riches, has much more often led to local ruin.

STEPHEN KRETZMANN
Washington, Sept. 19, 2002

The writer is the oil industry analyst at the Institute for Policy Studies.

HEADLINE: Literacy in Afghanistan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Long in Dark, Afghan Women Say to Read Is Finally to See" (front page, Sept. 22): 
 Literacy is indeed the key to improving the well-being of both mothers and children. 
An Afghan woman in your story, Mahgul, said it best: "If I can get some knowledge, I can help my children more." 
Girls who are literate and receive a basic education are more likely to postpone marriage and childbirth, seek health care for themselves and their families, have lower rates of sexually transmitted infections and H.I.V. and encourage their own children, including girls, to go to school.
It is clear: to provide a brighter future for children in Afghanistan and other developing countries, we must invest in mothers and their children.

CHARLES MACCORMACK
President, Save the Children
Westport, Conn., Sept. 24, 2002

HEADLINE: Vox Populi, Online 

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
ON a steamy afternoon last month, Dan Lenahan, a Battery Park City resident, gestured with his cane on the elevated walkway overlooking the World Trade Center site and told eight fellow New Yorkers why his neighborhood needed to remain separated from tourist crowds by West Street, a main artery that some people want to bury to make room for a memorial promenade.
 The meeting was remarkable not because any consensus emerged on how the area should be rebuilt ("It's so elitist," a Greenwich Village resident said of Mr. Lenahan's position), but because this physical gathering in Lower Manhattan arose from a debate in cyberspace. 
 "We wanted to visualize it for ourselves," said Maria Grieco, a music teacher from Queens who took part in the online discussion, organized by the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York as part of its Listening to the City initiative.
Known to one another only by online aliases and argument, the members of the group -- one of 26 in the program -- stayed in touch by e-mail after their two-week discussion ended in early August. And if consensus did not emerge from their field trip, at least the perspective from Battery Park was clarified. 
"Maybe it doesn't have to be a physical reconnection," conceded Margaret Duffy of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, who sympathized with Mr. Lenahan's desire to be done with construction as the group watched dump trucks negotiate the hole below. "Maybe it could be a visual reconnection."
A meeting at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in July at which 4,000 New Yorkers gathered to pass judgment on the original six plans for rebuilding the World Trade Center has been cited as an exercise in the very principles of participatory democracy, in which informed public discussion leads to the best decisions.
Less chronicled is the experience of 800 people who could not make it to the Javits Center that day but instead convened over the Internet over a two-week period to discuss many of the same questions, at more length and perhaps with more nuance. 
The results of the online discussion were included with those of the Javits Center meeting in a report that the Civic Alliance submitted this week to the agencies responsible for the redevelopment, which have promised to study them closely.
But the 10,000-odd messages produced by the online groups are also being scrutinized as a model for civic engagement on local and national issues. Some who have monitored the process suggest that online discussion may be a more promising way to promote democratic debate than a Javits-style town hall -- in part because it is more practical. 
"You don't have to buy people lunch on the Internet or get them a free pass on the ferry to get there," said Robert D. Yaro, the president of the Regional Plan Association, one of the organizers of the Javits Center event and a member of the Civic Alliance. "And people could do this at 3 in the morning if that's when they were free."
The Javits Center meeting cost about $2 million to produce; the online discussions cost about $120,000. Although the online dialogue was skewed toward computer users and involved fewer participants from ethnic minorities, it attracted a significantly higher percentage of people under 34. More than half of the participants in online and offline groups said that their opinions had shifted over the course of the discussions.
Some organizers who tracked both processes say that by prolonging its discussions for two weeks, the online group allowed diverse points of view to be more fully explored. Rapport often developed instantly in their virtual communication, seemingly from the sense of safety people feel as they type into the ether.
"At Javits, there was no bouncing of ideas: we just went around the circle and each person had their say," said Cynthia Schmae, a consultant for Web Lab, a nonprofit organization that specializes in online communication and ran the Web discussions. "You didn't have time to get to know each other so you don't have that flow."
The meetings in Lower Manhattan and in cyberspace were organized against a civic backdrop in which Americans, particularly the young, are voting less, volunteering less and paying less attention to public affairs than those before them. Some advocates see the Internet as a potential lightning rod to encourage more civic involvement.
"In a democracy you want people talking about public issues," said Michael X. Delli Carpini, director of the public policy program at the Pew Charitable Trusts, which is sponsoring an online discussion about volunteering this fall for high school students. "There is a hope that the Internet may be a tool that can allow people to talk in a structured way about things that really matter to them and revive the impetus to say, 'I want to be involved.' "
If there is such potential, government agencies have not paid much attention to it. Only 10 percent of government Web sites offer citizens a way to comment online on issues, according to a study released this month by the Taubman Center for Public Policy at Brown University. Almost none have sponsored online discussions.
"Government planners have a service-deliver vision in which what they want to do is let people do tax filing, order licenses, get business permits online," said Darrell M. West, director of the center at Brown. "But they're not really envisioning the Internet as a tool to alter the relationship between citizens and officials."
There are plenty of reasons to be skeptical about the Internet's power to usher in a new era of Jeffersonian democracy. For now, the medium cannot replicate the visceral thrill of being at the Javits Center as thousands of people saw their votes tallied on a big screen and cheered or booed accordingly. Such emotion may ultimately drive civic participation to a degree that semi-anonymous interactions on a computer screen cannot.
Online forums are also notorious for destructive "flame" wars, a hostile form of exchange rarely seen in face-to-face settings. Stable virtual communities -- Work-From-Home Moms at Ivillage.com or MSN.com's Seed Swappers, for example -- tend to focus on narrow areas of noncontroversial interest. Web sites like CNN recently abandoned their political forums, where genuine debate was rare and grandstanding was frequent.
"It is often said that online communities are good for discussing issues but terrible at resolving them because no one ever concedes the last word," said Cliff Figallo, a former manager of The Well, one of the earliest and longest-running online communities, which has had its share of blowups.
But Mr. Figallo, who helped Web Lab recruit about a dozen volunteer moderators for the Listening to the City discussions, said that those forums were far more cohesive and productive than others he has observed, largely because they were "communities with a purpose."
The online version of the Listening to the City discussions was an afterthought. Carolyn J. Lukensmeyer, the president of AmericaSpeaks, had been planning the Javits Center meeting for months on behalf of the Civic Alliance when she met Marc Weiss, the founder of Web Lab, at a conference. Intrigued by the notion of an online meeting that could handle the overflow from Javits -- and by the Internet's potential for promoting the kind of grass-roots participation that her group advocates -- Ms. Lukensmeyer asked Mr. Weiss if he could raise funds for an online dialogue. 
Securing small grants from AOL Time Warner, the Surdna Foundation and the family of one of his volunteers, Mr. Weiss began registering participants in a matter of weeks. With virtually no advertising, the response was impressive.
Based on personal information required for registration, the 26 online groups were organized to be geographically and demographically diverse. Anyone from New York City and the surrounding counties could take part. Participants received an agenda item by e-mail every few days and responded to polling questions on topics like whom a memorial should commemorate, whether housing should be incorporated on the site and how much green space should be included.
Many participants said they were motivated by a desire to find out what others thought about a subject that they themselves felt strongly about. Others said they hoped somehow to influence the decision on what was built. A driving impulse to contribute almost as a sense of obligation surfaced in many online comments.
"I wanted to participate in what's going to happen next," said Ellen Datlow, 52, a science fiction editor who became the de facto leader of Group 4, the one that met downtown. "This is all I can do -- there is nothing else I can do to make this happen. I'm not a government official. I'm not someone with any say except a New Yorker who cares very much about what happens to the city." 
Whether people could be inspired to take part in online discussions on issues that inspire less passionate feelings is unclear. Organizers also wonder to what degree the sense of common purpose arising from the events of Sept. 11 softened and civilized the online interaction. 
But the discussion was certainly not bland. The groups, which had an average of about 30 members, exhibited the gamut of online behavior. There were members who never posted, showoffs who competed for the longest and most articulate posts, and one flamethrower who was barred from his group midway through the discussions for disruptive behavior, including posting "Rebuild the towers exactly the way they were" over and over again. 
Civic activists debate whether discussion in itself helps shore up democratic ideals, or if influencing policymakers must be the goal. An informal poll of several participants indicated that as much as they enjoyed the back-and-forth, they would like their words to have an impact rather than simply occupying cyberspace.
"Who am I?" said one, Vincent Pecoraro, a bank manager who works in Lower Manhattan. "The Port Authority owns the land. Larry Silverstein owns the lease. But there's a slim chance of hope that they're going to listen. That will be wonderful if I could have been a part of that."
