HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; 
The Half-Life Of Must-Haves

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE phalaenopsis orchid must have, in the wise words of Hollywood, changed agents this year. It is appearing as an interior accessory in Architectural Digest, Elle Decor, Traditional Home, House Beautiful and Real Simple.
 "They're pretty much on every page of every magazine," said David Stanley, the owner of Horticus in Los Angeles, a flower shop that specializes in orchids. Mr. Stanley's sales of the $35 white phalaenopsis have shot from 100 to 500 plants a month in the last year. "I can't imagine anyone getting tired of something so beautiful," he said. "But it's happening, thank God. I'm sick of them." 
 The furnishings world has always had fashion envy, but it would do well to remind itself that fashion has its victims. 
Every fall season brings its bumper crop of styles and looks for the home, and with it, gently put, a ubiquity beyond belief. Coral, Andy Warhols, square table lamps.
For every Mombasa bag, the horn-handled handbag not seen at the New York fashion shows last week (it was a waiting-list item in March), there is also a piece, a pattern or a palette that has shown up at one too many parties in the September-October whirl of decorating magazines, catalogs and shops.
On the horizon: overscaled houndstooth checks. Sailing toward the horizon: the French 1940's. Off the map: Asian fusion, and pink.
"I wouldn't base my whole life on pink now," said James Leland Day, a stylist for photography shoots whose own pink apartment is pictured in Living Room magazine. "I don't think it's over, but it's peaking." There are also stories featuring pink in October's House & Garden and House Beautiful. Mr. Day moved to a new apartment last month and painted it green and blue.
"I had to push the envelope," he said.
White is the new black this year in design fashion, in particular a 1960's Pop Art movie-set white, seen most prominently in September's "Glamour Now" Vogue. White leather seemed as kicky as a plastic go-go boot when it showed up last year on Mies van der Rohe's Barcelona chairs in the private Playboy Club-like penthouse at the Park in Chelsea. It is pictured in the new catalog from Design Within Reach, a mass-market modern furniture retailer, on Barcelona chairs and daybeds, traditionally upholstered in black. The English club furniture in the public rooms at the Viceroy, a late-model boutique hotel in Santa Monica designed by Kelly Wearstler, is also upholstered in white leather, not brown.
"It's beachy, it's crisp," said Ms. Wearstler, when asked what inspired her. "I'm a leader, not a follower."
Morocco is a popular at-home destination this year, in September's W and October's Chic Simple. "The Marrakesh thing is over," said Nate Berkus, a decorator in Chicago, speaking of its power to excite as a style. "It's everywhere; it's exhausting. The family room as opium den. I wish that was my family."
Margaret Russell, editor in chief of Elle Decor, said, "One too many lanterns." (September's Elle Decor included a Moroccan-themed "hippy chic" TriBeCa loft.)
How does Ms. Russell determine what not to publish? "You just reach a saturation point, in submissions, like you're seeing the same place over and over again," she said. Ebonized floors and the "15th take on Christian Liaigre" are Code Red, red not being the new black.
Ms. Russell still likes toile de Jouy, something of a reprieve. "When you saw it, you knew it would come and go," said Mr. Day, the stylist. The French fabric, printed with 18th-century patterns, which streaked through decoration several years ago, fashionable and fresh-looking in modern interiors, has come -- and gone to the bank laughing. Target is selling it, as draperies and pants. Look for toile as place mats from E.A.T. in New York and bedsheets and tablecloths in the Martha Stewart mail-order catalog.
"The collection is selling unbelievably well," said Stacy Senior Allan, marketing manager of Thibaut, a wallpaper and fabric company with a choice of 22 toiles.
"We asked our customers recently about whether it was peaking," Ms. Senior Allan said. "They get worried when they see it on pants. But we think it will be a long-lasting trend."
Unlike sunflowers.
"Big in 1994 and '95," she recalled, like the remotest history.
Or monkeys.
"They're cute, but we're tired of them," Ms. Senior Allan said. "It was part of the British colonial thing. It's hanging on in parts of the South."
Ms. Senior Allan observed that trends now had longer lives because of economic recession and a desire for familiarity.
"Even in fashion, they're letting women wear things for two seasons instead of one," she said. "It's the same in home furnishings. You have to get comfortable with it. They're smart not to let people think they're out of fashion, that they have to redecorate every year. They'll just give up."
Jonathan Adler, a popular designer, when asked if he felt at risk of becoming a cliche, or if his work was in danger of being overexposed, said, "It takes a lot more courage to extend a trend than to start one." Mr. Adler's signature vases and pillows, with his name firmly attached in captions to pictures, have showed up in more than a few magazines lately. 
"We in New York live in a very rarefied world," he said. "Jaded and 'too cool for school.' As someone in the business of selling things, I've discovered how small the jaded world is. And how poor."
Mr. Adler, a potter by training, has stores in Los Angeles, East Hampton and SoHo and plans to open a new store on the Upper East Side in November. 
Ikea, the international cheap furnishings giant, has unleashed an advertising campaign to unmoor people from their emotional attachments to household possessions, and to promote disposability in decorating -- a high-speed obsolescence not unlike your standard trend.
"If you're in a bad relationship with old furniture but don't put an end to it, you are crazy," reads an advertisement that pictures a sturdy, serviceable table lamp that looks like someone's first spouse.
How do you learn to love again? 
"If I love it, we adapt it," said Thomas O'Brien, the president of Aero Studios in New York, and its principal designer. Mr. O'Brien's square-based, square-shaded table lamp, designed in 1992 and still in production, is instantly recognizable, in large part because of the number of look-alikes.
"It's a classic form from the 1920's and 30's," he said, acknowledging his own sources. "I have a big belief in subtle changes, like different finishes, or recoloring, or scale." Mr. O'Brien explained, "It's like clothing -- what we retire is the finishing, not the form."
Mr. Berkus, in Chicago, concurred. "Decoration is so expensive," he said. "You have to be careful about what you choose, that it doesn't play out quickly. You can call it classic, but . . . a $10,000 sofa -- it's like a commitment ceremony. There should be a blood test."
Mr. Berkus advised indulging a taste for fashion in other ways. "Don't even buy new furniture," he said. "Start at the smaller local auction houses. Paint, wall coverings, moldings, lighting, window treatments, carpeting -- the backdrop can change easily."
What does Mr. Berkus do when clients come to him with magazine pictures of popular trends in hand?
"Toile is one right now," he said. "You go with something that's similar -- it might still be a two-colored woven French textile, but it's not the Japanese garden scene you're seeing on the cover of Pottery Barn."
Joseph Riccio, a New York designer, advised touches, not strokes, that can be quickly erased. "Pillows, etc.," he said. "Bring cliches in as minor elements. As soon as the look is over, it's easier to reinterpret, instead of changing direction."
David Netto, a New York designer whose white 1960's-style basement Pop Art playroom project appeared in Living Room, said that it was designed at the client's instruction, which was "lacquer, lacquer, lacquer -- white was appended to that."
"I like not to have a signature look," Mr. Netto said. "The first thing I thought when I saw Bilbao was, 'This is great, but I wouldn't want to see two of them.' "
Mr. Netto's client had contemporary art to display, from a family collection in Houston. Mr. Netto chose work by Chuck Close, Christo and "small Rothkos."
Any Andy Warhols, King of Pop? Warhol's Factory produced, like a 20th-century toile de Jouy, nearly 10,000 silk-screen images on canvas, according to the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. Seven, including portraits of Goethe and Jimmy Carter, made cameo appearances in October's House & Garden and The World of Interiors -- as properly bourgeois an interior decoration as a Vermeer in a 17th-century Dutch town house.
"No," Mr. Netto said of the job. "Warhol is exactly what you would expect to find."

HEADLINE: For Game Makers, Inspiration In the Soul of an Old Machine 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KUSHNER 

 BODY:
ONCE a year Malte Mundt and his friends in northern Germany party like it's 1982. That's the year the Commodore 64 hit the shelves, and Mr. Mundt and the other self-described C64 freaks stage an annual bash to celebrate their beloved, obsolete computers.
 Commodore memorabilia is traded. Beer flows. And most of all, games are played. Not just the dusty old ones, but new titles that hard-core hobbyists have been programming for the old machine. 
 This is the subculture of home-brew gaming: games composed on modern computers but played on ancient and discontinued systems like the Commodore 64, the Amiga and the Atari 2600. The coders are the Dr. Frankensteins of their world, digging up dead hardware and inserting the brains of fresh software. Part nostalgia, part programming challenge, home-brew games offer a glimpse into not only the passion of players but also the staying power of the game industry's pioneering hardware. "They have a magic that no other systems can come up with," Mr. Mundt said.
The resurgence of interest in retro games comes as the modern game industry enjoys unprecedented success. Despite the poor economy and the dot-com crash, video games earned a record $10.8 billion last year in the United States alone. The trinity of leading video game consoles -- Microsoft's Xbox, Nintendo's GameCube and Sony's PlayStation 2 -- have seduced the mainstream with robust graphics and sophisticated characters.
But gamers old enough to remember the days of the Commodore 64 and Atari 2600 are not necessarily won over by the newfangled wares. "Consoles are much more powerful and amusing for the general population," said Roman Chlebec, a 26-year-old Webmaster in Slovakia who runs a popular Commodore 64 site called the C64 Portal (www.c64.sk). "But those who grew up with C64 aren't so easily lured by computing power or number of colors." 
"You can still make games that are fun and interesting even if they pale in comparison to the Xbox," said Albert Yarusso, of Austin, Tex., who runs Atari Age (www.atariage.com), a site for fans of that company's systems, including the 2600, which was introduced in 1977 and dominated the industry for many years. Classic games like Pong and Pac-Man delivered a pure kind of competition that did not require digesting a 40-page handbook. More important, Mr. Yarusso said, unlike many of today's games, which can cost millions of dollars to develop, classic games did not require the collaboration of dozens of people on a team but could be written by one person.
Mr. Mundt, who creates Commodore 64 games with a group of hobbyists who call themselves Protovision, is driven by a pragmatic appreciation of the wares. "The system architecture for the Commodore is so simple and straightforward," he said. "It's nothing like Windows." Protovision has created games like Metal Dust, a shoot-'em-up, and Reel Fishing, a rod-and-reel simulation.
Many home-brew creators are game industry employees looking for a diversionary test of their coding skills. Mike Mika, the 29-year-old creative director of Digital Extremes, a company in London, Ontario, that makes games for the Xbox, GameCube and PlayStation 2, is responsible for one of the current hits on the home-brew scene. Aiming to improve upon one of his favorite games for the Atari 2600, Berzerk, Mr. Mika re-engineered the game to include the voice-overs originally found only in the arcade version of Berzerk. 
Making such games is a taxing labor of love, however, Mr. Mika said. "To get the 2600 to do anything requires a lot of research and digging," he said. Since the systems could support only a very small amount of data, they require the programmers to make the most out of bare-bones game play. 
Those creating titles for the cartridge-based Atari systems have the added challenge of packaging their goods. This requires them to crack open old cartridges, rip out the chips, then solder in new ones containing their code. The home-brew programmers trade or sell their creations over the Internet, at gaming conventions and at specialty shops for around $20 to $50.
Infogrames, the company that now owns the Atari license, doesn't mind players' tinkering with the obsolete wares. "If they're making games that work on the system, then more power to them," said Steve Allison, a spokesman for the company in New York. In fact, Infogrames has been exploiting the vintage factor itself. Playable versions of classic Atari titles like Tempest and Centipede are now featured during the load-in screens of Xbox and PlayStation 2 games.
Of course, if the home-brew gamers were getting rich, this might be another story. At best, they said they make soda money. Protovision has sold about 1,000 games through its site and has gained a following within the expanding C64 scene. But the Protovision programmers are not looking to dethrone consoles anytime soon. Instead, they are content to share their creations with one another over a few drinks at a party with friends.
"With one megahertz and 0.064 megabytes of memory, it shouldn't be possible to do anything, according to the multimedia hype of today," Mr. Mundt said. He takes pleasure in proving those multimedia partisans wrong. "It's fascinating what can be done with this machine."

HEADLINE: Japan Markets Resume Their Search for the Bottom 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
With another bout of selling today, Japan's leading stock market index finished erasing all its gains from one week ago, when the nation's central bank startled investors by announcing an unorthodox plan to buy company shares held by wobbling commercial banks.
 But though the announcement had only a fleeting effect on the Nikkei index, which is once again flirting with 20-year lows, its political impact still seems to be developing. Reports raced around Tokyo tonight that a senior official widely regarded as a roadblock to aggressive action on Japan's long-running banking crisis might be on the verge of departing. 
 The Mainichi newspaper reported that Hakuo Yanagisawa, the chief of the Financial Services Agency, the principal financial regulatory body in Japan, said he would resign because he opposed the new plan to bail out banks with public funds. In the late 1990's, Mr. Yanagisawa oversaw a huge banking bailout costing billions of dollars, and some analysts think he opposes a second one because it would amount to an admission that the first one failed. 
Mr. Yanagisawa said today that "there is no truth" to the resignation report. But Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was more coy, telling reporters today only that "it has not become a topic yet."
The prime minister's approval ratings jumped back up to about 60 percent after his visit last week to North Korea. The terms in office of a number of officials in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party expire Monday, and Mr. Koizumi has scheduled meetings this week to pick a new slate; he may use the occasion for a minor cabinet shuffle as well.
The first half of the Japanese fiscal year also ends Monday, a day of reckoning for the banks. By law they must revalue their huge portfolios of stocks and other assets based on that day's market prices, which will probably mean booking large losses. Analysts say that if the Nikkei average falls below about 8,000, some of the big banks will find themselves with too little capital to meet international standards; the Nikkei closed today at 9,165.41.
The looming accounting deadline, coupled with a possible break in the political deadlock here, will help make Japan a focus of attention on Friday, when finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven industrialized nations gather in Washington for a conference.
With its banking system saddled with at least $425 billion in nonperforming loans, Japan, the world's second-largest economy, stopped being an engine of global growth long ago. Now, with exports having declined slightly during the three summer months, it appears that last spring's tentative economic upturn has ended. For the full year, Japan's economy will probably shrink by half a percentage point, the worst showing of any major world economy, the International Monetary Fund estimated today.
"The banking system is struggling, consumer spending is down, the U.S. economy is weak, oil prices are near $30, there is deflation, political gridlock, reforms that have not been implemented -- otherwise, things are perfect," said Mickey Kantor, the former secretary of commerce, on Tuesday during a visit to Tokyo.
According to a senior Bank of Japan official, the surprise plan to buy stocks from banks was meant, in a season of policy drift, as "a wake-up call to banks, the government and the public."
"This unprecedented action by the Bank of Japan was driven by our serious concern about the current state of our financial system, which could not be fixed without more outright public intervention," the official said in a briefing to foreign reporters, on condition that he not be identified by name. "We thought this might be the last chance. The government and the prime minister are now under pressure by our action."
The plan's parameters -- a maximum of $15 billion in shares to be bought over the next two years -- will not free up nearly enough capital by itself to cope with the mountain of bad loans. But "the Bank of Japan action at least deserves some credit for showing the willingness to think outside the box," said Kenneth Rogoff, chief economist for the International Monetary Fund, speaking to reporters in Washington today. 
Last week's announcement by the bank, which has a fair degree of independence, caught the government off guard. Markets fell when Mr. Koizumi failed to follow it immediately with new action on the bad-loan problem; instead, he promised new measures in a month. The lack of coordination drew criticism.
"Unless you serve the main course while the appetizer is still warm, it can only have limited impact," said Kathy Matsui, chief investment strategist here for Goldman Sachs.
Mr. Yanagisawa said last weekend in a videoconference with American and European officials that Japanese banks were making progress, disposing of some $80 billion in bad loans this year, and that they were on track to get the problem under control by 2005. But others are skeptical.
"It is very important for us to see whether the F.S.A. will have a comprehensive and concrete solution in the near term, which I don't think is happening," Takahira Ogawa, head of Asian sovereign ratings for Standard & Poor's, told reporters here today, referring to the Financial Services Agency. "If that is the case, it was the wrong decision by the Bank of Japan."
Robert A. Feldman, chief economist here for Morgan Stanley, voiced a common note when he said: "If Yanagisawa retains his office, it is a signal to markets that there will be no change in strategy. The markets will react negatively."
While one foreign analyst calls the Bank of Japan's stock purchase plan "Japan's Hail Mary pass," bank officials say they are unfazed by the markets' fall back to earth. They say they never intended the share purchase plan to be a "price-keeping operation," as efforts to prop up markets here have been nicknamed.
Warning that "stock prices could fall further," Masaru Hayami, the bank's governor, told a parliamentary committee today that "the plan is meant to provide stability to the overall system."
In a different measure of skepticism about Japan's stock markets, Merrill Lynch said on Tuesday that its Japanese equities division would be grouped with the rest of Asia and administered from Hong Kong. Earlier this year, Merrill closed most of its retail brokerage branches in Japan after losses of nearly $200 million over three years.
"A bad debt resolution has been the financial markets' holy grail over the past decade," Richard Jerram, chief economist for ING Barings Securities Japan, wrote to clients Tuesday. "There have been so many disappointments that we have to fight hard to avoid automatic dismissal of any measures that are announced. Healthy skepticism is a better approach."

HEADLINE: Small Loans to Small Concerns in Brazil 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
A handwritten notice taped on Lucia Velli's front door in the heart of Heliopolis, one of Sao Paulo's oldest and most labyrinthine shantytowns, announces that Mrs. Velli, a seamstress, is looking for help.
 "Now I have the new machine, I can hire an extra girl," said Mrs. Velli who, at 46, has been given the chance to prove her entrepreneurial worth thanks to a loan of less than $400 from a new microlending operation in her neighborhood. 
 The secondhand sewing machine that she bought with the money can run up the clothes that she puts together for Lojas Riachuelo, a major Brazilian retail chain, at speeds of up to 7,000 stitches a minute. That is twice the pace of any of the three rickety machines that clatter away in her tiny upstairs sewing room, and with it, Mrs. Velli calculates, she can double her current weekly production of 700 garments.
"My idea is to pay off the machine in a year and then take out another loan to buy another one," Mrs. Velli said. 
"It also means I could start up a night shift."
Brazil was one of the first countries in the world to experiment with microfinance nearly 30 years ago. But making small loans to minute businesses never really caught on here, largely because years of hyperinflation and a series of wilting currencies made interest rates prohibitive for would-be borrowers. 
And, as in most other developing countries, in Brazil microfinance was largely considered a development issue rather than a business. Projects were typically run by government institutions or aid groups -- the so-called nongovernmental organizations -- rather than by commercial banks, which were involved mainly as donors. That meant that even though hundreds of microfinancing projects sprang up across the country, none really gained critical mass.
Last month, however, Banco Real, which is owned by ABN Amro of the Netherlands and is Brazil's fifth-largest private bank, introduced Real Microcredito.
Though it is just a one-branch loan operation serving Heliopolis's estimated 100,000 inhabitants and 3,000 small, mainly informal, businesses, it is the first such effort by a major bank here. If successful, it could help spread commercial lending to thousands of small Brazilian companies currently starved of credit. "Scale is important in a country as big as Brazil," said Maria Otero, president of Accion International, a microlending group based in Boston that is Banco Real's partner in the Heliopolis project. Banco Real's involvement, she predicted, could get other major banks interested across the region.
"So far, commercial banks haven't even dabbled in microfinance, so this is an extremely significant effort," she said. 
Short-term loans are made with an interest rate of 3.5 percent a month, compared with rates as high as 12 percent on bank overdrafts and 20 percent offered by local money lenders.
"It's in our statutes that the bank should generate wealth not only for shareholders and employees, but also for the community," said Maria Luisa Pinto, director of social responsibility at Banco Real. "So once you've said you'll do something, you'd better do it."
For banks operating in Brazil, first-half profits rose 45 percent, to some $3 billion, from the first six months of 2001, according to the central bank, while average family income has fallen in the last four years. But Ms. Pinto vehemently rebuffs any suggestions that her bank's microcredit effort is either charity or a marketing gimmick.
"Yes, there is a value added for the bank's image, but that's not why we are doing this," she said. "Compared with the bank's other operations, the program is irrelevant in terms of size, but its impact on society is not irrelevant at all."
"We don't expect it to boost our profits by millions, but the program must be able to finance itself and grow," she added.
Carlos Daniel Coradi, president of the Sao Paulo financial consulting firm EFC, said banks were anticipating that whichever candidate wins Brazil's presidential elections on Oct. 6 will probably squeeze the profits of banks from market operations, cut interest rates and encourage the industry to provide more accessible loans to help kick-start the flagging economy.
"ABN is simply being very intelligent and is first off the mark," he said. "I wouldn't be surprised if other Brazilian banks, such as Bradesco have similar plans waiting in the wings for after the elections."
Backed by Accion International and $750 million from USAID, Real Microcredito has 3 managers and 11 credit agents, or young account managers who don yellow and green T-shirts with the slogan "Let's grow together" and the bank's telephone number. They plow Heliopolis streets prospecting for business.
So far, 23 loans of $60 to $1,500 have been granted for periods of 4 to 12 months, but Flavio Weizenmann, who coordinates the project at Banco Real, predicts each agent will soon have 200 to 300 clients.
Depending on the success of the Heliopolis pilot program, Banco Real expects to open microcredit branches in two other poor areas of Sao Paulo next year and then to start expanding across Brazil.
In the poorer northeast, where Banco Real has bought two state-owned banks, Mr. Weizenmann expects to have 16,000 clients and $7 million in outstanding loans five years from now. He estimates the potential market for microloans in Brazil to be 10 million to 12 million borrowers.
With 6,000 clients, the Heliopolis project should break even, he said.
The poor are a good credit risk, Ms. Otero of Accion said. "In 20 years of lending to over three million people in Latin America, Accion has a loan loss rate of about 2.5 percent," she said -- a very low rate.
Banco Real works hard to eliminate risks. Clients and credit agents go over the accounts of borrowers carefully before any cash is disbursed. Mrs. Velli almost failed to get a loan because her agent discovered she had not paid a $7 phone bill.
Business plans are also discussed. Marcelo Pinto, who heads the Heliopolis branch (and is no relation to Ms. Pinto of Banco Real), said that although most applicants have little formal education, they often prove to be as sharp as many an M.B.A. 
Joao Nogueira, a pastry chef who supplies cafes and colleges across Sao Paulo with cheese puffs and spicy meat pies from a tiny kitchen in Heliopolis, said a loan of just $280 gave him "alavancagem" or leverage, to negotiate cheaper prices with suppliers by paying upfront.
"I currently make 12,000 pies a month, and I can't keep up with demand," he said. 
"I think 20,000 a month is a reasonable target, so I'm hoping this first loan will get my foot in the door at the bank and next year they will give me a bigger loan so I can expand."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 27, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in World Business yesterday about loans to small businesses in Brazil misstated the financial backing provided by the United States Agency for International Development to Real Microcredito, a commercial venture making such loans. The agency, known as USAID, provided $750,000, not $750 million.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
McCall Answers Negative Ads

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

 BODY:
 H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic nominee for governor, released this 30-second ad yesterday to be shown on upstate New York broadcast stations and cable stations in the suburbs of New York City. It is his first ad in a week and the first in response to two negative ads by Gov. George E. Pataki in the past week.

PRODUCER -- GMMB

ON THE SCREEN -- Mr. McCall speaking into the camera with occasional flashes of text, emphasizing his points.

THE SCRIPT -- "I'm Carl McCall, the guy George Pataki's running all those false, negative ads against. So let me set the record straight. I oppose any tax increase. As comptroller I uncovered $1.6 billion in wasteful spending and invested 70 percent more in New York businesses. With our economy and schools failing, George Pataki figures he can't defend his record, so he attacks me instead. I think New York deserves better, and that's why I'm running for governor."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Pataki is running two English-language negative commercials (and a Spanish-language one) against Mr. McCall. Mr. McCall's stance on taxes has not always been clear. In a television interview last year, he did advocate restoring the "commuter tax" on workers who live outside New York City. In a debate last month he said taxes should be "the last thing we should think about." He backs up his assertions about wasteful spending with reports issued by his own office. Mr. Pataki's campaign disputes Mr. McCall's assertions about investments in New York. They cite annual reports of the pension fund Mr. McCall oversees to assert that during Mr. McCall's tenure as comptroller "direct investments" in New York fell 39 percent, to 6.1 percent from 10.1 percent. The state of the schools and economy depend on what part of the state you are in.

SCORECARD -- This is a double-barreled ad, seeking to confront Mr. Pataki's criticisms while allowing Mr. McCall to present himself to voters, many of whom, polls indicate, do not know who he is. Mr. McCall tries for a personal connection, looking directly into the camera, but he runs the risk of sounding defensive and giving weight to Mr. Pataki's criticisms by reminding viewers what they were. Still, a substantial number of potential voters will never see this ad, or two of Mr. Pataki's, because they are not running on New York City stations. RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Employment and prosperity affect body inflation.

BYLINE:  By Hal R. Varian; Hal R. Varian is an economics professor and dean of the School of Information Management and Systems at the University of California at Berkeley. E-mail:hal@sims.berkeley.edu.

 BODY:
CLOSE to half the American population is estimated to be overweight, a condition that has serious economic consequences because of its impact on labor supply and health care.
 Body weight is itself influenced by economic variables, often in complex ways. For much of human history, poorer people were thinner than richer people. Even today, inhabitants of rich countries tend to be heavier than those of poor countries. But within countries, wealthier people often weigh less than others. What causes these differences? 
 The economic determinants of weight are investigated in "The Growth of Obesity and Technological Change," a recent paper by Darius Lakdawalla and Tomas Philipson (National Bureau of Economic Research Working Paper No. 8,946).
Mr. Lakdawalla and Mr. Philipson argue that there are two distinct economic drivers of body weight: a supply-side effect caused by higher incomes and lower food prices, and a demand-side effect caused by the increasingly sedentary nature of work.
Rich countries tend to have relatively low food prices and more sedentary jobs than do poor countries, making them fatter on average. But within rich countries, everyone faces the same food prices and similar technology, so differences in weight are influenced by other factors, like education and income.
Doctors perennially tell us to eat less and exercise more. But economic factors are working against their advice: food keeps becoming cheaper and work keeps becoming physically easier. It's not surprising that we keep gaining weight, despite our doctors' advice.
There has certainly been a sharp increase in weight over the last century, equivalent to a 30-pound gain for a 6-foot man. Remarkably, this change occurred while the calories available from the food supply declined over much of this period. Only in the last 10 years have the calories per person per day climbed significantly over the level available in 1909.
This suggests that, in aggregate, most of the increase results from too little exercise, not too many calories. Mr. Lakdawalla and Mr. Philipson set out to try to determine just what fraction of the weight gain can be attributed to each factor.
They start with a data set that tracks individual reports on occupation and weight. The Bureau of Labor Statistics rates occupations by how physically strenuous they are, so this allows determining the average amount of exercise associated with each person.
Mr. Lakdawalla and Mr. Philipson were rightly suspicious of the self-reported weight figures in their sample and found another data set with both self-reported and measured weight, which allowed them to estimate actual weight from the self-reported figures. One interesting finding: virtually all women tend to underreport their weight, while only heavier men do; lighter men tend to overreport it.
The next step was to determine how food prices and income affect weight. Income was relatively easy, since it was reported in the original survey. Prices were harder, but the authors solved this with a clever trick. About half the states levy a sales tax on food, while half do not. Hence the relative price of food varies from state to state, and this variation is enough to estimate the impact of price changes on body weight.
Mr. Lakdawalla and Mr. Philipson report a number of findings. More schooling tends to reduce weight, but by a relatively modest amount. Being black or Hispanic tends to increase weight, by a quite significant amount. Being in a sedentary occupation for a year leads to a small increase in weight; but staying in that occupation for 14 years causes a significant increase.
These are all statements about the partial effect of each economic variable, holding the other variables fixed. An increase in schooling tends to increase income, so weight might go up on both accounts. But economists are generally interested in the partial effect of an increase in schooling, holding income fixed. Determining such partial effects requires a model of the behavioral forces that jointly determine the relevant variables.
After a detailed statistical analysis of the data, the authors conclude that about 40 percent of the growth in weight in the last 20 years has been caused by the increased supply of food and 60 percent by the increase in sedentary employment.
As the authors put it: people used to be paid to exercise, since most work involved heavy physical labor. Now we have to pay to exercise, by taking time away from sitting in front of computers and TV's.
Technological change, the main culprit in the fattening of America, may yet save us. Research in weight-control drugs, food and technology is booming, so perhaps scientists will find a way that we can have our cake and eat it, too (a particularly apt metaphor in this context).
Mr. Lakdawalla and Mr. Philipson point out that while their study focuses on the supply of calories, the quality of calories matters as well. The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey reports that the portion of calories generated by fat consumption actually fell in the 1980's. But the increase in total calories consumed in that period pushed up the total fat intake. Examining the changing composition of calories is a promising avenue for future research.
Let me suggest that it would also be of considerable interest to extend this study to other cultures. My unscientific observations suggest that Europeans -- particularly the French -- consume a higher proportion of fat in their diets, but they also eat smaller portions and walk much more.
I wonder if the National Bureau of Economic Research would sponsor a trip to Paris to observe at close hand the eating practices of the French. It would be necessary, of course, to spend many hours sitting at cafes observing their daily habits. Yes, this is tough work, but I suspect that some economist would be willing to take up the challenge.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two researchers say that there are distinct economic determinants that are influencing body weight: higher incomes and lower food prices and the increasingly sedentary nature of work. (Getty Images)

HEADLINE: With Pataki And McCall, Tone Takes A Nasty Turn 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and H. Carl McCall yesterday traded a ferocious round of accusations on education, claiming failed policies and dishonest campaigning, with each side unveiling a new television ad attacking the other.
 Once again, the campaigns turned up the volume on a contest for governor that was already noisier and nastier than races usually get before the final weeks. They issued a flurry of statements in even harsher language -- "lying," "desperate," "disastrous" -- than in their carefully worded ads. 
 A new poll released yesterday showed that Mr. McCall, the Democratic candidate, had pulled within 11 percent of the Republican governor among likely voters, a far cry from the 20- to 30-point leads Mr. Pataki enjoyed for most of the year. The poll, by Quinnipiac University, had Mr. Pataki at 46 percent and Mr. McCall at 35 percent.
Tom Golisano, the Independence Party nominee who has spent more than $31 million of his own money on the race, had 14 percent of the vote, double his share two months ago.
Strategists in all three campaigns said the poll -- which roughly mirrors other recent surveys, including the campaigns' -- helps explain some of the desperate tone heard yesterday from the Pataki and McCall camps. 
The governor wants to deliver a knockout blow to Mr. McCall before the state comptroller can define himself in the eyes of voters, many of whom are still unfamiliar with him or his record, and before he can make a close race of it.
But if Mr. McCall pulls any closer, he will be taken more seriously and will be able to raise more money, lessening his campaign's enormous financial disadvantage.
Referring to the poll, Mr. McCall said, "It's clear that maybe the governor is threatened by that and is trying to derail our momentum, but he will not be able to do it because the people of New York want change."
When asked about the campaign, the governor insisted that he did not look at polls and disavowed any role in his own ads. But his spokesman, Michael McKeon, compared Mr. McCall to the Democrat Mr. Pataki thrashed in 1998, winning by 21 percentage points. "It looks like Carl McCall is right on track to end up slightly ahead of Peter Vallone, which has got to be very disturbing to him and his fund-raising team," he said.
Mr. McCall has made education the centerpiece of his campaign, assailing the governor for, among other things, opposing a lawsuit that demanded more money for New York City's schools, and blocking the expansion of prekindergarten programs.
After largely ignoring the attacks, the Pataki campaign began a full-throated response last week, with a series of ads attacking Mr. McCall's record on economic development and as president of New York City's Board of Education in the early 1990's. Mr. Pataki's new ad continued that drumbeat, this time in Spanish.
The new McCall ad responded by accusing the governor of deceit. It begins with the candidate saying, "I'm Carl McCall, the guy George Pataki's running all those false, negative ads against."
A Pataki campaign statement responded, charging that there had been "months of misleading attacks by Carl McCall that have distorted the proud Pataki record for education."
Allen R. Cappelli, Mr. McCall's campaign manager, responded back, saying that after "a series of desperate, misleading, negative ads, George Pataki is floundering."
His counterpart, Adam Stoll, then accused Mr. McCall of going back on a promise not to engage in negative campaigning. "Which Carl McCall do you believe?" he asked.
Mr. Cappelli said that "George Pataki is lying about Carl McCall's record" and using "phony numbers."
All but lost in the din were the candidates themselves. Mr. Golisano visited downtown Manhattan to declare that the state was heading into a fiscal crisis, which he blamed mostly on the governor, and to propose a program of belt-tightening.
State officials and financial analysts say the state faces a multibillion-dollar deficit next year, after significantly raising spending three years in a row, despite the economic downturn. A top Pataki ally, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, who has been campaigning for Mr. Pataki, recently predicted that the gap will be $8 billion to $10 billion.
Mr. Pataki's office and his campaign have consistently refused to address questions about that problem. Yesterday, Mr. McKeon said Mr. Bruno's estimate was too high, but declined to offer another one.
Mr. Golisano has mostly trained his fire on the governor, but he suggested yesterday that might change. He said he would run "a campaign against the duopoly of the Republicans and Democrats and the conditions that they've got our state into."
Mr. McCall and Mr. Pataki attended the same event outside the United Nations building in Manhattan, though not at the same time, joining in the Jewish Community Council's celebration of the holiday Sukkot. Each man sat in a sukkah, a small hut built for the occasion, joined a rabbi in a toast with Fresca, spoke out in favor of Israel and deplored the recent bombings there.
Today, former Vice President Al Gore will be the star attraction at a fund-raising reception for Mr. McCall. Mr. Pataki will turn to a more unlikely source for star power, collecting the endorsement of the rapper LL Cool J.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 27, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the campaign for New York governor misstated the name of the sponsor of a Sukkot celebration that the candidates attended at the United Nations. It is the Jewish Community Relations Council of New York, not the Jewish Community Council.

HEADLINE: Tyco's Chief Says Earnings Will Be Lower Than Expected 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

 BODY:
In his first presentation to analysts and investors since his appointment as Tyco International's new chief executive in late July, Edward D. Breen said yesterday that the company's earnings in the fourth quarter would be much lower than earlier expected.
 Mr. Breen, who has hired forensic accountants to undertake a review of the company's accounting for the last three years in the wake of criminal charges against its former top executives, said that he now expected to report earnings of 30 to 33 cents a share for the quarter ending this month instead of the 45 to 47 cents the company had estimated in in July. 
 Despite the revised earnings expectation, which he attributed to higher-than-expected taxes and slow electronics operations, Mr. Breen said that his examination of the company's books left him comfortable with Tyco's past accounting. In response, investors bid up Tyco's shares 10 percent, or $1.41, to $15 a share, on his upbeat mood about the company. 
"What is pretty neat, you know, in a very difficult economic environment, is our revenues are very good," Mr. Breen said during the conference call. "We are not dropping off. We are not losing market share." He said that he expected the company to produce revenue of about $9.1 billion in the fourth quarter.
Mr. Breen also said that the company's internal investigation, which is being conducted by 50 accountants and 8 lawyers in 45 locations around the world by the law firm Boies, Schiller & Flexner and the forensic accounting firm Urbach Kahn & Werlin Advisors, was 40 percent complete. So far, he said, no serious irregularities have been discovered.
"We have not yet found anything that would require additional disclosure," Mr. Breen said. "I believe the steps we have taken in the last two months are putting us on the right road."
Tyco, which is nominally based in Bermuda for tax purposes but operates out of Exeter, N.H., and Boca Raton, Fla., owns dozens of companies that make products ranging from surgical instruments to security systems. It is also among the biggest suppliers of undersea fiber optic cables and electrical connectors. Tyco employs more than 270,000 people.
Mr. Breen -- who promised to move the company in a different direction after the many acquisitions engineered by its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski -- said that one crucial goal was to regain the trust of Tyco's customers. That would mean convincing them that the company remains healthy and solvent despite the indictments of Mr. Kozlowski and Mark Swartz, the former chief financial officer, on charges that they looted Tyco by paying multimillion-dollar bonuses to themselves without the board's authorization.
"The most important thing, in my opinion, when I came into the company, and I've stated this many times, was fixing corporate governance and fixing the real and perceived liquidity gap," he said. "We have customers that just read -- and I'm not meaning this negatively -- they read newspaper articles, they hear things, and they are not, they don't understand the details.
"I want our customers very calm, very relaxed," he said, so that the scandals involving Tyco's former executives are not "an issue in their buying and decision-making in purchasing from Tyco." 
Analysts said that they were relieved by Mr. Breen's straightforward approach.
"He was direct and reassuring," said Harriet Baldwin, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, who has a buy rating on the stock. "People expected him to lower the numbers."
Mr. Breen also addressed fears that the company might run out of cash, saying that he hoped to reach a new financing agreement in advance of February, when a big chunk of debt comes due. 
"I feel very comfortable with our liquidity situation, the gap that exists -- and I always plan around conservative scenarios because once I fix that gap, I want it fixed," he said.
He also told investors that he might scale back manufacturing in the TyCom unit and might also shed small, nonstrategic businesses, though he said no decisions had been made yet.
Tyco expects to take a charge of $2 billion to $2.5 billion on its TyCom fiber optic network, which it has spent $3.5 billion building over the last two years. Mr. Breen insisted that such a charge, which would mean that Tyco would end up writing off more than $4 billion in losses on the network, would not breach any bank covenants.

HEADLINE: California Culprits 

 BODY:
Federal investigators have now unearthed further evidence that market manipulation by energy companies played an important role in California's power crisis in 2000 and 2001. We have long known that clever trading strategies devised by companies like Enron helped jack up the price of power. Now comes a ruling from an administrative judge at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that the El Paso Corporation illegally inflated the price of natural gas. Because natural gas is used to produce much of California's power, inflating its price had the effect of driving up the cost of electricity. 
 The company has denied the charges. The ruling must be reviewed by the four members of the regulatory commission, and will almost certainly be appealed if the commission upholds the judge. Yet the company's case does not look promising. According to the judge, Curtis Wagner Jr., El Paso deliberately reduced the flow of natural gas through the main pipeline into Southern California, leaving more than 20 percent of the pipeline's capacity unused from Nov. 1, 2000, to March 31, 2001. In that same period, natural gas prices in Southern California soared to five times the price elsewhere in the country and, indeed, on the other side of the California border in Mexico. 
 The report represents the first time that any federal regulatory official has found widespread manipulation of energy supplies, as distinct from energy prices. The finding represents vindication for California's Gov. Gray Davis and Senator Dianne Feinstein, who have long suspected manipulation by gas companies. It also reflects well on the commission chairman, Patrick Wood III. A complaint from California about El Paso's behavior had languished in the files for nearly a year until Mr. Wood came aboard and cranked up the commission's investigative apparatus.
More broadly, the ruling demonstrates the folly of rushing to simple answers about something as complicated as the California energy crisis. It will be recalled that Vice President Dick Cheney put most of the blame on a natural gas shortage, which he then used as an argument for opening up vast areas of the West (including Alaska) to oil and gas exploration. It's now clear that the shortages were exacerbated by some of Mr. Cheney's old friends in the energy business who gamed the system.
By the same token, however, it would also be wrong to blame the whole mess on manipulation. For one thing, industry did not build nearly enough new capacity to keep pace with California's booming economy. For another, the state's flawed deregulation scheme practically invited unscrupulous behavior. Still, it's encouraging that Washington is finally getting the goods on the manipulators.

HEADLINE: City Poverty Rate Shows First Rise in 5 Years 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
After declining for five straight years, the poverty rate in New York City is beginning to grow, according to an analysis of new Census Bureau data by an advocacy group for the poor. 
 The slight increase in the poverty rate does not fully reflect the extent to which the events of Sept. 11 and the general economic downturn have swelled the city's unemployment rolls and homeless shelters in 2002, said the Community Service Society of New York, the poverty research and advocacy group that prepared the analysis. 
 The society predicted that poverty rates would continue to grow, but several economists said that given the trouble the city underwent in 2001, the increase of 0.4 percentage point was as good as could be hoped. 
The analysis is based on data from the Census Bureau's annual Current Population Survey, which uses a statistically small sample of door-to-door and telephone surveys and was released Tuesday. 
To create a more numerically significant sample, the society averaged two consecutive years of census data and found that New York's overall poverty rate for 2000 and 2001 was 20.2 percent, or 0.4 percent point higher than the average for 1999 and 2000. The percentage of New Yorkers beneath the federal poverty level had been declining steadily since 1995-1996, when it stood at 26.4 percent. 
The 0.4 percentage point increase in local poverty rates mirrored exactly the rise in poverty rates in the rest of the country, which rose to 11.7 percent from 11.3 percent. As with the national survey, non-Hispanic whites were the racial group for whom the poverty rate notably increased. In the city in 1999-2000, 9.1 percent of non-Hispanic whites were beneath the poverty threshold; in 2000-2001 11.6 percent were.
Mark Levitan, a senior policy analyst with the society, said the latest data showed that poverty rates in the city followed unemployment rates closely, a pattern which, he said, does not bode well for the city. Last year the city's unemployment rate averaged 6.1 percent. The city's unemployment rate now is 7.6 percent.
Other economists' views of the latest figures were less grim. "Any rise is unfortunate," said Rae Rosen, a senior economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, "but it sounds pretty good to me, given the loss of jobs we've had and the kinds of jobs we've lost."
Mr. Levitan also said the close correlation between poverty rates and unemployment rates showed that a recent decline in welfare rolls had more to do with a good job market than the welfare-to-work policies of the Giuliani administration.
"We don't see any evidence that welfare reform has changed that pattern," Mr. Levitan said. "The fact that poverty has stopped declining as the economy has weakened is evidence that the decline in poverty in the late 1990's was driven by the expanding economy, not welfare reform."
Supporters of the changes in the welfare system that sent roughly 600,000 people off the city's rolls in the last five years said, however, that the mild increase in poverty, especially because it affected largely non-Hispanic whites, was proof that the changes were working. "If we saw a sharp increase in poverty among minorities, that might be cause for concern," said Lawrence Mead, a professor at New York University who studies welfare patterns, "but you don't see that here."

HEADLINE: County Budgets Pinched by State Medicaid Changes 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
County governments across New York State are facing big budget shortfalls next year, largely because of new health-care costs that Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have thrust upon them.
 The combination of a sluggish economy and the increased health-care costs means that many county executives are proposing steep tax increases or service cuts. Broome County, for instance, is considering either a 35 percent property tax increase or a 25 percent increase in the sales tax. Erie County is planning to cut its work force by 7 percent. Westchester County is trying to plug a $120 million deficit next year. 
 The financial distress among local governments owes much to the recession and the need to increase pension-fund contributions because of the drop in stock prices. Local officials say the governor and legislative leaders have made the situation worse by expanding the Medicaid program to include more services and to increase the salaries of health-care workers.
Health-care costs account for anywhere from half to all of a county's property tax revenue, and this year, counties statewide will spend $4.3 billion on those costs.
Unlike most states, New York requires counties to pay a quarter of Medicaid costs. That means every time the Legislature adds a new program under Medicaid, local governments pick up much of the bill. 
"I call them Albany taxes," said the Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, who is president of the New York State Association of Counties. "Albany is making us collect their taxes."
This year, for instance, the Legislature increased reimbursement rates to raise salaries for health-care employees and required coverage for poor women with certain cancers. The Legislature also required coverage for hospice care and for disabled people who enter the work force but cannot afford insurance. 
On average, what counties pay for health care rose 12 percent in 2002, and that is expected to increase next year, too. In some counties, the Medicaid budget has become as big as the property tax collections, according to the association of counties. 
New York City is facing its own problems with Medicaid costs as it struggles to deal with a caseload that has jumped to more than 2 million this year, from 1.6 million. 
Rising local taxes have become an issue in the campaign for governor, especially in the New York City suburbs, where Mr. Pataki's opponents have tried to link him to the increases. 
Mr. Pataki frequently takes credit for many of the new health programs like Child Health Plus that are paid for through Medicaid. He also played a pivotal role in passing the bill in January that provided money to raise the pay of health workers, which is currently costing counties about $50 million annually.
The governor's budget aides say there are larger trends at work. The costs of prescription drugs and doctors' fees have risen rapidly across the nation, they point out. In addition, demographic shifts in upstate New York have meant more and more elderly and poor people are signing up for the program. 
Several county executives acknowledged that some of the rise in costs was beyond Albany's control. "It's both sides of the coin," said Mark W. Thomas, the Democratic county executive in Chautauqua County. "It's the economic conditions but it's also the add-ons."
County executives say the governor and lawmakers, in essence, have shifted the financial burden for several programs from the state to the federal health-insurance system, and thus to the counties as well. 
"It's happening because in Albany they are giving away the store," said Nicholas J. Pirro, the Onondaga County executive. "If you could take your friends out, run up a nice bill and only pay 25 cents on the dollar, you would do it a lot."
Mr. Pirro, a Republican, said Onondaga County, which includes Syracuse, had been forced to raise property taxes 6.5 percent and to cut about 200 jobs because of a $9 million rise in medical costs and about $4 million in new pension contributions. 
Aides to legislative leaders concede that changes have raised county costs but, they said, in the long run some programs will save the counties' money by providing insurance for the uninsured. Enrolling uninsured people with menial jobs in Medicaid, for instance, means counties do not have to pick up the entire hospital bill if those people fall seriously ill. 
Tom Santulli, the Chemung County executive, said Medicaid costs in his county rose 21 percent over the last year and were projected to be more than the entire property tax levy next year. The county has raised the sales tax to 8 percent from 7 percent to pay for the program. 
In Nassau County, Thomas Suozzi, the Democratic county executive, said the larger-than-expected pension contributions along with the new Medicaid programs have added at least $120 million to a budget shortfall. "There is a growing problem in New York State where the state passes laws to create programs but leaves the costs on the property tax-payers," he said. "They take credit for great programs but they don't pay for them."
One effect of the rising medical expenses has been that counties are paring back other services, like roads and economic development grants. In Chautauqua County, Medicaid costs are expected to go up 39 percent next year. Pension costs will rise eight-fold. 
Mr. Thomas said he has proposed a 28 percent property tax increase to cover those costs, but what is more troubling to him is that he has had to cut a quarter of Chautauqua County's economic development spending. More and more of his budget is going to medical programs, he said. "If this keeps up, what we will end up being is an insurance company."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Doubles 

BYLINE:  By Ken Belson (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Japan's trade surplus more than doubled in August as exports continued to grow. 
The surplus stood at 644 billion yen ($5.23 billion) in August, 108 percent more than in the month last year. Exports grew 6.2 percent, helped by strong demand for electronics goods in Asia and steel in Europe. The surplus with the United States shrank 7.3 percent. Ken Belson (NYT)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
How Knicks Drummed Up Business

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
For a decade, the Knicks' season-ticket waiting list symbolized their success and gave them the cachet of a hot Broadway show.
 But after the Knicks' failure to make the playoffs last season for the first time in 15 years and the recession that has hammered Wall Street, Madison Square Garden, for the first time, contacted everyone on the team's 8,000-person waiting list. 
 Dipping so deeply into the waiting list yielded 2,000 new season-ticket buyers, bringing the Knicks close to last year's season-ticket base of about 15,000, said Steve Mills, the president of sports team operations for the Garden.
"We offered everybody on the waiting list an opportunity to purchase season tickets," Mills said. "We've sold 2,000 new seats to people who weren't in the building last year. We feel very positive about that." 
It was the most extensive use of the waiting list since it was formed in 1992, he said. 
Usually, hundreds of people on the list are contacted, but the Garden had never contacted everyone.
The list grew in tandem with the Knicks' success, ballooning as high as 15,000 several years ago before the Garden pared it down to 8,000 by separating those who were serious buyers from those who were not.
A similar effort was made last year to spur Rangers season-ticket sales, Mills said. The Rangers have not made the playoffs since 1997. "Most people didn't know they could get season tickets," he said, referring to both the Rangers and the Knicks, who fell to 30-52 last season.
The Garden, which will put a limited number of Knicks individual and season tickets on sale tomorrow, said prices would remain unchanged for the first time in 10 years. Ticket prices are $10, $26.50, $40, $56, $67, $79, $100, $210 and $285, with a limited number of $750 and $1,600 seats at or near courtside. At an average cost of $89.80, Knicks tickets are the most expensive in the N.B.A., according to Team Marketing Report.
Mills declined to say specifically how many Knicks season-ticket holders did not renew this year. And he said he did not know how many had given the tickets up because of the Knicks' mediocre performance or out of financial necessity.
Mark Sullivan, group publisher of the VNU Sports Group in Manhattan, said both factors merged in his refusal to renew his two $56 tickets for the Knicks' 41 home games. He went to only five games last season and found the tickets difficult to give away.
"If you factor in tickets, food, a taxi and a baby sitter, that's $200 for a mediocre experience," he said. "For $200, you can go to a Broadway show, to Lincoln Center, or have a spectacular dinner."
Mills said there were various reasons most of those on the waiting list elected not to buy season tickets: they could not afford them; they wanted tickets in a more expensive price range that were not available; they preferred to buy partial plans of 10 to 14 games, which will be made available soon.
"We'll be going back to the people on the waiting list for the mini-plans," Mills said.
Dan Migala, executive editor of Team Marketing Report, said that throughout sports, the usual attrition of season-ticket holders has been jolted by the economic slowdown.
"It's a different time," Migala said. "Some people on waiting lists signed up in better times."
Jennifer Weil of Manhattan was one of those informed by mail of the availability of season tickets, at a price range of $26.50 to $79 each, after waiting only two years.
"No way I could afford a full season," said Weil, a former television producer and a recent graduate of Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. "So I asked if I could do 12 games, and they said I'm on the list, so keep calling."
Although she expects to buy a 12-game Knicks plan, her basketball passions have shifted since she joined the waiting list.
"I've been Knicks a fan for eight years, but they've gotten really bad," Weil said. So recently she bought a 12-game plan for the Nets at Continental Arena.
Lou Lamoriello, the chief executive of the Nets, was not available to discuss the effect of sharply higher ticket prices on season-ticket sales for his team after it won the Eastern Conference championship.
Weil is lucky to have waited only two years. The fans who most recently bought season tickets to Giants games in the Meadowlands had sat expectantly for 23 years on the team's 20,000-name waiting list.
Recently, two men who signed up on the Green Bay Packers' 57,500-name waiting list in 1974 received their long-coveted tickets.
Waiting lists can sustain once-powerful teams through hard times.
The Chicago Bulls' onetime waiting list of 20,000 names kept United Center season-ticket sales robust through Michael Jordan's first retirement, and for most of the time since his second retirement. Sellouts ended last season, as the cumulative effect of the Bulls' woes ate into sales of season and individual tickets, Tim Hallam, a team spokesman, said.
"It's normal practice to have turnover year to year on waiting lists," said Bernie Mullin, a senior vice president of the N.B.A. But, he added, "The vast majority of teams don't have waiting lists."

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH/STEPHANIE ODEGARD; 
Good Weaves Meet Good Deeds

BYLINE:  By NANCY HASS

 BODY:
THIS month, as many of Stephanie Odegard's Upper East Side neighbors were straggling home from a summer of traffic and crowds in the Hamptons, she was returning to her one-bedroom apartment on East 90th Street from Kashmir, a war zone of an entirely different magnitude.
 Ms. Odegard, 53, who is known for her designs for modernized Tibetan rugs, which cover the floors of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, Restaurant Daniel in New York and the homes of Christy Turlington in New York and Robert Redford in Aspen, Colo., did not go to Kashmir as a tourist. She was on the sort of one-woman mission that has characterized her career. 
 "I hadn't been in Kashmir for years, and I was really shocked by how bad things had gotten," she said last week, speaking of the flare-up of hostilities between India and Pakistan over that Muslim region, part of which is controlled by India as the state of Jammu and Kashmir. 
Sitting in her apartment, Ms. Odegard was surrounded by her own carpets mixed with modern furniture, including a Le Corbusier chaise lounge and a Thonet table. But the objects and textiles she has collected in Asia over the years are largely from the 17th and 18th centuries, including a Tibetan painted box (traditionally used to hold ritual butter sculptures) and ancient Japanese robes.
The bits and pieces of fabric and artwork form a virtual road map of the 25 years she has spent helping third world artisans make beautiful things. She does it because she believes that some day the making of handicrafts may resuscitate their disintegrating societies.
As she has done for decades, Ms. Odegard conducted this business trip amid rubble. She flew into Srinagar, the summer capital of the Indian state, where she had an appointment with the head of a small weaving collective. He had cashmere and valuable Kashmir saffron to use as a dye but didn't know how to do the dyeing. 
Ms. Odegard carried some of the cashmere and saffron back to one of her four rug factories in Nepal, so that samples of the yarn could be spun and dyed by her craftsmen. The collective is now making saffron-dyed shawls, which Ms. Odegard plans to sell in January from her carpet showroom in New York for $500 each and up, with at least half going back to the weavers. 
The trip was a small effort by her standards. Her company, Odegard Rare and Custom Carpets, and her life are built on the twin foundations of good deeds and good business. Thirty years ago, when most designers of her generation were at art schools or apprenticing in ateliers in the East Village, Ms. Odegard, a former department store buyer, was a Peace Corps volunteer in Fiji, assigned to helping crafts merchants make their wares attractive to Western buyers. (Growing up a Lutheran in Minneapolis, she had wanted to be a missionary.) She stayed in the nonprofit world for more than a decade, working for the World Bank and the United Nations as a consultant on improving indigenous crafts in places like Jamaica and India.
In 1987, after a posting in Nepal, Ms. Odegard, who has no formal design training, went into business in New York, arranging to make high-end Tibetan carpets in Nepal, with the work overseen by Tibetan refugees. (Most Tibetan carpets, prized for their lanolin-rich wool from sheep that graze in the Himalayas, have been made in Nepal since 1959, when the Chinese annexed Tibet.)
Ms. Odegard started her company as a way to prove an economic theory. After years in the third world, she was convinced that the best way to raise the standard of living was to produce high-end crafts. That project would take more skilled, higher paid workers. The World Bank had tried to achieve the same end, but through grants. "Stephanie really bucked that trend and she was incredibly dogged," said Nancy Barry, who was the World Bank program director when Ms. Odegard was there, and who is now the president of Women's World Banking, a New York-based organization that makes small loans to third world entrepreneurs.
Then Ms. Odegard set about reviving the market for Tibetan carpets, which typically had borne tribal motifs, making them too busy for elegant interiors. "I had been teaching people in Nepal to make good carpets, but I couldn't find anyone to buy them," she said. 
She decided to give her Tibetan carpets a new look by paring down the motifs and using antique Asian textiles as an inspiration, and she increased the knots for a square foot to a sleek 100 from the traditional 50 or 60. She also developed new dyes to add richer, more modern shades to the palette.
Starting in 1987, with an East 22nd Street apartment she used to lived in as her showroom, she has built her business into a company with $10 million a year in sales. After a rocky start -- her company nearly went bankrupt in 1993 -- she found her niche, selling these lush yet minimalist carpets to interior designers and architects who didn't balk at 8-by-10-foot carpets for $5,000 to $20,000. 
"She worked very hard to get the right people to see them," said Sherri Donghia, the design director of Donghia Furniture and Textiles, who has for years used Ms. Odegard's carpets in the displays she creates in her own showroom. (Ms. Donghia has begun designing a collection for the Odegard label.)
"She encouraged you to put your face into the carpets to see the dyes and how much life there is in them," Ms. Donghia said. "She made you see that there's real soul in the products."
Ms. Odegard's persistence paid off: her carpets got wide play in magazines after they were chosen for the Getty Museum in 1997 and for the Phillips Collection, the museum in Washington, in 2000. David Rockwell, the New York architect, began using Ms. Odegard's carpets in his projects as well, including the rooms and the mezzanine of the Chambers Hotel, which opened last year. "She's completely modern without being minimal," Mr. Rockwell said. "There's complexity and depth to everything she makes."
Ms. Odegard is now among the biggest importers of Tibetan carpets to the United States, where some three million square feet of Tibetan carpets were imported last year, according to the Central Carpet Industries Association, a trade group in Nepal. In 1985, Americans imported 70,000 square feet of carpet from Nepal. The market's growth, which began in the mid-90's, can be at least partly credited to Ms. Odegard. A glance inside any design magazine shows ads from more than a dozen boutique-size Tibetan carpet makers, few of which were in business a decade ago. 
And, said Ms. Barry of Women's World Banking, the boom has helped shore up Nepal's faltering economy, just as Ms. Odegard envisioned. 
Jack Lenor Larsen, the fabric designer, acknowledged Ms. Odegard's contribution: "Stephanie created the market for Tibetan carpets as an element in contemporary design. Now they're everywhere, enormously important. That's entirely because of her. She was the first to do it, and she was alone doing it for many years."
Ms. Odegard now works from a 15,000-square-foot showroom at 200 Lexington Avenue. The four Nepali-owned factories where her carpets are made employ more than 10,000 workers. Next month she will open Paradeisos International Design Studios, a 30,000-square-foot, three-building complex designed by Alison Spear in the Miami design district. There, she will focus on an expanded line of her designs, including jewelry and fabrics.
At home, Ms. Odegard seems a particularly unlikely type to have spent her life muscling her way into the American rug market. If she is pugnacious, she hides it behind a gentle facade, calm blue eyes and a wardrobe of handmade linen and draped wool. She is the largest American financial supporter of Rugmark, an anti-child-labor organization, to which she gives 1.7 percent of the selling price of her rugs ($60,000 last year) and a third of her time. She contributes at least $100,000 more to initiatives of her own, like building a school in Katmandu. 
But when she speaks about her social agenda, she has no canned human rights spiel. When she mentions the carpets underfoot, which she changes every few months -- "to get to know all of them, really deep down" -- she reflexively leads the conversation back to the skill of the weavers and how the factory owners she works with have become enlightened about child labor. 
"It's hard for me to talk about myself in any sort of reflective way because I've never had the time to even think about it," she said. "Some people have a totally formed idea of where they're going from the beginning, but I didn't. I really thought I would just go back and forth and help a few people. I had no idea it would turn into this."
Although she spends much of her life on the road, mainly in India and Nepal, her Upper East Side apartment serves as a place to retreat from what she calls the "soul-draining energy" of New York and as a casual warren for her collection. This year, after friends chided her about her small apartment, Ms. Odegard, who is single, purchased the apartment below hers to make an 800-square-foot duplex. But she has not found the time to start a real renovation.
In one corner there are some pieces of Murano glass, and above an artfully worn Chesterfield couch there is a painting by Chucho Reyes, a Mexican painter who worked with Luis Barragan in the 1920's, but most of Ms. Odegard's pieces are crafts from cultures she has seen up close.
"I see more than just the objects, I see the people who made them," she said. "It's like looking at a Gauguin painting and wondering what those women in Fiji or Tahiti were thinking. I know what they were thinking."
