HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Heady Days for Makers of Luxury Vehicles

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Sales of cars are shaky in most of the world's major markets, the United States and Germany are struggling to avoid slipping back into recession and war talk fills the air.
 Yet to judge by the parade of luxury cars making their debut at the Paris motor show this week, one would think the automobile industry was still living in the Roaring Twenties -- or at least the late 90's. 
 In seemingly blithe defiance of economic reality, the industry is stepping up production at the rarefied end of the market: sedans and sport utility vehicles with sticker prices north of $50,000.
The drive for luxury has propelled some companies into making uncharacteristic and extremely risky bets.
Volkswagen is introducing a majestic new sedan, the Phaeton, priced from $55,000 to nearly $100,000, depending on whether customers fancy a 6- or 12-cylinder engine. 
Porsche unveiled a sleek S.U.V., the Cayenne, which starts at $56,000 and soars above $100,000 with a turbocharged engine. It is the first nonsports car in the company's history.
"We know the money is there," said Wendelin Wiedeking, the chairman of Porsche, which is making perhaps the boldest bet. "The question is: Are people going to spend the money?" 
The premium car market, with its faster growth rate and higher profits, has been the industry's sweet spot for a decade. BMW, the most profitable major carmaker, expects sales of luxury cars to grow 4 percent next year, compared with 2 to 3 percent for the whole industry.
Yet the sheer number of new models -- at a time of such economic and political uncertainty -- is raising the specter that the industry will spoil its most reliable stream of profits.
"All these cars were developed during the boom years of the late 1990's, when everybody thought the growth would carry on forever," said Graeme Maxton, an analyst at Autopolis, a consulting firm in London. "They're launching them at a time when the market is turning down."
Executives interviewed here said the car market will either be flat or will rebound modestly next year. But those predictions do not take into account potential disruptions, like a second bout of recession in the United States or military action against Iraq, which could lead to a spike in oil prices.
For all the purveyors of luxury cars to succeed, the market will not only have to grow, but grow robustly.
Executives at DaimlerChrysler estimate that in the core luxury segment -- sedans ranging from $50,000 to $80,000 -- Mercedes-Benz and its rivals will produce 205,000 to 215,000 cars next year. In a good year, they say, sales of such cars range from 150,000 to 175,000.
"There's unprecedented competition in this market," said Johannes Reifenrath, a spokesman for Mercedes.
These numbers do not take into account the upscale S.U.V. market, which increasingly overlaps with traditional luxury cars. BMW and Mercedes each produce more than 100,000 S.U.V.'s a year. BMW assembles its X5 near Spartanburg, S.C., while Mercedes makes the M-Class in Tuscaloosa, Ala.
BMW said this week that it would invest $400 million and hire 400 more workers at the Spartanburg factory, increasing its capacity to 150,000 vehicles a year. BMW also produces the Z4 sports car there.
Starting in 2003, however, BMW will face competition from Porsche as well as Volkswagen, which also introduced an upscale sport utility, the Touareg, at the auto show. The Porsche and VW vehicles share some components, though the Touareg, with a starting price of $38,000, is cheaper.
While the popularity of S.U.V.'s is well documented, some analysts say the new entrants are coming to the party late.
"Everyone has gotten caught up in this fever, but I think it is going to subside," said Christopher Cedergren, the managing director of NexTrend, an automotive research firm in Westwood, Calif. 
The stakes are probably highest for Porsche, a 54-year-old company that built its reputation on a stable of uncompromising sports cars. Mr. Wiedeking, who has run Porsche since 1992, said the Cayenne was the most critical new model in the company's history.
He said there was an opening for Porsche to attract discerning drivers who would consider buying an S.U.V., but only if it had the high performance and safety standards of a luxury car.
With a 450-horsepower engine capable of going 266 kilometers an hour (165 miles an hour), the Cayenne is not likely to be confused with a Ford Explorer. At the same time, some analysts worry that it is too big a leap from Porsche's flagship 911 or its Boxster convertible.
"I'm concerned it will dilute their brand image," Mr. Cedergren said.
Mr. Wiedeking acknowledged that an S.U.V. is a stretch. But he said that the design and engineering were in the best traditions of Porsche, and that the brand was elastic enough to accommodate a new product.
"You can stretch a rubber band, provided you do it slowly," Mr. Wiedeking said.
The same questions of elasticity are being asked about Volkswagen, Germany's largest manufacturer, which hopes to persuade people that its name, "people's car," can be stamped on a $60,000 sedan.
The Phaeton, which went on sale in Europe this summer and will come to the United States next year, is intended to compete with the top sedans sold by Mercedes, BMW and Jaguar. Skeptics say it will also cannibalize VW's Audi division, which rolled out a new version of its A8 luxury sedan this week.
The Phaeton's ambitions are even grander than the Cayenne's. VW hopes the car will lift the status of its entire brand. It has set up a separate sales and marketing team, which hopes to establish the Phaeton's credentials by persuading deluxe hotels to use it as a limousine.
Robert Buchelhofer, director of sales and marketing for Volkswagen's luxury cars, said the company was losing loyal VW owners after they graduated beyond the Passat, a midsize medium-price sedan. "The Phaeton will help us keep many of those customers," he said.
VW hopes to sell 20,000 Phaetons a year, about half in the United States. Mr. Buchelhofer said VW would turn a profit on the car in its first generation, though he would not say how many years that would be.
"The luxury category is not like other markets," Mr. Buchelhofer said. "These are affluent buyers who are less sensitive to changes in their purchasing power than they are to exciting new products."
This, in a nutshell, is the industry's rationale for producing ever-more-expensive cars. Manufacturers seem convinced that the global economy has created an expanding pool of wealthy consumers, whose desire to drive a Mercedes or BMW will not be dented by the ups and downs of their stock portfolios.
"People definitely lost a lot of money on the stock market," said Michael Ganal, head of marketing at BMW. "But we've learned that the key to their economic power is real estate, not stocks." 
BMW has bucked the industry's weak results, selling 19 percent more cars in the first eight months of this year than in the period last year. Sales of Mercedes-Benz were basically flat in the same period.
"There really isn't a wrong time, from an economic perspective, to bring out a luxury vehicle," Mr. Cedergren of NexTrend said. "The Dow is crashing, and Porsche is going to sell more 911's in the United States this year than ever before. Who would have thought it?"
Detroit's Big Three, known for mass-market appeal, have also been busy bolstering their luxury lineups and have been aggressive in expanding into new frontiers, like pickup trucks. General Motors has gone to considerable effort to revamp Cadillac, trying to transform it from a dowdy-but-proud brand for senior citizens into a full-line maker of luxury sedans, sports cars, S.U.V.'s and pickups. The newer Cadillacs, including the Escalade S.U.V. and pickup, feature bold designs that have resonated with rappers and pro athletes and have been featured in the first TV ads to use a Led Zeppelin song as a soundtrack.
The Ford Motor Company, in its turnaround plan announced in January, said its upscale brands -- Volvo, Aston Martin, Jaguar and Land Rover -- would be a cornerstone of future profits, though some analysts have said Ford is overreaching. Ford has also continued to expand its luxury S.U.V. lineup; the new Lincoln Aviator, a slightly smaller version of the Navigator, starts at $40,000.
But while the Big Three have made some strides this year -- Cadillac's sales have increased 18.6 percent through August -- luxury sales have remained strong in the United States largely because of European and Japanese brands. Toyota Motor, whose Lexus brand is the most popular luxury line in the country, is up 7.9 percent this year, through August, while Nissan Motor's revived Infiniti brand, buoyed by the new G35 sedan, is up 20.5 percent, according to the Autodata Corporation. Sales of BMW are up 6.8 percent.
Although the new luxury cars have dizzying sticker prices, analysts point out that the price of automobiles, even expensive ones, has not kept pace with inflation since 1998 because of overproduction.
"What you see is that more and more people can afford luxury cars," said Greg Melich, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley in London. "Barring a macroshock, that affordability is going to keep going up."
As visitors gawked at the gleaming machines on display here, setting down their canapes and Champagne flutes to sit behind the wheel of the new Bentley or Jaguar, the outside world seemed very far away.

HEADLINE: U.S. Revises Growth Rate Of Economy Up to1.3% 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The economy grew at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the second quarter, a performance that was slightly stronger than previously thought but still a sharp slowdown from the beginning of the year. 
 The revised figure for gross domestic product, considered the best barometer of the country's economic health, showed that the economy grew a little faster in the April-June quarter than the 1.1 percent rate estimated a month ago, the Commerce Department said today. 
 Gross domestic product measures the total value of goods and services produced in the United States. 
The biggest factor in the upward revision was an improvement in the trade picture, which resulted in the bloated deficit being slightly less of a drag on the economy than previously estimated. 
The trade deficit shaved 1.4 percentage points off second-quarter G.D.P., compared with the reduction of 1.65 percentage points previously reported. Stronger demand for American exports accounted for the improvement. 
Even with the small improvement to second-quarter G.D.P., the economic recovery was struggling with below-par growth, reflecting less vigorous spending by consumers and deep cuts in capital spending on new plants and other buildings by businesses. 
Consumer spending in the second quarter grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent, a bit weaker than the government previously estimated and considerably less brisk than the 3.1 percent rate seen in the first three months of this year. 
Another report, the consumer confidence survey from the University of Michigan, showed growing pessimism among consumers. The report, which is released only to subscribers, fell to 86.1 from 87.6 in August, according to people who saw the report.
Consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity in the United States, grew more cautious in the second quarter as a wave of corporate accounting scandals, a stock market slide and a stagnant job market made people more anxious about the economy's direction. 
Businesses, facing stock market distress and economic uncertainties, cut spending on new factories, office buildings and other structures at a rate of 17.6 percent in the second quarter -- it declined at a 14.2 percent rate in the first quarter. 
The economy's 1.3 percent growth rate in the second quarter was the weakest showing since the third quarter of 2001, when the G.D.P. shrank at a rate of 0.3 percent. 
The Commerce Department report showed that after-tax profit of United States corporations rose at a rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, the same as previously estimated, but down from 2 percent in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: Ruling Against Lumber Tariff Is Affirmed 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization affirmed an earlier decision that the United States broke trade rules in the way it calculated a tariff on Canadian lumber.
 The decision follows the Canadian government's challenge of a temporary 19.3 percent tariff the United States imposed last August on $6 billion worth of Canadian pine, spruce and fir boards. 
The United States contended that shipments by sawmills like the Canfor Corporation and Abitibi-Consolidated were subsidized by the Canadian government. 
 Canadian officials said the ruling showed the trade arbiter was leaning against United States protections. The United States said the vote showed that Canada's natural resource subsidies fall under W.T.O. jurisdiction.
The W.T.O. said the duties were improperly based on comparisons between what Canadian provinces charge companies to cut timber on government-owned land and the cost of timber in neighboring states in the United States. The United States would have to show a gap between the cost of timber on government and private land in Canada to prove a subsidy, the W.T.O. said.

HEADLINE: Downtown, A Debate Over Burying West Street 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Almost from the beginning of the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, one point of near-universal agreement has been that Battery Park City is isolated from the rest of downtown. To rejoin it to the rest of the city, planners have proposed that West Street be buried and covered with a tree-lined promenade.
 But now, as with any major development project in New York City, local opposition has begun to build. Though few so far, a growing number of Battery Park City residents have begun to lobby against a West Street tunnel, saying they fear that a decade-long construction project will further isolate their neighborhood, rather than reconnect it to the rest of Lower Manhattan. 
 The nascent Coalition to Save West Street has raised a discomfiting specter for rebuilding officials: a fight over what could be a centerpiece of the redevelopment of long-blighted areas south of the World Trade Center site. 
"I can't see any way that this would not make it harder to live in Battery Park City," said Joanne Taylor, a resident and one of the organizers of the coalition. "In 1993, after the first bombing of the World Trade Center, West Street was closed and it took forever to get anywhere from down here. This past year, West Street was closed from September to April, and it was a nightmare for us. Now they want us to endure 10 years of construction where we will not be able to drive by car or taxi out of Battery Park City to the rest of the city."
Many rebuilding officials, including some at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and at some of the architecture and urban planning firms hired to work on the proposal, say they have not heard much opposition to the West Street tunnel. They point out that more than 70 percent of the participants at two town hall meetings at the Javits Convention Center this summer agreed that it was "very important" to eliminate West Street as a barrier between Battery Park City and the rest of Manhattan.
Those officials who have heard opposition have urged the disgruntled to wait until they see detailed plans, to be presented later this year, before deciding what elements of the tunnel proposals they dislike.
"There has been a heavy majority of people in Lower Manhattan and Battery Park City who believe that West Street is a barrier and it does cut them off," said Andrew Winters, director of design and development at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency that is overseeing the rebuilding effort. 
The opponents, however, believe that to wait for plans is to lose the fight, one that they believe exists mainly because the people overseeing planning for Lower Manhattan do not live there and do not understand the true nature of the area. They say they fear that a buried West Street and surface promenade would not allow adequate access for emergency vehicles to get into southern Battery Park City.
They also express concern that it would restrict residents' ability to easily enter the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, and to reach the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive via the Battery Park underpass.
Planners who have worked on West Street proposals say the promenade figures in a broader redesign of downtown, one that will increase housing in the area south of Liberty Street between Broadway and West Street. Building a grand promenade would encourage the conversion of lackluster office space in that area to apartments, and could bring the focus of both sides of West Street back toward each other. Currently, they say, most of the buildings in Battery Park City turn their backs on West Street.
Four options are being considered in the redesign of West Street. One option includes no tunnel; rather, it would have more pedestrian bridges over the street than the two that currently exist.
Bill Love, a Battery Park City resident who has spoken out against the tunnel plans at several public meetings, said he believed that "pedestrian bridges are all that's necessary." 
Two pedestrian bridges were in place before Sept. 11; one, linking the World Financial Center to the trade center and its subways, was destroyed in the collapse of the twin towers. But a new overpass has been built at Rector Street, and some plans under consideration envision five or more elevated crossings.
Other Battery Park City residents argue that West Street itself is not so formidable a barrier. "The thousands of tourists who throng to our neighborhood every weekend don't have any problem crossing over it," said John Dellaportas, who put together the coalition's Web site, www.saveweststreet.com.
Two of the other West Street proposals would cover the street only in the area immediately adjacent to the trade center site, in the four blocks from Vesey Street to Liberty Street. One of these plans would build a platform over the roadway, and the other would dig a tunnel to move traffic underground. 
Those plans are not wholly objectionable to some of the 10 coalition members who gathered on a recent evening on the World Financial Center plaza to plot strategy. Still, they say, they fear that even such a short tunnel would worsen traffic from visitors to the trade center site, particularly those who come in buses.
It is the fourth option -- a tunnel from Vesey Street to Battery Park -- that has drawn the most resistance. In part, the objections are short-term, focused on how long it would take to dig and build the tunnel. 
People on both sides make a guess at 10 years and $2 billion for such a project, a disheartening estimate given that the State Transportation Department just finished a multiyear renovation of the street, extending northward to 59th Street. The only way to pay for such a project, some residents say, is to allow for commercial construction above the tunnel.
Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of Community Board 1, which includes the area, and a member of the development corporation's board, said she could understand the complaints of those who fear such a construction project. "A project that takes 10 years is not going to be looked upon with great admiration," she said. "I feel less empathy for those who just feel they don't want to be connected to the rest of the neighborhoods."

HEADLINE: U.S. and W.T.O. Negotiate Drug Access 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The United States and the World Trade Organization will try to come up with an agreement by year-end on how to give poor countries greater access to drugs to fight AIDS and other diseases, trade officials said today.
 An agreement among W.T.O. members in Doha, Qatar, last year acknowledged that many nations most desperately in need of such medicines lack the means of manufacturing them. 
 Robert Zoellick, the United States trade representative, met today with Supachai Panitchpakdi, the director general of the W.T.O., in his first official trip to Washington since taking the office. Mr. Supachai of Thailand is the first official from a developing nation to lead the international trade organization.
The existing agreement on intellectual property, called Trips, granted the world's poorest nations the right to make low-cost generic versions of patented medicines, while barring those nations from importing drugs from countries like Brazil, South Africa and India.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Earnings News Sends the Dow Sharply Lower

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
After a two-day respite, stocks plunged yesterday as investors were served more earnings disappointments and more weak economic data. The only good news, if it could be called that, was that the three major stock gauges did not fall to new lows.
 The Dow Jones industrial average, off 3.7 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, down 3.2 percent, were pulled lower by negative earnings news from Philip Morris and by a sharp decline in General Electric after two brokerage firms cut their ratings on the company. The Nasdaq index, off 1.8 percent, was weighed down by declines in Microsoft, Intel and Dell Computer. 
 All three gauges were down for the fifth consecutive week and it appears that when the month ends on Monday, the Dow and the Nasdaq will be down for the sixth consecutive month, while the S.&P. 500 index will be off for five of the last six months. 
As for the end of the quarter, the S.& P. 500 index and the Nasdaq are heading for their third consecutive quarterly decline while the Dow is poised for its second.
At the close, the Dow was down 295.67 points, to 7,701.45, just 18.32 points above the four-year low it hit Tuesday. The Dow is down 3.6 percent for the week, and if it closes at the same level on Monday, it would be off 11.1 percent for the month and 16.7 percent for the quarter. That would be the worst September since 1937 and the worst quarter since the 1987 market crash. The S.& P. 500 index was down 27.58, to 827.37. That is a decline of 2.1 percent for the week, 9.7 percent for the month so far and 16.4 percent for the quarter, also its worst quarterly performance since 1987.
The Nasdaq was down 22.45 points, to 1,199.16, just 16.99 points from the six-year low it reached Tuesday. For the week the Nasdaq was down 1.8 percent and would be off 8.8 percent for the month and 18 percent for the quarter. The Nasdaq fell 20.7 percent in the second quarter of this year and 30.7 percent in the third quarter a year ago.
"We have gone from a sense of all-out optimism in March, with the S.& P. at 1,170 and first-quarter growth at 5 percent, to outright fear in July," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "And now you get the sense that we have gone from fear to despair."
Yesterday's declines came with the announcement of more earnings disappointments, as the so-called confession season for corporate America moved into full swing. Because more companies usually say that they are going to miss earnings forecasts than beat them, the pessimistic drumbeat can be hard to ignore.
Ignoring the earnings news becomes even more difficult when new data is showing that the economy may be weaker than expected. That threat was especially highlighted this week with the surprise dissent of two Federal Reserve policy makers, who voted for an interest rate cut at the central bank's meeting on Tuesday. While the majority voted to hold rates steady, the dissents sent the signal that some policy makers think the economy is showing disturbing signs of weakness.
In addition, one of the "positive" economic reports for the week, which helped the stock market rally Thursday, was the fact that orders for durable goods declined only 0.6 percent in August, much less than the 3 percent Wall Street forecast.
Yesterday, the University of Michigan reported that its index of consumer confidence fell to 86.1 in September, from 87.6 in August and the fourth consecutive monthly decline.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said in a report yesterday that "repeated shocks to the U.S. economy are delaying the onset of a full-fledged recovery." For that reason he cut his growth forecast for the fourth quarter and first quarter of 2003 to 2.5 percent, from 3.5 percent for the fourth quarter and 4.1 percent for the first quarter. He also trimmed his earnings forecast by 2 percent.
Also weighing on investors is the continued debate over a possible war in Iraq, which drove the price of crude oil over $30 a barrel this week. "I had been thinking that the war is not really having that much impact," Mr. Paulsen of Wells Capital said. "But maybe that thing hanging out there is enough to keep the bearishness alive."
A further rise in the price of oil, economists agree, would put additional drag on the economic recovery, which is already producing very little job growth. Without job growth, it will be harder for consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of economic growth, to keep the economy expanding.
Philip Morris, the tobacco and foods company, said late Thursday that its profits for the year would rise 3 percent to 5 percent, down from a July forecast of 9 percent. 
Wyeth, the drug manufacturer, also said its 2002 profits would fall short of expectations. Philip Morris was down $4.87, or 11.4 percent, to $37.86, while Wyeth was off $7.35, or 19.1 percent, to $31.10.
General Electric stock was down $1.92, or 7.3 percent, to $24.47. On Wednesday, the company said that it would meet its profit forecasts for the third quarter. But in comments made in a Webcast on Thursday, a G.E. executive said that the current economic environment was tougher than the company had expected. The downgrades on stock ratings came yesterday.
Delta Air Lines said that it would have a net loss of about $350 million in the third quarter because travel demand had not rebounded as much as the company expected. Delta, the nation's third-largest airline, also announced that it would eliminate 1,500 flight attendant jobs, or about 9 percent of those jobs. The stock was down $2.81, or 24.4 percent, to $8.69.
In the bond market, interest rates slipped lower, as they usually have done when stocks are falling. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell to 3.66 percent in late afternoon trading, from 3.77 percent Thursday. It is just above the 3.65 percent it hit Tuesday, the lowest yield on a government security with a 10-year maturity in more than 40 years, according to the Federal Reserve. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 31/32 , to 105 28/32 . The yield on the Treasury's two-year note fell to a new low of 1.80 percent, from 1.92 percent Thursday.
The decline in longer-term rates has finally pushed 30-year mortgage rates, already at 40-year lows, below 6 percent. The Freddie Mac national average rate on a 30-year mortgage was 5.99 percent for the week ended yesterday, down from 6.05 percent the week before. That should keep the rush to refinance mortgages and to buy new homes going. But analysts have said that this activity, though welcome, will not be enough to produce a robust recovery.

HEADLINE: Seen as Safety Net, 9/11 Program Is Anything But 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
The financial assistance program in New York State that officials described as a kind of ultimate safety net for those who lost their jobs or had their property damaged because of the World Trade Center disaster has given grants to only a small fraction of the people who applied. Indeed, program officials admit they have not even reviewed more than half of the nearly 73,000 requests for aid that they received in recent months.
 Officials involved in the effort, known as the Individual and Family Grant program, said they had approved only 10,100 grants, and had yet to examine about 37,000 applications for emergency help. The average grant they had made was roughly $1,040 -- far short of the nearly $15,000 apiece that state officials had said would be available to applicants. 
 Both those figures -- the number of approvals and the money distributed -- fall below the rate and size of awards made by other states that have run similar joint programs to address emergencies in recent years, according to federal government statistics.
And in a measure of the program's troubles, seven members of New York's Congressional delegation this week beseeched officials with the Federal Emergency Management Agency -- administrators that they have criticized for months, calling them slow and incompetent in their relief efforts -- to take over the grant program's effort because the state is "ill-equipped" and "ill-prepared" to continue. FEMA finances 75 percent of the grants that the state approves.
State officials yesterday defended their performance, saying many of the backlogged requests had come in over the summer. Robert M. Lillpopp, a spokesman for the State Department of Labor, which administers the program, said that it was vital that the department verify the legitimacy of claims. He said the department had reviewed the applications more speedily at first and before the deluge of summer requests. Mr. Lillpopp suggested the criticism from Democratic lawmakers in Washington concerning the program was politically motivated.
A spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, who had announced the creation of the program in the weeks after the attack, did not return several calls for comment.
Some people who applied to the state program, however, said they experienced a mix of near-comic confusion and even hostility.
David Katzoff, who lost his personal computer in the collapse of the trade center, said he was erroneously offered a free steam cleaning of his apartment -- on the Upper East Side. When he pointed out the mistake to officials, he said, his application was rejected two weeks later.
Ilona Kloupte, a business analyst who designs software for fixed-income trading operations, received little of what she requested, even though she submitted photographs and receipts of all the personal property that had been destroyed in her Battery Park City apartment.
She said she cut short her search for help after she was asked for a letter from a doctor stating that she wore glasses, as well as a letter from her employer stating that she needed a computer for business.
"I said, 'This is not Bangladesh; this is the United States of America,' " said Ms. Kloupte, recalling a conversation with a Labor Department caseworker. "You are asking people who are financial professionals, who live in New York, who work on Wall Street, to provide written documents that you use your computers for work? What century are they living in?"
The response to victims of the Sept. 11 attacks, including government programs and private charitable efforts, has for a year produced a blend of great generosity, extraordinary effort and repeated problems with inefficiency and duplication.
In a certain sense, the state's program was offered as a kind of antidote to the confusion and frustration wrought by other efforts. Mr. Pataki, in announcing the program, said it was set up for those who felt abandoned, overwhelmed or excluded from the other relief efforts.
Initially, FEMA asked state officials to allow its administrators to run the program, said Brad Gair, FEMA's federal recovery officer in New York. But New York officials declined, confident of their experience handling upstate disasters.
In a Sept. 19, 2001, news release, Linda Angello, the state labor commissioner, said, "The State Labor Department is prepared to take whatever steps necessary to help New Yorkers recover as quickly as possible and return stability to their lives."
In the trade center disaster, the grant program was expected to cover home repairs and the replacement of personal property, along with reimbursement for air purifiers, vacuums and air-conditioners that needed replacing. It would also make grants to help people who had lost their jobs with transportation costs as they sought new employment.
But from the outset, the program had problems, according to applicants and lawmakers. Many applicants have questioned the state's insistence that they be rejected for a loan by the Small Business Administration in order to qualify. Others have complained that the documentation requirements are too onerous, since federal regulations say that "families do not have to provide real or property estimates or receipts."
"Our members have reported very spotty results, and a lot of confusion and miscommunication on the part of the administrators," said Kevin Curnin, a lawyer and co-founder of the From the Ground Up foundation, a coalition of nearly 300 small businesses in Lower Manhattan.
By April, seven months after the attack, the program had received 17,000 requests for assistance, but had granted only 3,500. Then came the summer, when a surge of applicants from Chinatown and other parts of Lower Manhattan sought reimbursement for air purifiers or the replacement of air-conditioners that coughed up dust. Many people were also given inaccurate information, via misleading advertising, that they would receive a new air-conditioner at no cost, Mr. Lillpopp, the Labor Department spokesman, said.
"They found themselves way behind in their ability to process," Mr. Gair, the FEMA official, said of the state's efforts.
As of yesterday, the New York program had offered $10.5 million to applicants, for an average of $1,039 per claim. By contrast, in the 27 different disasters in 23 states in the 2001 fiscal year, similar state-federal efforts averaged $16 million per disaster, and $2,586 per claim, according to federal statistics, with a 55 percent approval rating.
"Of all the problems we've seen in the delivery of aid, the failures of I.F.G. program are really the worst," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat.
Recently, FEMA has pitched in to assist by taking over the state grant program's help line, contributing 150 employees and scanning 15,000 receipts and other documents to relieve the backlog of mail that had piled up in Albany. As a result, the grant program program processed 4,000 cases last week.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Pataki requested that the program's deadline of Sept. 30 be extended to Jan. 31. But on Thursday, state and federal officials announced that they had sliced two months off that request, to Nov. 30, because one year had been enough time to get reimbursed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Energy Task Force Dispute Reaches a Federal Court
The dispute between the Bush administration and Congress over the disclosure of records related to the development of the administration's energy policy has reached federal court.
 Judge John D. Bates of Federal District Court in Washington is hearing the case, a fight over which branch of government's claim is paramount: the executive power to keep records confidential or the legislative right to investigate how money is spent. Page A1. 

Bail Is Accepted for Tyco's Ex-Chief
L. Dennis Kozlowski, left, the former chief executive of Tyco who has been charged with looting the company of $600 million, was allowed to remain free after a judge accepted $10 million in bail that was put up by his ex-wife, rejecting arguments that the money had been obtained through criminal activity. Mark Swartz, Tyco's former chief financial officer, was given until Oct. 11 to make bail. C2.

Ratings Lowered on Building Loans
A credit rating agency downgraded $4.5 billion in loans on commercial buildings, mostly in New York, because they were not sufficiently insured against terrorism. But the move was expected and should have little effect on the owners of the buildings or investors. C14.

Report Shows Economic Slowdown
The economy grew at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the second quarter, a performance that was slightly stronger than previously thought but which still marked a dramatic slowdown from the beginning of the year. C2.

Trans Air Receives Loan Guarantee
American Trans Air said that the federal government had agreed to guarantee most of a $165 million loan it had asked for. The guarantee is part of a Congressional effort to help stabilize the airline industry after Sept. 11. C14.

Congress Hears Ex-Qwest Official
Philip Anschutz, the former chairman of Qwest Communications, talked by telephone with Congressional investigators who are looking into the financial troubles of the company, a spokesman said. The House Energy and Commerce Committee wanted to ask Mr. Anschutz about his sale of Qwest shares. C2.

Ford to Shield Police Car Gas Tanks
Ford Motor agreed to install shields around the gas tanks on 350,000 Crown Victoria police cars after at least a dozen officers were killed in fiery crashes. Ford's agreement to pay for the modifications and to study ways to make the cars safer came after police departments charged that the vehicles are prone to burst into flames in rear-end crashes. C2.

U.S. and Russia to Discuss Energy
Energy executives and government officials from Russia and America will meet next week to discuss energy cooperation at a time when concerns over the safety of world oil supplies have been heightened by the Bush administration's push for action against Iraq. C2.

Delta Doubles Its Projected Loss
Delta Air Lines said it expected to lose about $350 million in the third quarter, nearly twice as much as previously expected, because of sluggish revenue and demand. The announcement, which came a day after Delta told employees it was cutting another 1,500 flight attendant jobs and a trade group warned the industry could lose a record $8 billion this year, sent airline stocks tumbling. Delta shares sank 20.4 percent, or $2.34 a share, to $9.16. C2.

China Approves Equity Stake in Bank
China plans to allow Newbridge Capital, an American private equity firm that specializes in emerging markets, to buy a stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank, a step toward gradually opening China's financial sector to foreigners. C3.

HEADLINE: Dockworkers Locked Out Of West Coast Terminals 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
West Coast port operators shut down cargo terminals from Seattle to Los Angeles tonight, in effect locking out unionized longshoremen. The terminals will remain closed until Sunday morning, company officials said.
 The lockout is the latest volley in a dispute between the companies and the longshoremen's union that could lead to a strike that could undercut an already stumbling national economy. 
 When members of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union showed up for the evening shift tonight, terminal gates were locked and staffed with armed security guards. The organization representing shippers said the 38-hour lockout was intended as a cold shower for the longshoremen. The shippers say work has slowed to a snail's pace since the contract with the longshoremen expired at the beginning of this month.
"This is how the union conducts its negotiations," said Jason Greenwald, a spokesman for Pacific Maritime Association, the operators' umbrella organization. "When the contract comes due, worker productivity plummets. The intent of our action here is to cool things off."
Calling the work slowdown a "strike with pay," Mr. Greenwald said productivity had fallen 25 percent to 90 percent, causing ships to miss their scheduled departure times, disrupting rail schedules and leaving valuable cargo sitting on docks.
The union issued a directive on Thursday for dockworkers to keep "in strict accordance" with safety regulations, but insisted it was a precautionary measure.
"You have more merchandise going through the terminals and the same amount of men handling it," said Steve Stallone, a union spokesman. "I wouldn't call that a slowdown. The companies have instituted the biggest speedup that ever happened, and it's dangerous."
Union officials in the Los Angeles-area harbors said there had been five deaths on the docks in the last five years, a barometer of the rapid pace and unsafe working conditions there.
Mr. Stallone said the lockout was a punitive step since the 10,500 rank-and-file members oppose the companies' demands for new technology on the piers without unionized job guarantees.
Shippers say the current system cannot accommodate the booming volume of cargo that moves through the ports, topping $320 billion last year and making Los Angeles the biggest port in the country. West Coast ports handle more than 40 percent of the nation's seaborne cargo.
"Who's being hurt by the lockout?" Mr. Stallone asked. "The workers will miss two shifts. It's like a little vacation. It's the companies' customers who are taking the hit. The small business people and the American economy as a whole."
Economists warn that if West Coast ports are shut down for more than a week, it would have a devastating effect on the already soft economy and it could throw Asian economies into a tailspin.
The Bush administration has said it is unwilling at this point to step into the negotiations. "We're monitoring this very closely," said Sue Hensley, a spokeswoman for the Department of Labor, repeating what she said on Monday, when shippers also had threatened a lockout.
It is peak season at the terminals because Christmas goods have begun to arrive. Saturdays are considered busy days, meaning that on Saturday at least a billion dollars of merchandise will be sitting on freighters anchored at sea. That could leave companies like automobile manufacturers that rely on so called just-in-time inventories with a crimp in their supply lines.
It remains to be seen how the conflict will be resolved, said Mr. Greenwald of the Pacific Maritime Association, but he promised that the docks would reopen on Sunday morning.

HEADLINE: Despite Big Issues, Primaries Prompted Only 17% to Vote 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Roiling life-and-death issues like war and terrorism and economic concerns were not enough to entice many people to the polls for midterm primaries this year, a new study shows.
 The Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a nonpartisan group in Washington, found in the study unveiled on Thursday that the percentage of the voting-age population that went to the polls rose slightly this year, reversing a four-decade trend of declining voter participation. Even so, only 17 percent of the voting-age population cast ballots this year in primaries for major statewide offices in 37 states that had primaries for both parties. 
 Four years ago, the figure was 16.8 percent. Although the increase was slight, it was the first since 1966 for elections when the presidency was not at stake. 
The committee said that the increase in participation reflected an unusually high number of tight primary contests and that it came at a time when concerns over war with Iraq and economic problems have raised interest in politics. Still, the researchers noted, almost half the places with statewide primaries this year recorded their lowest turnout rates in history.
"I'm not encouraged," said Curtis Gans, the director of the committee, "because a two-tenths of a percentage point rise is not really significant." The results are "abysmal," he added, "and speak more to the level of disengagement rather than anything about re-engagement."
But Mr. Gans said it could portend a higher turnout in the November general election -- which will see many competitive governors races this year -- than in the 1998 contest, when 35.3 percent of the voting-age population went to the polls. 
He also noted that in two of the general elections in the last 40 years when turnout increased, 1982 and 1992, voters had serious concerns about the economy. Such anxieties generally are bad for the party in the White House, Mr. Gans said. But this year, that may be tempered by the debate over war with Iraq, which he described as so far being a "unifying issue favoring the Republicans."
"War talk tends to push the economy to a lesser or co-equal concern," he said.
Voter turnout has been falling steadily since the mid-1960's, raising concerns among some researchers like Mr. Gans that the trend could increasingly subject the political parties to the influence of extremist, but energized, movements. 
In 1966, according to Mr. Gans's figures, 33.6 percent of the voting-age population went to the polls in the midterm primaries, and almost half voted in November.
Though not encouraging, Mr. Gans's findings may be more optimistic than some other recent studies. 
A poll last month by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press found interest in local races flat, with no difference from four years ago, said Andrew Kohut, the director of the center, who added, "Interest in campaign news was about equal, and the intention to vote was about the same."
"I wouldn't make book on a civic renewal," Mr. Kohut said.
On average, according to Mr. Gans's findings, 9.1 percent of the voting-age population took part in 42 Democratic primaries this year, compared with 7.7 percent in the 38 Republican contests. (The figures do not equal 17 percent because that figure is drawn only from the 37 states that had statewide primaries for both parties this year.)
In the South, three states saw record turnout for Republican midterm primaries: North Carolina, at 6.8 percent of the voting-age population; Georgia, at 8.1 percent; and South Carolina, at 10.1 percent. Mr. Gans said those records were largely the results of the continued flow of voters from the Democratic Party to the Republican Party, a trend since 1965.

Graph tracks average turnout of the voting-age population in states where both major parties held statewide primaries (37 states this year) from 1962 to 2002. (Source: Committee for the Study of the American Electorate)

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL; 
A Button for All Occasions, Including Brown vs. Harvard

BYLINE:  By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 26 

 BODY:
For the biggest football game of the year against its staunchest and most bitter foe -- and for the game that could conceivably decide the league championship, even though it is only the second game of the season, for all this you could, in most quarters on the Brown University campus today, cut the tension with, well. . . .
 "Game? There's a game on Saturday? I did hear something. Harvard, right?" said Maceo June, a junior from Manhattan. 
 "I suppose there would be a game," said Kyle Bieneman, a junior from San Francisco. "It's about that time of year, isn't it?" 
And Jessica Gordon, a freshman from Miami, said she would not know which team Brown was playing until the day before the game. That is when the marching band distributes buttons of a disparaging nature that when worn by Brown fans are hoped to unsettle the opposing team. Last week, when Brown visited Towson, in Maryland, the message on the button was: "Got Crabs?"
Gordon's interest centered on the buttons. "I wonder what they're going to come up with for Harvard," she said. (It was recalled that the button for last season's Yale game said: "Is Our Children Learning?" It was based on a quotation from a Yale alumnus, George W. Bush.)
This is the Ivy League, after all, where even the athletes are known to attend class. Go around campus and there is not a single sign posted or flapping from a dormitory window that says big game -- or any game -- on Saturday. 
Penn State, Michigan or Nebraska this is not. Go around Thayer Street, the off-campus center of student activity, and there is no sign of a coming game, not in the window of the College Hill Bookstore, not in the Andreas Restaurant, not in the Garment District, a discount clothing store.
The game will not be televised. And the stone, 77-year-old Brown Stadium, with its cozy bleacher seats along each sideline (there are no end zone accommodations) that seat 20,000, will be, the best estimates have it, about half full for the game, a few thousand more than usually show up when the Bears are home. 
Ah, but go to the Olney-Margolies Athletic Center, where the football offices are, where the team dresses, watches game films and occupies the training room, and it is a horse of a different color.
"It's crazy, the tension is building, the coaches are hollering, 'Beat Crimson,' I can't wait for the game on Saturday," said Tim Cotter, a freshman defensive back from Scranton, Pa. "If we win, it'll be payback time from last year. I had heard about the big rivalry with Harvard before coming to school here, but I didn't know it could reach such a fever pitch."
And the Division I-AA standout receiver Chas Gessner said: "Even with the stadium half full, you'll be able to feel the tension. We'd like to be able to stick it to Harvard. Not only because they've won the last two against us, but because of their, well, attitude. Yes, arrogance. You know -- 'We're Hah-vahd.' But we have a lot of pride at Brown. So those two elements coming together can make for a pretty big collision." 
Gessner, a 6-foot-5, 220-pound history major from Hyattsville, Md., added that a sprinkling of students might recognize him on campus, and that even a few wished him luck on Saturday. "But I think athletics is looked down upon by a lot of the students and faculty," he said. "Like we're just jocks, and the football players are meatheads."
Harvard is the defending Ivy League football champion; Brown was third last season, behind Penn.
Harvard and Brown are rated the top two teams in the Ivy League, each with a candidate -- Gessner and receiver Carl Morris of Harvard -- for the Walter Payton Award, presented annually to the top player in Division I-AA football. 
Harvard is 1-0, coming off a 28-24 nonconference victory over Holy Cross. Brown is 0-1, having lost its opener, a nonconference game to Towson, 56-42.
"We're trying to recover from that game," Brown Coach Phil Estes said. "The coaches came back the day after and spent from 8 in the morning on Sunday to about midnight going over game films, and it's been close to the same the rest of the week, figuring out what we have to do to beat Harvard. I need to find out what kind of team we have. I believe we have a very strong team. I feel confident that Towson was not the defining moment of our season."
Linebacker Andrew Gallagher, an economics major from Allentown, Pa., and one of the team captains, was recruited by Harvard and Brown, and chose Brown because, he said, "The atmosphere was more congenial."
"It seemed the Harvard people were just trying to sell you the name," he continued. "And around campus, it's true that there may not be a huge interest in football, but I think everyone wants to beat Harvard -- in anything."
This will be the 102nd meeting in football between these two universities, dating from 1893, with Harvard holding a 71-28-2 advantage. Both teams have long and, in many cases, distinguished football histories. Brown, it happened, was the first team to play in an official Rose Bowl, in 1916. It had such outstanding players as running back Fritz Pollard, who became the first African-American professional football coach, in the 1920's; a quarterback and defensive back in the late 1940's named Joe Paterno (he still shares a team interception record); and Steve Jordan, Brown '82, a six-time All-Pro tight end for the Minnesota Vikings.
It is probably true that interest in football has declined in the Ivy League in the last 20 years or so, since the Ivy League was pushed from I-A and forced to accept a more or less minor league designation of I-AA. But for some, the passion in Ivy League football remains great, and pranks still abound.
A 1978 Brown alumnus, Dr. Marc Siegel, an associate professor at New York University Medical Center, recalls the year that Brown students stole the huge, six-foot-high drum from the Harvard marching band and drove back on Interstate 95 in a truck, gleefully beating the drum all the way. In retaliation, Siegel said, he heard that some Harvards sneaked into a Brown anatomy lab and stole an arm from a cadaver, went back up I-95, put a quarter for the toll in the hand of their acquisition, and left the amazed tollkeeper holding the unattached limb.
Oh, and the Brown button slogan for Harvard on Saturday is, "I received HONORS for WEARING this button," a swipe at the grade inflation of which Harvard recently has been accused.
Once again, it is getting down and dirty when the Harvards and the Browns clash.

HEADLINE: World Financial Officials Back New Debt Framework 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
The United States and the world's other leading industrial countries moved tonight to assuage global anxieties by declaring their willingness to help countries caught up in economic turmoil, mentioning both Brazil and Argentina as examples.
 In a statement issued by the finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrial countries, following a meeting here this evening, the countries acknowledged that some countries face "considerable challenges" and said they would support those who adopt strong policies to restore growth. 
 The statement also highlighted how worried the United States and others have become about the fragility of the world economy. And it reflected a renewed emphasis by the Bush administration on addressing the problems in poorer countries. 
The group emphatically praised Brazil, where investors have become increasingly panicked about the likelihood of a leftist victory in next month's presidential election. Brazil received a $30 billion loan package last month from the International Monetary Fund, but its currency has been sinking badly in the last few days.
But the finance ministers, led by Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, also voiced surprisingly warm support for Argentina, which has defaulted on more than $100 billion in loans and been widely criticized for failing to fix its fiscal problems.
" We welcome Brazil's continued commitment to sound policies and are ready to support Argentina, through the I.M.F., in the context of a sustainable program," the countries said tonight.
The communique fits into a broader pattern by the Bush administration to view the problems of developing countries as not only economic issues but also as part of a national security strategy, a marked departure in tone from the administration's initial tough-love approach.
Earlier this evening, Mr. O'Neill and the finance ministers from other industrial countries endorsed an important new international legal framework to help nearly bankrupt countries renegotiate loans with their creditors.
Under the plan, which will be endorsed publicly on Saturday, a country in financial trouble would be able to enter something akin to a bankruptcy proceeding. The key change is that a country could re-negotiate its loans if it wins approval from a majority of its creditors, and dissenting creditors would be required to go along.
At least part of the plan is fiercely opposed by big international banks like Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase, which fear being forced to renegotiate billions of dollars in loans they have made throughout Latin America, Africa and Asia. 
Under the plan, to be endorsed publicly on Saturday, a country in financial trouble would be able to enter something akin to a bankruptcy proceeding. The major change is that a country can renegotiate its loans if it wins approval from a majority of its creditors. At the moment, common practice allows any one dissenter to stop such renegotiations. 
The meetings, which began today, were organized mostly by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. They have drawn together financial officials and bankers from around the world.
They have also drawn thousands of protesters, and the police arrested 649 of them today, mainly on charges of disrupting traffic or holding demonstrations without a permit.
The protests had been widely expected. Some organizers had said they planned to "shut down" Washington today, but the crowds that showed up were smaller and more subdued than many had predicted.
The protesters, organized by a group called the Anti-Capitalist Convergence, marched and rode bicycles to a park several blocks from the White House. Carrying signs with messages like "End Corporate Greed" and "Drop Bush Not Bombs," their ranks included antiwar protesters, self-avowed anarchists and even a small, enthusiastic group of pagans.
Though some protesters openly hoped to disrupt normal business here, they were far outnumbered by the police. There was little violence, but security was so tight that police officers quickly began arresting people for holding rallies without a permit or disrupting traffic.
"It was a herding of cattle," said David Stewart, a 24-year-old protester who attended several events but was not arrested.
Between the large police presence and a relatively small turnout of less than 2,000 protesters, the demonstrations had far less effect on Washington businesses than the fact that thousands of workers stayed home to avoid possible trouble. 
But thousands of other protesters planned a series of other events on Saturday. Those have been organized by a broad array of environmentalists, labor unions and groups that view the World Bank and the monetary fund as agents of large multinational corporations.
Leaders organizing those events, many under a group called Mobilization for Global Justice, have registered most of their events with the police in advance and have vowed to keep their rallies nonviolent.
Inside the heavily barricaded buildings of the monetary fund and the World Bank, financial leaders focused heavily on the growing problems in Latin America. Argentina, which has already defaulted on more than $100 billion in loans, remains stalled in its pleas for more lenience from the fund. 
In Brazil, which accounts for 40 percent of the Latin American economy, the national currency has hit its lowest point since the fund offered a $30 billion bailout package last month.
There were far more signs of disagreement than agreement at the meetings. Rich and poor countries are increasingly at odds over what has come to be called the "Washington consensus," an American-style prescription for economic development under which financial assistance is focused on countries that support open markets, deregulation and prudent fiscal policies.
The World Bank stepped up its criticism of the United States and Europe on trade policy, accusing both of causing immense damage to poor countries by maintaining high barriers to agricultural imports.
The meetings are taking place at a time when economic anxiety runs high in many corners of the world. The global economy remains weak, stock markets are buried in pessimism, oil prices are rising amid fear of an American attack on Iraq and trade protectionism is on the rise.
The Bush administration, though occupied with its campaign against terrorists and with its efforts to topple Saddam Hussein in Iraq, is nonetheless devoting greater attention to the economic distress of poor countries.

HEADLINE: Ratings of Building Loans Fall on Insurance Worries 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
A leading credit rating agency said late yesterday that it had downgraded the ratings on $4.5 billion in loans on some of the most prominent office buildings in New York City because the buildings were not adequately insured against terrorism.
 But some bond traders said the decision was likely to have little effect on the owners of the buildings or investors. The traders said the market had been expecting the downgrades since the agency, Moody's Investors Service, expressed concerns about the lack of terrorism coverage at the end of May. 
 "These properties have been trading as if they were going to be downgraded for some time," said John B. Levy, the president of John B. Levy & Company, a real estate investment bank in Richmond, Va. "I don't think you'll see much movement in prices because of these downgrades." 
Moody's indicated that most of the loans that were downgraded were on buildings in New York. But it said loans on the the Bank of America tower in Seattle were also downgraded. Loans on office buildings and hotels in many other cities -- that were among pools of loans dominated by New York buildings -- were also downgraded. The downgrades ranged from one to three notches, but all remained within Moody's investment-grade categories.
Among those downgraded in New York were loans on Rockefeller Center, the Conde Nast Building at 4 Times Square, the headquarters of Citigroup on East 53rd Street and the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square.
The downgrades reflect increased concerns by Moody's over the decision by the insurance industry to withdraw coverage for terrorism after the attacks on the World Trade Center a little more than a year ago.
Moody's said that even though security had been improved at some buildings and that they had obtained at least some terrorism insurance, the risk they faced was "incompatible with the highest levels of Moody's ratings."
The agency has taken the action as the White House and the insurance, banking and real estate industries are pressing Congress to provide assistance that would enable insurance companies to offer terrorism coverage at greatly reduced risk.
Both the House and the Senate have adopted legislation on terrorism coverage, but their solutions are radically different. The Senate would have the government pay most of the costs of a terrorist attack in excess of $10 billion while the House provides for long-term loans to insurers rather than an outright grant.
Before the attacks, which cost the insurance industry an estimated $50 billion, insurers had regarded terrorism in the United States as a remote possibility. They had provided terrorism coverage at no charge.
A few weeks after the attacks, some insurers began offering terrorism coverage in limited amounts at very high prices. More insurers have jumped in to take advantage of the high prices. But there is still not enough terrorism coverage to meet demand, and many businesses that could get coverage are unwilling to pay the price. 
The Bush administration and the industries that have been lobbying for help contend that the lack of terrorism coverage has been a drag on the economy. But they have been unable to muster evidence to prove their point.
In recent weeks, the Real Estate Roundtable, a trade group in Washington, has said that more than $10 billion in real estate deals have been delayed or canceled because of the terrorism insurance issue. But many others said that they thought that the insurance was one of many reasons blocking the projects.
"Everyone in the real estate business would certainly like it if we had government backing for terrorism insurance," Mr. Levy said. "But, that being said, the market is kind of going along without it."
As evidence of the strength of the real estate market, Mr. Levy said, more than $240 million in bonds were sold this week in a refinancing of an office tower in Midtown Manhattan. He said that many bonds had been sold involving packages of dozens of buildings, but that the $240 million deal was the first since the September attacks in which bonds were sold on a single building.

HEADLINE: Russia and U.S. to Discuss Collaborative Oil Ventures 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Energy executives and government officials from Russia and the United States will meet in Houston next week to discuss energy cooperation at a time when concerns over the safety of world oil supplies have been heightened by the Bush administration's push for action against Iraq.
 The conference is expected to include a who's who of leaders of the Russian oil industry as well as executives from American energy companies. The secretary of commerce, Donald L. Evans, and the secretary of the Treasury, Paul H. O'Neill, are also scheduled to take part. 
 The conference, a product of the summit meeting between President Bush and President Putin in May, was originally seen as a step to cement the new relationship between the countries after the terror attacks of Sept. 11. But it has taken on added significance since, as the United States seeks international support for a drive to oust Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. 
Those efforts have set oil markets on edge: crude prices have risen 27 percent since mid-June. And the possibility of warfare that could disrupt oil supplies from the Persian Gulf has thrown a spotlight on the growing importance of Russian oil. 
The Russian companies say they will use the conference to propose projects that would bring more Russian oil more rapidly to world markets, especially the United States. Right now, almost the only export routes open to substantial shipments of Russian oil lead to Western Europe.
"The whole idea is to see whether Russia can become a marketer and a supplier of crude oil to the U.S.," said Simon Kukes, president of Tyumen Oil, Russia's fourth-largest producer. "It could reduce reliance of the U.S. on OPEC and lead to more stability in supply."
American officials have frequently mentioned Russia as a growing world energy supplier, as tensions have risen in the Middle East. Russian output has grown by about 7 percent annually in recent years, and now stands at 7.7 million barrels a day, comparable to that of Saudi Arabia, though Russia consumes about half of its production domestically. 
Speaking to reporters by telephone on Thursday, Mr. Evans said Russia was "a major contributor to the global energy supply, and I expect it to grow."
Mr. Evans would not say whether Russian business interests in Iraq would be a topic at the conference. But Russian companies say it ought to be. Russia has been one of Iraq's biggest trading partners since the United Nations allowed Iraq to start trading oil for food in 1996. Russian companies want assurances from Washington that an American-backed post-Hussein government will honor their contracts with the current regime.
"Everyone is just marking off their territory," said one influential Russian businessman, referring to Russian companies in Iraq. "It's a smart strategy -- signing contracts to get a head start."
Even so, few people here are confident that Russian companies will be able to return to choice projects in Iraq quickly after military action.
"No one here believes that the Americans will be able to install relative order soon," said Sergei Karaganov, the chairman of the board of the Council on Foreign and Defense Policy. "Very few people here are pro-Hussein. He is seen as a dictator and dangerous. But the cure looks more dangerous than the sickness."
Russian companies have said they can supply 10 percent of the United States' demand for imported crude, a figure many analysts dismiss as too optimistic. Indeed, most oil analysts say Russian exports could not offset a major disruption in flows from the Middle East, by far the world's largest oil-producing region.
Still, Russian output is growing, and companies need new markets since demand is stagnant in their existing markets in Europe.
The Russian industry hopes to reach 9.5 million barrels a day by 2010, and will need to expand export facilities extensively to handle the oil. The cramped pipeline network will have to be expanded, and new deepwater ports built to accommodate the supertankers used in the trans-Atlantic oil trade.
The Russian oil companies, led by Lukoil, the biggest producer, will tell the conference of a plan to build 930 miles of pipeline and new loading facilities in the northern port city of Murmansk as a new route for exports to North America.
"American companies could supply services and equipment and share financing costs for this project," said Gennady Krasovsky, a Lukoil spokesman. "This pipeline means more supplies for American consumers, and gives Russia more outlets for its crude."
But the Murmansk project will take years to complete, according to Mr. Kukes, who has called for more immediate steps. He said that international commodity exchanges could help by listing prices for Russia's benchmark oil grade, known as Urals (after the Russian mountain range), and the United States could help by leasing international oil storage facilities to Russian oil companies.
Russian politicians have applauded the new energy rapport between Moscow and Washington as a counterweight to OPEC. Russia is not a member of the cartel, and has sometimes defied the cartel's demands that it limit its exports in the interest of higher prices. 
"The ultimate goal of American and Russian energy cooperation is tearing down the OPEC monopoly," Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko Party, said in an interview. It will, he said, "take away the stick that they are using to terrorize everyone."
Russia's energy sector has only begun to attract a flow of foreign investment after years of unstable economics and bureaucratic hurdles, and there are few signs that major commercial deals will be struck at the conference. But the interest level is rising on both sides.
ChevronTexaco's chief executive, David O'Reilly, was in Moscow this week to survey energy opportunities in Russia. A spokesman for Russia's energy minister said ChevronTexaco had been invited to participate in developing new reserves in Eastern Siberia and the Russian Far East.

HEADLINE: Beating Them To the Prewar 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 

 BODY:
Daniel Webster's ideas haven't held this much sway in the White House for a century and a half.
 But last week, when the White House was defending President Bush's new strategy of "pre-emption," the great orator's thinking about self-defense -- or at least a carefully selected slice of it -- was suddenly being thrown around the White House press room. 
 "Anticipatory self-defense is not a new concept," Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, told reporters the other day as she was explaining why pre-emption was replacing containment and deterrence as the foundation of American defense policy and serving as the justification for striking Iraq before Iraq strikes. "You know, Daniel Webster actually wrote a very famous defense of anticipatory self-defense," she said.
He did, but under circumstances Ms. Rice, a former Stanford University provost, might not want to delve into too deeply. President Bush, of course, employs the term to gin up support for a strike against Iraq before it could put weapons of mass destruction to use. Secretary of State Webster, in contrast, was attempting to calm down Americans demanding another war with Britain -- while chastising the British for not exhausting diplomatic alternatives before burning a civilian American steamboat on the Niagara River. 
It was only the latest example of how history, definitions and defense doctrines are being twisted to fit the Iraq debate. In its rush to convince Congress and the United Nations of the need to act quickly, the Bush administration has bandied about some very different concepts -- pre-emption, preventive war and Ms. Rice's "anticipatory self-defense" (a phrase Webster never used) -- as if they were the same thing. Experts in the field say they are not.
"There's a standard distinction here, and a very important one," said Michael Walzer, whose 1977 work "Just and Unjust Wars" has remained a staple of undergraduate courses on international conflicts. "Condoleezza Rice says we don't have to wait to be attacked; that's true," said Professor Walzer, now at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. "But you do have to wait until you are about to be attacked."
As the debate has matured in recent days, Vice President Dick Cheney has crumpled the concepts together with the ringing phrase that the cost of inaction may be greater than the cost of action. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has insisted there is nothing new here: American history, he suggests, is full of both pre-emptive and preventive military action. But his critics and purists about language offer another explanation: the fuzziness is deliberate. After all, it is hard to argue that Iraq is going to strike us in hours or days when Saddam Hussein has possessed chemical and biological weapons for years, and the British said this week that he is two to five years from having a nuclear device. Thus, attacking Iraq doesn't quite fit under the classic definition of pre-emptive self-defense.
Yet taking out his weapons, to say nothing of knocking off Mr. Hussein himself to make sure they are not rebuilt, more closely resembles preventive war. And that is a problem for the administration, because history and international law have frowned upon preventive war. It has often been used as an excuse for naked aggression.
Daniel Webster gave his own definition of a justifiable pre-emptive action. In 1837 a group of insurgents from Canada who wanted to overthrow British rule teamed up with some Americans eager to repeat the American Revolution on Canadian soil. In what can only be described as a half-baked scheme, they fired some cannonballs across the Niagara River, supplied by a steamboat called the Caroline. The Royal Navy burned it -- an act of pre-emption -- when it was docked on the American side of the river. One man died, but dramatic tales of far greater casualties (including victims swept over Niagara Falls) appeared in American newspapers.
It was five years and a new presidential administration before Webster and his British counterpart tamped it all down, settling the northern border of Maine along the way. In the series of diplomatic exchanges, Webster wrote that striking first against an enemy was acceptable only when the necessity of that self-defense is instant, overwhelming, and leaving no choice of means, and no moment for deliberation."
That is the definition Ms. Rice was alluding to, and the White House insists that the Webster definition applies to this day. But is the Iraqi threat instant? Is it overwhelming? And one question being asked at the United Nations this week: Is there really no moment for deliberation?
A legal adviser in the White House insists Webster's elements are present in the Iraq confrontation. The threat is overwhelming, because his weapons could be used against American allies, including Israel, or slipped to a terrorist for delivery here.
"The only area where we take a slightly more expansive view is in the definition of 'instant,' " the official said. "It's a growing threat, and by the time it becomes an instant threat it's too late."
To other scholars, though, Iraq looks less like a pre-emptive strike and more like a preventive war. And there the classic example is one the White House is unlikely to cite with approval: Dec. 7, 1941. Every schoolchild in Japan is taught that the United States-led embargo on Japan was slowly killing the country's economy and undermining its ability to defend itself. That's why Japan has kept a museum celebrating the heroes of Pearl Harbor.
The logic goes something like this, says Graham Allison of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "I may some day have a war with you, and right now I'm strong, and you're not. So I'm going to have the war now. That, of course, was Japan's thinking, and in candid moments some Japanese scholars say -- off the record -- that the country's big mistake was waiting too long." But Mr. Allison notes that historically, preventive war has been regarded as illegitimate, because if countries act simply because rivals are getting relatively stronger, you end up having a lot of wars.
The other logic for preventive war, he notes, is reducing casualties. "The Israelis figured that in 1967, if they went first, they could blunt the consequences," he said. That mirrors Mr. Cheney's logic. 
Distinctions between preventive and pre-emption are not likely to slow down President Bush as he heads toward a confrontation with Baghdad. Time and again, he and his aides have argued that the old definitions of war don't apply. Terrorists don't send off the kind of classic warning signals -- massing troops on the border, for example -- that made it so much easier to detect an imminent attack in the past. 
What the White House seems to desire is a a new category, something halfway between pre-emptive action and preventive war. With one caveat: In Iraq's case they want to blend in a touch of regime change -- Washington's polite phrase for overthrowing a government -- so that they only have to do this once. As Professor Walzer notes, "That's what makes this neither pre-emptive nor preventive." 
Unfortunately, Daniel Webster didn't go there.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Japanese view the attack on Pearl Harbor as self-defense because a United States embargo was hurting Japan. (Associated Press)
