HEADLINE: FILM; 
The Scenery, Though, He Won't Chew

BYLINE:  By FRANZ LIDZ; Franz Lidz is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated and the author of "Unstrung Heroes." He writes frequently about film.

DATELINE: MALIBU, Calif. 

 BODY:
P . G. WODEHOUSE once described a character as looking like a Welsh rarebit about to come to the height of its fever, and it is this very cheese dish at an acute stage of meltdown that Anthony Hopkins's face now resembles.
 Every two minutes for the last half-hour, the soft air of his Malibu beach house has been rent with the brrrring! of a telephone. Every two minutes Mr. Hopkins has dutifully picked up the receiver and said, "Hello." And every two minutes the receiver cocked to his ear has emitted a shrill, metallic crrrrr! Someone is trying to send him him a fax. 
 Alas, Mr. Hopkins does not own a fax machine. Hence, the Welsh rarebit. 
A master of simmering restraint, this 64-year-old Welsh actor stands at attention, a frosty twinkle in his dead blue eyes. He doesn't blink. "I've worked hard at distilling my work to a more economic form," he says with a kind of pinched elegance. "Over the years, I've become fairly adept at performing little still parts."
Clocking in at 21 minutes, the littlest of his still parts was undoubtedly that of Hannibal Lecter, the voracious mass murderer he essayed in the 1991 thriller "Silence of the Lambs." The M.O. of that brilliant shrink was eating patients when they ceased to interest him. Of one victim, he famously sighed, "His therapy was going nowhere."
Mr. Hopkins achieved a certain perverse poignancy (and won an Oscar) by informing Hannibal the Cannibal with demonic charm, a sense of wounded innocence and an insinuating drawl that crossed Truman Capote with Katharine Hepburn. "There's love in Hannibal, but no pity," says Mr. Hopkins. "His tragedy is that he'll never escape the colossal horror of his inner world."
Now Sir Anthony -- he was knighted in 1993 -- reprises the role for the second time in "Red Dragon," a "Silence of the Lambs" prequel that its director, Brett Ratner, calls "a heartfelt story about a serial killer." Unlike the rococo campiness of last year's "Hannibal" -- Mr. Hopkins gave new meaning to "brain food" by performing neurosurgery with sizzling skillet and rare white Burgundy at hand -- the prevailing mood of the new release is studied gloom.
"Red Dragon," which opens on Friday, is actually the second film to be based on the Thomas Harris novel of the same name. In the original, Michael Mann's "Manhunter" (1986), Lecter was played by another actor trained in the British theater, Brian Cox.
Mr. Hopkins's take is eerily serene, sinister and hypnotic. Even straitjacketed, his face imprisoned in a grotesque hockey mask, he seems perfectly capable of talking you into swallowing your tongue.
"Tony brought a coiled intensity to his scenes in 'Red Dragon,' " Mr. Ratner says. "Lecter is now a vicious, violent man full of blazing rage. In one scene, Tony is so angry and tortured that you can see tears in his eyes."
It's unclear whether Mr. Hopkins regards doing this interview as torture, though he conspicuously consults his watch every 53 seconds or so. In spite of the endless fax interruptions, he's as attentive and unfailingly polite as the repressed butler he played in "Remains of the Day" (1993).
So commanding is Mr. Hopkins's quietude that at times he seems to be following the advice an actor-friend gave him on what makes a good manservant: when he's in the room, the room is emptier.
The twice-divorced Mr. Hopkins -- his second marriage, to Jennifer Lynton, ended in April after 29 years -- shares his beach house with two grand pianos. "The ocean is my backyard," he says, pounding out a Chopin prelude on a Bosendorfer in his living room.
Portraits of malevolent gamecocks stare down from the kitchen walls, but the kitchen counters are somewhat disappointingly bare. There's not a fava bean or a bottle of chianti in sight.
"I seriously considered turning 'Red Dragon' down," Mr. Hopkins says. "I'd done the cutesy stuff twice, and the jokes had worn thin. I wanted to move on. I had no desire to be Fava Bean Man again."
That changed when the producer Dino de Laurentiis leaned on him. In his expressively mangled English, Mr. de Laurentiis recalls: "I told Tony that Brett Ratner is very enthusiasm and wants to do this film with you desperate. I told him, 'It's go if you say yes.' "
Mr. Hopkins said: "And if I don't?"
"Well then, I don't know what we going to do," Mr. de Laurentiis says he replied. "Please, listen to Brett."
Mr. Hopkins listened.
Mr. Ratner says: "I won Tony over by explaining what I love about the character. I said: 'I love that I'm afraid of you. I love being terrified of you.' "
In a recent Internet poll, Mr. Hopkins's Lecter was voted the scariest psychopath in screen history -- not too surprising if you consider that the monstrously beguiling creation was stitched together from parts of filmdom's greatest fiends.
"Like Dracula, Hannibal Lecter has a pronounced taste for human blood," David Skal wrote in "The Monster Show: A Cultural History of Horror." "Like Frankenstein, he is a brilliant but mad scientist; he has two personalities, like Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, both civilized and savage; and like some sideshow super-geek, he is held and exhibited in a succession of zoolike enclosures."
As a boy in Port Talbot, a grim South Wales steel town, Mr. Hopkins wasn't much of a horror fan. "Boris and Bela were fun to watch, but they were more entertaining than frightening," he says. "I remember seeing 'King Kong' and laughing at it."
The only film he found remotely creepy was "Moss Rose," a 1947 Edwardian Gothic about a chorus girl who blackmails her way into an English country estate. As the mad matriarch, Ethel Barrymore was no unobtrusive loony: she made a meal of it. "Now that was scary," Mr. Hopkins says.
His "useless and thoroughly confusing childhood" was as unremarkable as your average triple-ax murderer's. Born Philip Anthony Hopkins, the only child of a baker, he was, by his own account, a clumsy, chunky lad, rotten at school and everything else.
"I was a poor learner, which left me open to ridicule and gave me an inferiority complex," he has said. "I grew up absolutely convinced I was stupid." His only real talent was for drinking India ink, which impressed his school chums but not his teachers.
In desperation, his parents sent him off to a posh boarding school, where the headmaster told him he was "hopeless" and he developed a "sheer contempt for authority." He stumbled into acting at 17 with a Y.M.C.A. group (his one line: "Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth"), studied in London at the Royal Academy and, in 1965, joined Laurence Olivier's National Theater.
His big break came while understudying Olivier in Strindberg's "Dance of Death." When Olivier was hospitalized with appendicitis, he later wrote, Mr. Hopkins "walked away with the part of Edgar like a cat with a mouse between its teeth."
A self-described "antisocial moron," Mr. Hopkins was prone to churlishness and boozing. In 1969, he walked out on his first wife, Petronella Barker, and their 14-month-old daughter, Abigail, now 35 and a film actress. Four years later, he walked out on a production of "Macbeth" at the National.
"I'd begun to loathe acting in the classical theater," Mr. Hopkins says. He resurfaced to acclaim in the 1974 Broadway production of "Equus." Hollywood came calling, and he settled there the next year. But his disposition didn't improve until he stopped drinking, cold, on Dec. 29, 1975, after waking up in a Phoenix hotel room with no memory of having driven from Los Angeles. It was two days before his 38th birthday. 
STILL, he continued to spiral downward, at times sitting at home for hours without saying a word. He'd climb in his car and cruise aimlessly for days: once he went on a drive and didn't return for two months. "If there is someone fighting within you, it makes your life unbearable," he says. "Anger has to be converted into something else or it destroys you."
During a 10-year stint in L.A., Mr. Hopkins made lots of money and so many dodgy movies -- least notably "International Velvet," "Audrey Rose" and "Change of Seasons," in which he shared a hot tub with Bo Derek -- that it's hard to imagine what roles he turned down. There were triumphs, too, in film ("The Elephant Man," "The Bounty") and in television, where he excelled at playing madmen and grotesques. He won Emmys for his turns as Hitler and Bruno Hauptmann, the kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby. But somehow, the promise didn't quite ignite into stardom.
After embracing Alcoholics Anonymous, Mr. Hopkins returned to England in the mid-1980's with his second wife, Ms. Lynton. He rebuilt his career with stunning stage work: in David Henry Hwang's "M. Butterfly," he played a French diplomat seduced and traduced by the talents of a Chinese performer; he did the lead in "King Lear"; he won the London Theater Association's award for best actor with his portrayal of a scabrous newspaper tycoon in David Hare and Howard Brenton's "Pravda."
Then came Hannibal, and everything changed. Merchant and Ivory tapped Mr. Hopkins for "Howards End" and "Remains of the Day," for which he received his second best-actor nomination. For the 1995 film biography "Nixon," Oliver Stone cast him in the lead. "Nixon was the greatest challenge of my career," Mr. Hopkins says. The hunted, haunted portrayal earned him his third Oscar nomination. (His most recent was a nomination for best supporting actor, for playing John Quincy Adams in Steven Spielberg's "Amistad.")
Two years ago, in an L.A. courthouse, Mr. Hopkins pledged allegiance to the American flag. Though Sir Anthony retains his British citizenship and title, Fleet Street tabloids branded him "Hannibal Traitor" and "Hannibal Defector" and quoted a scandalized Port Talbot postmaster: "Sir Anthony is always harping on about his Welshness, but when the chips are down he decides to go away. To be honest, I think he is a hypocrite."
Upon hearing this, Mr. Hopkins throws up his hands. "I am a simple man from a meat-and-potatoes background," he says. "I moved to La-La Land because, at heart, I am a beach bum." Bumming around, he reckons, has helped him conquer "a psychological state of self-destructive mayhem." 
So what becalms a legend most? "Lear learned compassion," he says. "It melted him and thawed him out."
Not long ago Mr. Hopkins watched a documentary on the pianist Vladimir Horowitz. "At one point Horowitz takes off his jacket and plays this very complex, discordant piece -- Scriabin, I believe," he says. "When it was over, he got up, crossed to the sofa and asked his wife what she thought.
" 'Well,' she said, 'you're the devil.' And he said, 'Yeah.' At the age of 81, he was the devil.
"At that moment, I thought, 'There's a devil side to Horowitz, a dark side, a big shadow side, because of his prodigious genius.' He had gone through a patch of depression so severe that for many years he didn't play. I thought, 'That must not be too easy to live with.' "
Now crustily cruising into a triumphant old age, this once dark and stormy knight claims work no longer engulfs him. "It's a job -- nothing more," Mr. Hopkins says. "I don't take it home. People are slightly astonished or may be offended by my rather mundane approach to it all, or what seems to be mundane. I try to explain it's what I do and that I'm not any of these people I play. I just interpret, and I really don't know how it works. Maybe that makes me a very shallow actor."
So what is Mr. Hopkins's idea of hell?
The icy blue eyes suddenly look sharp enough to pierce glass. "Hell, for me, would be a wet Wednesday afternoon at the Old Vic," he says. "Other actors would be onstage reciting verse, and I'd be standing in the wings in wrinkled tights, thinking, 'Oh, God, another endless production' for the rest of eternity."

'Hamlet' to Lecter
Since 1960, Anthony Hopkins has appeared in (or narrated) nearly 100 movies, including many made for television. Here is a selected list of feature films and his roles.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/East 93rd Street Between Madison and Park Avenues; 
Where City's Stately Mansions Made a Last Stand

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE world changed forever -- after the stock market crash of 1929. And one of the biggest changes was the end of the era of large mansions on the Upper East Side, as even the richest families found irresistible the convenience and economy of apartment living. But on 93rd Street between Madison and Park Avenues, several families sought to make a last stand of elegance. Now new owners are taking over two of the mansions.
 This block of 93rd was nearly empty in 1888 when its oldest buildings went up, the row houses at 57 and 61 East 93rd. Then in 1891 came the small apartment buildings at 62 to 72 East 93rd. In 1900 the developer Frederick Kilpatrick built the more expansive Alamo apartment building at 55 East 93rd, which offered apartments of 5 to 12 rooms. 
 By this time the block had filled up with other modest buildings, hardly the company that the mansions' builders, who were filtering up Fifth Avenue, would like to keep. One big house did go up on the northwest corner of 93rd and Park, built in 1917 by the financier Francis F. Palmer and designed by Delano & Aldrich, but the nearly cubic Georgian-style house related to the growing stature of Park Avenue, not to 93rd Street. 
Down in Murray Hill, the banker George F. Baker, head of National City Bank and one of the richest men in the country, was fighting apartment and loft developers who sought to build high-rises that would overshadow his mansion at Madison near 39th. Baker, who oversaw a family complex that included a house for his in-laws, the Loews, faced the unpleasant prospect of buying up parcel after parcel as other householders fled to Midtown and farther north.
He kept on, but the younger generation did not. In 1927, George F. Baker Jr. left the Murray Hill enclave and bought the old Palmer mansion at 93rd and Park. The younger Baker brought back Delano & Aldrich to add a ballroom to the main houseand to design a smaller house at 67 East 93rd and a garage at 69 East 93rd, all in complementary style. 
The son's uptown defection spread, and in 1930 his sister and brother-in-law, Florence and William Goadby Loew, bought the properties at 54 to 58 East 93rd, They retained Walker & Gillette to design a sumptuous, Regency-style limestone house at 56 East 93rd, with a distinctive, inward-curving facade. Building records indicate it was for "the owner, his wife and 16 servants." 
In the same year, Virginia Vanderbilt, divorced in 1927 from William K. Vanderbilt Jr., bought the buildings at 60 to 64 East 93rd Street. To replace them, she had the architect John Russell Pope design a French classic house of 51 rooms. It is likely that Mrs. Vanderbilt was more than just casually friendly with the Bakers and the Loews. In 1920 she gave a dinner at her Fifth Avenue mansion for the Loews' daughter, Evelyn. 
The "new residential colony," as The New York Times put it in 1930, ran counter to the decline of the large private house in New York, and that year marked the last boom for such dwellings. Plans for five in all of Manhattan were filed at the Department of Buildings that year, and the few built after the Depression never again rivaled the precrash versions. 
A fourth big house was scheduled for the block in 1930. The old buildings at 66 to 68 East 93rd were bought by the songwriter Irving Berlin, who also had a connection to Mrs. Vanderbilt. His wife was the former Ellin Mackay, and her grandfather, John W. Mackay, had been a partner in Nevada silver operations with Mrs. Vanderbilt's father, James Fair.
Berlin intended also to build a house, but the deepening Depression ended his plans. "Money came up a lot the summer after the Crash," his daughter, Mary Ellin Barrett, recalled in her book, "Irving Berlin: A Daughter's Memoir" (Knopf, 1994). The Berlins did not file plans for the house, and Mrs. Barrett says she does not know if they even hired an architect; they remained living in the Warwick Hotel on West 54th Street.
The Loew and Vanderbilt houses were completed in 1931, the same year that George F. Baker Sr. died in his Murray Hill house, and both Baker Jr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt bought other adjacent properties to protect their home sites. The aspirations of these millionaires brought others to the block, like the architect William H. Russell, who remodeled the front of 65 East 93rd Street in the Art Deco style for his own occupancy. But the golden age of mansions on East 93rd Street was brief; Virginia Vanderbilt died in 1935, Florence Loew in 1936 and George F. Baker Jr. in 1937.
Those with different ideas arrived, among them Jan Ruhtenberg, a Latvian-born modernist architect who had studied with Mies van der Rohe. Ruhtenberg stripped down the old brownstone at 57 East 93rd. In 1937 the magazine Architectural Forum praised the removal of plaster from the interior brick walls, which "gained three inches of valuable space in the entry and provided a richly textured surface in the studio which shows off the severe furniture to great advantage." 
The smaller houses were cut up into apartments. In 1938 one tenant in Russell's Art Deco house, which had been converted to apartments, was Diana Vreeland. She had just begun her American fashion career at Harper's Bazaar -- later she was to become editor in chief of Vogue. Her purposely outrageous column, "Why Don't You?," made provocative fashion suggestions, including yellow collars "for all your dogs" and a furry elkhide trunk for the back of your car. 
THE biggest houses were harder to carve up. In 1955 the Loew family sold its house to the impresario Billy Rose, still famous for his Aquacades at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair, and in 1958 the Bakers sold their big corner house to the Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia, which still owns it. Irving Berlin did not sell his house site until 1959. The Vanderbilt house later became one of several buildings of the Lycee Francaise de New York.
Edward F. Ulmann, a retired industrialist, owned Baker's smaller house in the 1970's and 1980's, and recalled it with affection. "Although I hadn't been brought up in modest circumstances, it was a revelation to me what a genius William Delano was as far as demanding comfort is concerned," he said. "Everything always fell to hand, the light switches, the outlets, the door handles, they were always where you wanted them. 
"There was an entire floor for the servants, not way up in the roof but inserted invisibly above the ground floor. The trunk room was beautifully fitted out with cedar slats to keep your trunks off the floor. 
"In the dining room you never had the smell of food because the kitchen was in the basement -- in fact it took me several years to discover we even had a kitchen. There was a bank of freezers in the basement that wouldn't have surprised the captain of the Q.E.II." 
Both Mr. Ulmann's house and the Baker garage are now owned by the investor and house collector Richard H. Jenrette. 
Now a huge barricade runs in front of the old Loew house for the Spence School, which bought the building in 1999 and is altering it for school use. Samuel White, the architect in charge of the work, said the Loews' varied interiors -- from Jacobean to Art Deco -- are in storage and will be reinstalled.
Next door in the old Vanderbilt mansion, the students of the Lycee Francaise are still at work, but the school has sold the building to Carlton Hobbs, a London antiques dealer. The school will occupy the building until its new campus at 75th and York is finished. So the latest chapter in the history of this block of New York's last mansions will not be completed for a few more years.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Restoring Neighborhoods by Renovating Eyesores

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
THE best way to turn around a neighborhood on the skids is the hardest way, at least according to the experience of one nonprofit development company using an innovative approach in Orange and East Orange.
 "What we've learned you have to do," said Patrick Morrissey, director of the Hands group, "is take the biggest eyesore on a block -- the messiest, most awful building where the police get called all the time and the neighbors don't even want to walk past it on the street -- take it, get control of it and transform it into a house that sends a positive message about what's going on in that neighborhood." 
 Hands, formerly known as Housing and Neighborhood Development Services Inc., was founded in 1986 by members of the clergy and community leaders who said they wanted to see Orange -- population 32,000 -- and East Orange -- population 77,000 -- "remain good places to raise a family." 
Both towns have long had very low rates of homeownership, currently 26 percent in Orange, 28 percent in East Orange, compared with a statewide average of 67 percent. Both towns also have about 19 percent of households living below the poverty line, compared with a statewide poverty rate of 6.2 percent. 
Nevertheless, both municipalities possess a stock of decent -- or at least salvageable -- housing, plus a goodly number of working families and anchor institutions like hospitals and community colleges.
In any given neighborhood poised between deterioration and revitalization, there are "tipping factors" that determine the direction it goes, said Wayne Meyer, the housing director of Hands. 
"One bad house will send an entire block, or even several blocks, in the wrong direction, toward deterioration and decline," Mr. Meyer said. One bad house can also seriously affect property values, he asserted. Mr. Meyer, a lawyer with 20 years experience in the private real estate world before he joined Hands, estimated that a troubled building generally brings down the value of all homes on the block by 10 percent.
During its first decade, the small staff at Hands -- which has always been countable on fingers -- followed the ordinary path of community developers. It contracted to build new one and two-family homes or rehabilitate raggedy ones when the city handed over title to derelict properties. Then, Hands sold the houses to first-time home buyers. It created a HomeBuyers Club to prepare first-time buyers and organized three neighborhood groups and two citywide coalitions. It provided training for community leaders and worked out partnerships with City Hall, other nonprofits and business groups.
"At some point we realized, however," Mr. Morrissey said, "that to actually save a neighborhood that's in danger of going down, you can't simply add new homes. You have to put the process of decline in reverse."
WHAT Hands came up with is something called "high-impact development for long-term sustainable change." The strategy involves zeroing in on buildings that are in such bad shape that they are contaminating the area and transforming them into model brick-and-mortar "citizens."
Working with a $500,000 grant from the state's Balanced Housing Program -- which approved a similar pilot program in Camden several years ago -- Hands is focusing on properties in Orange's East Ward, stretching along the East Orange border. The East Ward was divided east to west 30 years ago by construction of Interstate 280.
"Give us your worst," Hands essentially asks owners of property in the area, including the city. But getting clear title to the wrecks has proved to be the most difficult part of the process, according to Mr. Morrissey and Mr. Meyer. So difficult, in fact, that Hands cried out for help to the Housing and Community Development Association of New Jersey. Diane Sterner, director of the group, responded by working with Hands to write legislation that will make it easier for municipalities to clear title to properties. The legislation is pending in the State Legislature.
Mr. Meyer tells tales of title searches on abandoned properties or estates that involved sorting claims by dozens of relatives, associates and squatters (tenants who have no leases and do not pay rent). He must do all the sorting and resolving before going to City Hall, he said, because overburdened municipalities are not equipped for such struggles.
"We cleaned up this corner, Hillyer and William," Mr. Morrissey said, standing outside the two-story frame houses there now. "It was the worst corner in the East Ward, so bad you can't believe -- guns, drugs, a brothel in there, everything. We cleaned it up." Mr. Meyer added, "It took forever, because owners had died, and getting the titles was a nightmare."
Currently, Hands is rebuilding a multifamily building at 151 Chapman Street.
"The city made some mistakes in the process of taking over the property," Mr. Morrissey said. "When we pointed it out to the city, it seemed to be low on their priority list to deal with it, and we couldn't take title until the neighborhood group went to City Hall wearing buttons and shouting slogans."
Sarah Bundley, who lives across the street in a three-bedroom home with a neat garden and well-swept sidewalk, had to strain to remember when the building first became derelict. "Let's see, my granddaughter was a baby then, and now she's in high school," she said, "so it's been about 17 years."
Within a few blocks, Hands just completed work on a house at 153 Elm Street. "Every month at the meetings of neighborhood groups, this house and the one next to it were the topic of conversation," he said. The building at 153 Elm was a two-family house, occupied by several tenants whose rent was paid by the federal Section 8 housing assistance program. It was abandoned long ago by its owner, and the tenants in turn rented out some of its rooms. The downstairs became a "party room," as Mr. Meyer put it. 
Elizabeth Jackson, who lives down the block in a Hands house she purchased in 1996, called it "worse than an eyesore." She said that about two-thirds of the residents of the block had been there 20 years or more and were obviously committed to their neighborhood -- but felt trapped in their homes by "a lot of young people hanging on the corner, swarming around at night."
The house had fallen into the Hands of a bank in San Diego that held a $110,000 mortgage, collected the subsidized rents but was two years behind on paying taxes. Hands arranged financing to relocate the tenants, rent-paying and otherwise, and totally rehabilitate the building, but could not manage to get the bank to respond.
That required the services of Ms. Jackson, who is not only a community activist now serving on the Hands board, but also a community policing specialist with the Orange Police Department for 20 years. 
She provided copies of the police activity logs showing nightly calls to that address and weekly conference calls with the ward councilman, and these were faxed to the bank. 
"The bank quickly hired an appraiser from Saddle River, who arrived at the house after dark one evening, driving a Lexus," Mr. Meyer recounted. "He gave a kid $10 to watch the car, but never did go inside the house. The place really, really smelled, for one thing. I just gave him the data, and that's how we got the house."
HANDS took ownership of the place for $35,000, made it over into one of the nicest houses on the block, painted it sparkling white and sold it to a man and his family.
Meanwhile, the organization has just managed to acquire title to the troubled house next door and is preparing to do a makeover there. It will be the 62nd house that the group has either built or renovated. 
On the other side of 153, there had been a "For Sale" sign out front during much of the title-search saga. But one day after much of the work had been done at the Hands house, Mr. Morrissey noticed the sign was down and repairmen and painters were at work on the neighboring house. "What's going on?" Mr. Morrissey said he asked the owner when he appeared on the front lawn.
"He says to me, 'Don't you know? They're fixing up that place there, and the whole neighborhood is going to go up.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mohammed Momo, with Wayne Meyer of Hands, in front of Mr. Momo's home at 153 Elm Street, Orange. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Business Founder at 14, Old Hand at 20

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
RON LAZAR remembers meeting Gregory Galant three years ago at a Chamber of Commerce dinner in Huntington. Mr. Lazar, a commercial broker in Melville who graduated from Dartmouth College in 1953, didn't realize he was chatting with a poised if precocious member of Huntington High School's class of 2001. Mr. Lazar invited him to attend the next meeting of the chamber committee he chairs on economic development.
 A longtime member of the Huntington chamber, whom Mr. Lazar declined to identify, witnessed their conversation. "He says to me, 'Don't you know you were talking to a high school kid!' " Mr. Lazar recalled. "I guess he meant, 'Don't waste your time.' I ignored him. High school kid or not, Greg was already a businessman. I knew I wasn't wasting my time." 
 Mr. Lazar's opinion was borne out when Mr. Galant (pronounced GAL-ant) showed up at the next committee meeting and volunteered to write a business plan for the group, a task long deferred by the members. Mr. Lazar gave him a shot at it. A week later Mr Galant handed over a thick document explaining the committee's mission and suggesting a detailed plan of action. 
Mr. Lazar was impressed.
Mr. Galant turned 20 on Sept. 10 and earlier this month started his sophomore year at Emory University in Atlanta. He shows no sign of allowing his status as an undergraduate to slow down the growth of his Web development business on Long Island. The business is called Halenet, after the Halesite neighborhood of Huntington where he grew up and where his family still lives. He also remains active in the Huntington chamber, where he continues to meet potential customers and chat up people who may be decades older but who may also need a new Web site.
Age has never been an issue with Mr. Galant, who started his business when he was 14. Over the phone, he is as poised and confident as someone twice his age. In person, he appears years older. Older people sometimes use his youth as an excuse to bargain harder, he said, and peers don't always understand his entrepreneurial drive. It still rankles that his freshman classmates nicknamed him Bill Gates and that clients sometimes balked at signing contracts with a minor.
"I don't think age is important," he said. "What matters is that you understand business. I've been doing Web sites about as long as anybody else. Of course, Web sites haven't been around all that long."
Mr. Galant said that joining the chamber was a wise decision. He sent his check in by mail, so chamber officials did not know the organization had just enrolled the first high school student in its history. 
Somehow, in spite of college classwork and the hours spent building some 30 Web sites last year, Mr. Galant found time to form a new group at the chamber, the Young Professionals Chamber of Commerce, aimed at encouraging youthful entrepreneurship. 
The group's name is something of a misnomer, since the members are high school and college students. "The thing is, they all aspire to become professionals, and the group is there to help them do that," said Linda Mitchell, a former third-grade teacher and former corporate trainer who now works for the chamber.
This year, for the second consecutive year, Mr. Galant helped William Barrett, a retired executive who is a mentor to many young entrepreneurs on the North Shore, run a series of workshops for the chamber, classes that teach entrepreneurial fundamentals to young people.
The workshops' reputation has now blossomed beyond the adolescent set. Among the participants this year were David Engasser, a 30-year-old aspiring graphic artist, and Donna Inocco, an experienced high school business teacher who wanted to pick up some ideas for her own classes.
"How old am I? I'm 19! " Ms. Inocco said, smiling broadly. 
Throughout the eight workshop sessions, Mr. Galant and Mr. Barrett, who is 75, took turns offering suggestions, asking questions and as often as possible assuring the participants that they were making good progress.
The students included Maddie Warlan and Tessa Coneys, both 13, who made scented soap by hand and sold it through Sensations, a gift shop on Main Street in Huntington. Another was William Palumbo, 17, who buys and sells used cars. Matthew Moore and Kevin Rausro, both 16, developed a plan for a business that would provide entertainment at golf tournaments. Eddie Marcucci, 14, helps out at his father's auto detailing business. Derek Schacker, 16, created customized lawn decorations sold through his mother's landscape design business.
One July evening, at one of the last of the workshops, a graduate from last year, Alex Zelenka, returned to share tales of entrepreneurial success. "Like Mr. Barrett says, you can't sit there and hope it happens -- you've got to take action to make it happen," said Mr. Zelenka, 19, who was describing how he creates demand for his landscaping business, now in its second year.
Mr. Galant did not offer himself as an example of teenage entrepreneurship, but he could have. His first paying client was a detective agency in Ramsey, N.J. More business followed. Mr. Galant found himself designing Web sites for government agencies, small local businesses and some nonprofit groups. In 2000 he joined the Long Island Web Developers Guild, submitted one of his Web sites and won an award for it.
He estimates that he will earn $30,000 this year designing Web sites. While paltry by the dot-com standards of several years ago, the amount is hardly insignificant, considering Mr. Galant works part time as a site developer and full time as a student some 700 miles away. The amount, in fact, is probably more than some professional Web developers will make this year. 
The field has thinned out lately, but Mr. Galant said that he, for one, was not lacking for business. He does an increasing amount of what's called back-end work, that is, improving the way a Web site processes information. For this, most of his clients are other Web developers who lack the necessary computer programming skills.
Mr. Galant believes a Web developer's No. 1 task is to create a site that works efficiently. "Many sites fail because they aren't useful," he said. "You take one look and say, 'A designer did this site,' or 'A programmer did this site.' The design is beautiful but serves no purpose. Or the site is filled with movement but gives you no information and doesn't let you really do anything."
Mr. Galant said he focused on the purpose of a given Web site and tried to organize the site around his client's business needs. "A lot of it is common sense," he said.
Aside from the preoccupations with his business, Mr. Galant is sorting out whether to major in business or liberal arts at Emory. He is leaning toward a business major, but his friends at the Chamber of Commerce, including Mr. Lazar, are urging him toward liberal arts.
"He can always return for a master's degree in business later on," Mr. Lazar said.
Of course, when you're 20, "later on" may seem an eternity away.
"I don't know where I'll be in 10 years, let alone 5," Mr. Galant said. "But I'm certain whatever it is will involve technology and that I'll be in business for myself."

(Photographs by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Downtown New Haven's Multifaceted Rehabilitation

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, New Haven rejected the idea of stimulating its economy by building a one-million-square-foot mall on its waterfront. A lawsuit filed against the city by the Connecticut Post Mall in Milford was a contributing factor.
 "It became clear to us," said New Haven's mayor, John DeStefano Jr., "that you ought to compete in areas where you can win, and so we wrapped our arms around the arts, biosciences and downtown residential development. It was from taking stock of inventory that we figured out what we could do to succeed." 
 The inventory began with Yale University, its investment in upgrading blighted streets and supporting fledgling bioscience companies, its repertory theater, art gallery, center for British art and concert series. The list continued with Long Wharf Theater, New Haven Symphony, Creative Arts Center, Educational Center for the Arts, Shubert Performing Arts Center, Palace Theater, four other colleges and universities, several national historic districts and three local ones -- with architecturally significant restored Victorian homes. 
Henry Fernandez, the city's economic development administrator, has worked for three years toward a five-year goal. In two more years, he said, "we will have rehabilitated the 50-square-block area of downtown New Haven, almost entirely with private money," except for $30 million provided by the state in 2001, of which $13 million has been used for housing redevelopment.
"Recognition of the commercial value of science and research labs," the mayor said, "brought developers who wanted to develop space for them, lawyers who wanted to service them. Retailers took notice of the fact that we have the largest population of 20- to 34-year-olds in the state." 
On a Saturday night, just south of the New Haven Green along Chapel, Temple, Crown and College Streets, there are new restaurants, smart shops, nightclubs, galleries and a sidewalk market several blocks long jammed with residents, suburbanites and some of Yale's 11,000 students. Crime, a major concern, has dropped from 21,000 incidents in 1990 to 10,000 so far this year and murders have declined from 35 in 1990 to 7 so far this year.
At long last, the failed Chapel Square Mall is getting a reprise. Williams Jackson Ewing of Baltimore, which had a leading role in the redevelopment of Grand Central Terminal as well as of Union Station in Washington and numerous other locations, has purchased the property. In partnership with College Street L.L.C. of New Haven and Lubert-Adler, a Philadelphia investment firm, it will help to reposition the mall as a retail, office and market-rate residential complex. "We are in the process of relocating existing tenants and resolving a lawsuit brought by some who don't want to move," said W. Lehr Jackson, a principal in the redevelopment firm.
The ground floor and second floor, with 214,540 square feet of retail and restaurant space now facing inside the building, will open onto Crown, Temple and Church Streets. The office tower above will contain four floors of 44 market-rate apartments, and seven floors become upscale offices. 
Standing on one full block each of Church Street are Macy's and Malley's department stores, both vacant for years. The city is considering moving Gateway Community College from its Long Wharf location into the two stores and joining them across George Street. But the prestigious Long Wharf Theater, whose lease expires in 2007, is considering the two department store blocks for its future home, while the city would prefer that the theater, a hotel and conference center form a complex at the site of the Veterans Memorial Coliseum, scheduled for demolition within a year. Jerry Meyer, president of the theater's board, said, "We voted to negotiate with the city, but we are looking at several sites." 
Meanwhile, Ikea, the Swedish home-furnishings chain, has agreed to buy the Pirelli-Armstrong Tire and Rubber Building at Long Wharf. The building, designed by Marcel Breuer, has state landmark status. "We have submitted applications to the Board of Aldermen and the Planning Commission," Patrick Smith, an Ikea spokesman, said, "and we expect construction to start in the spring of 2003." The rear of the building will be demolished but the landmark facade will remain. A 300,000-square-foot store will be built to the south side of the facade, and the rest of the 19.26-acre property will have parking for 1,336 cars.
One of the city's most beautiful buildings is the former headquarters of the Southern New England Telephone Company at 227 Church Street, which is being converted into 143 luxury apartments by ELK Investors of New York City. Morry Kalimian, a principal in ELK, bought the property some years ago for about $2 million, but delayed renovations until he was assured that the city would build a parking garage on land he owns behind the SNET building.
"You can't charge top rent and not have parking," he said. The studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom apartments will have hardwood floors, cherry cabinets, granite countertops, cast-iron bathtubs, 10-foot-high ceilings and a washer and dryer in every apartment. 
Another building that was converted to apartments opened in May and is fully occupied. It was developed by College Street L.L.C. and Lubert-Adler. The 187,000- square-foot-building, the former Strouse-Adler girdle factory, was reconfigured into 146 one- and two-bedroom apartments that rent for $900 to $2,950 a month. Young professionals are attracted to its semi-industrial features, including the massive original wood beams supported by steel girders in 20-by-25-foot living rooms with 15-foot-high ceilings and enormous windows. The building contains a fitness room, billiard room and a courtyard garden with a wrought iron gazebo. 
OPPOSITE the southeast corner of the Green, a residential project completed in the 90's transformed a derelict neighborhood into a handsome mix of new and rehabilitated buildings with 350 apartments. It won numerous awards for Herbert S. Newman & Partners of New Haven. 
Mr. Newman, a member of the faculty at Yale's School of Architecture, is now working on rehabilitating an 1860's structure and the contiguous 1928 Woolworth Building, converting the interiors to market-rate studio, one-bedroom and two-bedroom duplex apartments just off the Green. They will contribute to a total of 250 newly redeveloped downtown apartments. The ground floor will be reserved for commercial use, and the facades will be retained to comply with National Historic District rules. 
"Apartments here are at a premium," said Barbara Pearce, co-owner of the H. Pearce Residential Real Estate Company, "and we're still seeing people who bought homes in the mid-80's who can't get back what they paid. The average sale is around $85,000, up from $75,000 two years ago." 
Nevertheless, homes in the $200,000 range sell quickly, according to Nellie Oldenwaelder, manager of Pearce's New Haven office. "Houses at $400,000 and over don't last long," she said, "even though taxes are high. A $400,000 house on a 90-by-200-foot lot is taxed between $9,000 and $10,000." Tax-exempt institutions make up 45 percent of New Haven's real estate, which increases taxes on other property.
Carl Traub, head of Traub & Company, a commercial real estate firm, is concerned about the current redevelopment. "There is a ceaseless demand for apartments, because people want to live here -- there's so much to do. But I have a problem putting a residential building like the SNET conversion in the middle of the city's financial district and converting part of the Chapel Square Mall to apartments when we need office space. I worry about a saturation of residential property." He takes little comfort in the construction of one 60,000-square-foot downtown office building, the city's first speculative commercial building in a decade, at One Audubon Street, developed by the Acorn Group.
With office vacancies well below 10 percent, Richard Guralnick, managing director of Insignia/ESG's New Haven office, noted that "Connecticut Financial Center has some sublet space left by United Illuminating at $30 a foot," although the New Haven norm is high teens to low $20's a square foot. 
Biotechnology, observers say, appears to be the city's new industry. "Graduates coming out of the Yale Medical School start in Science Park" (a Yale-sponsored incubator), Mr. Guralnick said, "then branch out on their own, assisted by Yale and venture capital. The university anticipates six to eight start-ups a year." 
Several mature firms are housed at 300 George Street, a 550,000-square- foot building once owned by Southern New England Telephone that the Winstanley family, which has a privately held real estate firm in Concord, Mass., has repositioned. Bioscience companies in the area include Curagen, Achillion Pharmaceuticals, Molecular Staging, Rib-X Pharmaceuticals, Sopherion Therapeutics, VaxInnate, Bion, Alexion and Genaissance. "They have settled in and around New Haven, but New Haven is the core," Mr. Guralnick said.

HEADLINE: Emergency Workers Will Get Tax Breaks 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE Towns of Babylon and Huntington have voted to become the first municipalities on Long Island to award a partial property tax exemption to volunteer firefighters and ambulance personnel.
 The action comes at a time when Long Island officials are looking a ways to attract and retain volunteers, who would be crucially important in any terrorist attack. Fire officials in both Nassau and Suffolk said recruits increased after Sept. 11. 
The new exemption, authorized for Suffolk County in just-enacted state legislation introduced by Assemblyman Steve Levy, Democrat of Holbrook, and Senator Caesar Trunzo, Republican of Brentwood, will be a pittance initially, amounting to a saving of only $9 in town taxes for the Babylon volunteers who qualify. 
"I'll buy a pizza or something with it," said Robert Bodenmiller, the chief of the town's East Farmingdale Fire Company, who nonetheless expressed gratitude and applauded the town action.
Mr. Levy said last week that he had filed amendments that would allow Suffolk County and its towns, villages and school districts the option of authorizing property tax exemptions of 10 percent of assessed value for the county's estimated 10,000 firefighters and several thousand ambulance workers. An apparent flaw in the language of the law pinned the exemption to equalization rates, leading to the low amount in Babylon. Mr. Levy said the amendment would correct this. 
A separate law for Nassau will allow the county and its towns, villages and two cities to grant a similar exemption. That measure, introduced by Assemblyman David Sidikman, Democrat of Plainview, and Senator Carl Marcellino, Republican of Oyster Bay. was enacted last month, but it does not extend the exemption option to school districts, Mr. Sidikman's office said. 
Last week, the Democratic majority in the Nassau County Legislature introduced a bill that would allow the estimated 10,000 volunteer firefighters and an unknown number of ambulance workers a 10 percent break on county taxes. David Denenberg, Democrat of Merrick, said the cost to the county would be about $1.2 million, assuming all the volunteers were eligible. A vote could come as early as next month.
Oyster Bay and Hempstead are considering town exemptions. 
To qualify in Suffolk, volunteers must be property owners with at least five years as active members of their local fire departments or volunteer ambulance services. After 20 years' service, the exemption will become lifelong.
Other taxpayers would make up the difference for the exemptions. Mr. Levy said the cost should be measured against the benefits of maintaining Suffolk's 109 volunteer fire departments.
"This is a tax saver in the long run because without incentives, we will have to go to a paid force, which will cost a fortune," he said. If the 10,000 volunteer firefighters earned an average of $50,000 in salary and benefits, maintaining paid departments would cost $500 million a year. 
The exemption is in addition to pension benefits many volunteers accrue under a state law that allows up to $20 a year in credits, multiplied by years of service, or up to $400 a month for a volunteer active for 20 years. Property owners pay for the pensions in taxes collected by fire districts, villages and towns.
Mr. Levy said the new property tax exemption provided a more immediate incentive. "A lot of people don't want to wait until they retire to see a savings," he said. 
Steven Bellone, the Babylon supervisor, said he hoped the town's action would influence other governments and school districts to follow suit. "It's a way to say thank you," he said. "We have to be very thankful we have men and women who are willing to do this."
Robert J. Gaffney, Suffolk's county executive, supports the exemption for the county share of property taxes. Two county legislators have proposed bills to would enact it, but a vote may be delayed until the state law is amended to assure the full 10 percent tax break.
Robert Lipp, the principal economist for the County Legislature's Budget Review Office, said a 10 percent reduction in county taxes would save the average volunteer $85 a year. He said the savings would be only $14 as the law is currently written.
In East Farmingdale, Chief Bodenmiller said that the Babylon action was an indicator that more incentives might be on the way. "It's a start," he said. "But I wish there was something more we could do to give an incentive to young people."
He said pension benefits seemed more of an attraction to volunteers in or near middle age. "These are the people worried about their future and their retirement," he said.
Mr. Bodenmiller said he worried that other taxpayers would feel put-upon by financial incentives for volunteers. "Somebody is going to have to pay for it," he said. "At what point will people say, 'Hey, don't we already pay enough?' "

HEADLINE: Who Slept Here? Well-Preserved Homes Reveal All 

BYLINE:  By R. W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT is a hotbed of historic houses.
 There are 162 houses that have been turned into museums in a state with 169 cities and towns, according to a Web site maintained by the University of Connecticut library. 
 "I think the very DNA of our civilization has been lovingly preserved and cared for in these distinctively American museums," said William Hosley, 46, the executive director of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society, a Hartford organization that owns and operates nine historic house museums across Connecticut.
Some professionals in the field would qualify this rosy appraisal. The American Association for State and Local History and the National Trust for Historic Preservation sponsored a forum in April 2002 to examine what the participants termed "museum malaise." Having praised house museums as "the bedrock of the American preservation movement," Richard Moe, president of the National Trust said, "The current crop of house museums suffers from a distressing sameness." 
Other participants complained that house museums were too focused on dead, rich white guys and that they shelter "too damn many spinning wheels."
Given ferment in the field, what can we learn from these houses today?
A visit to five historic house museums in Connecticut shows that while you can still find tales about men -- iconic figures like George Washington and Nathan Hale -- historians and community volunteers are creating fresh programs to attract new audiences, vignettes drawn from history studied from the bottom up.
"Everyone you read about in traditional history books depended on people who never made it into those same history books," said Diane Cameron, a historian and researcher with a particular interest in the African-Americans who lived and worked at the three houses comprising the Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum in Wethersfield.
For seven years Ms. Cameron has scoured the scanty records to bring to life these formerly unnoticed people. She and her colleagues have learned enough to put together a tour at Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum that focuses on the lives of 15 different African-Americans in Wethersfield.
"We want to show the enslaved as more than tools," said Ms. Cameron, "to show them as people essential to the houses, the economy, the community, the changing culture, people with their own identities and cultures that helped them survive in new and unimaginable circumstances."
The vigor of the colonial revival movement in the early 20th century helped create today's Webb-Deane-Stevens Museum, where Jennifer Eifrig is the director and Donna Keith Baron is the curator.
In May of 1781, George Washington really did sleep at the Webb House, and you can see the room he stayed in, complete with the wallpaper that was put up in anticipation of his visit.
Washington and his entourage met with the French general Rochambeau, and the two generals and their aides planned the campaign that ended with the defeat of Lord Cornwallis at Yorktown, Va., in October 1781. 
This sort of iconic history was irresistible to the people and organizations driving house restorations a century ago. Wallace Nutting, a pioneer figure in house restoration and other antiquarian pursuits, bought the Webb House in 1914.
The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America in Connecticut bought it from Nutting and later acquired the other two houses that make up the complex.
The Webb House was built in 1752 by Joseph Webb Sr., a Wethersfield merchant who died in 1761, leaving a wife, Mehitabel, six children and a very tangled estate. The widow Webb sought the assistance of Silas Deane, a newly minted lawyer who straightened out her affairs and then married her.
In 1766, Deane built a new house adjacent to the Webb House, a dwelling from which he was very often absent during the years of the American Revolution.
Silas Deane represented Connecticut in both the first and second Continental Congresses, and in 1776 became America's first accredited diplomat, working with Benjamin Franklin and Richard Lee to extract badly needed money and supplies from the French government.
Hubris and carelessness with his accounts apparently brought Deane down. He somehow antagonized the powerful Lee family of Virginia. Rumors about his deployment of funds began to circulate, and letters purportedly written by Deane advocating surrender to the British were published.
Despised as a traitor, Silas Deane died in 1789. In 1842 Congress exonerated him and made partial reparations to his heirs.
The Stevens part of the Webb-Deane-Stevens museum reflects no such skulduggery or feats of derring-do. Isaac Stevens was an up-and-coming saddler, born in Glastonbury Conn., who approached the merchant-class Webb family sometime in 1788 and asked if they would like to sell the building lot next to their house.
Cash in hand prevailed over social snobbery, and Stevens got to build his dream house. He and his descendants lived in the house, a typical late 18th-century Connecticut center hall structure, until 1957.
The Colonial Dames then acquired the house, along with all the things the family had accumulated for nearly two centuries.

Notable Boarders
The Hale Homestead in Coventry, Conn., belongs to the Antiquarian & Landmarks Society, a Hartford group founded in 1936 to "preserve historic properties for the benefit of the people of Connecticut."
Nathan Hale is a dead, white male; there is no doubt about that. The British hanged him as a spy on Sept. 22, 1776, in New York City, after he volunteered to venture behind enemy lines to see what intelligence he could gather.
Did he really say, "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country?"
An English officer named Montresor was on the spot for the execution and reported that he did.
Hale never lived in the buildings that comprise the Hale Homestead in Coventry, but that does not stop 5,000 people a year from making a pilgrimage to the site. 
"This house was built by Deacon Richard Hale, Nathan's father in 1776, the same year Nathan was working for George Washington as a military scout," said Desiree Mobed, the Homestead's site administrator.
But there is plenty of Nathan at the Hale Homestead. Here you can see his fowling piece hanging above a fireplace. You can also gaze at his signature and a little note he made in the family bible. Upstairs there is a full-length silhouette of a young man incised on the back of an 18th-century door that may be of Nathan Hale. He had seven brothers, five of whom served in the Revolution, so it is impossible to be sure. One of Ms. Mobed's favorite stories about Hale reveals that even though he was only 21 when he was executed, he had a full life.
"After he graduated from Yale he was teaching school in New London Conn.," Ms. Mobed said. "In addition to his paid duties teaching boys he began a school for girls that started at 5:30 in the morning. This was two hours before the boys classes began, and two hours before the girls had to start their day's chores around the house and farm."
Hale not only had the courage to face the hangman with a quote that made him famous forever, he also had the guts to go against the prevailing educational notions of his day that girls did not need book learning.
A New Haven patent lawyer and antiquary named George Dudley Seymour bought the Hale property in 1914. He spent many years and many dollars restoring the Hale Homestead and buying the land around it.
Today, the Hale Homestead is in the middle of a 500-acre tract called the Hale Forest, a Connecticut State Park, which means visitors can get a real taste of what life on an 18th-century farm was like.
"People are always amazed at how little stuff our ancestors had," Ms. Mobed said, "particularly the school children."
The Hale Homestead offers a series of what it calls colonial life ways programs for school and scouting groups. These programs give children a taste of the lifestyles, crafts, foods and work habits on a prosperous country farm in the 18th-century.

A Greek Influence
The Solomon Rockwell house in Winsted, a handsome structure built in 1813 in the prevailing Greek Revival style, typifies the kind of lightly endowed house museum that is run by dedicated volunteers.
The Rockwell House is maintained by the Winchester Historical Society, whose president is William P. Weber, and it shelters some surprising holdings. There is a trove of Civil War memorabilia including weapons, uniforms, letters and other documents that genealogy buffs are free to peruse. On the grounds there is an architecturally significant outhouse built in the full Greek Revival style with columns and other classical details.
The Rockwell House owns a collection of nine 19th-century family portraits, including a cache by the well-known itinerant limner Erastus Salisbury Field. In folk art circles, Field is a big name. He is much collected and his paintings fetch major prices.
In April of 1833, Field painted his way through the contiguous towns of Winsted, Winchester Center and Torrington, polishing off a total of 30 portraits in a two-month sojourn. The Field portraits in the Rockwell House are likenesses of Riley Whiting, his wife, Urania Hoadley Whiting, and several of their children. 
Riley Whiting was a clockmaker, a significant figure at the beginning of the Industrial Revolution. Whiting and other Connecticut clockmakers like Silas Hoadley, Seth Thomas and Eli Terry successfully devised and mass-produced wooden works clocks, beginning at the turn of the 19th century.
This invention brought the price of fairly accurate time keeping down from $60 to $5, just in time for the Industrial Revolution. This was when men and women and boys and girls had to get up at an appointed hour and get to the mill on time or risk dismissal.

Folk Traditions
Connecticut houses built before the American Revolution fall into the vernacular or folk category, rather than deriving from academic architecture.
Vernacular architecture, wrote James Deetz and Patricia Scott Deetz in "The Times of Their Lives, Life, Love and Death In Plymouth Colony," does not come from plans, but is the idea of what a house should be like. This idea is carried in the minds of the people and passed down by word of mouth and example.
In the Plymouth Colony, and in the Connecticut Colony of the 17th and early 18th centuries as well, the archetypal house was the hall-and-parlor house, an idea brought by the settlers from England, where it had been the most common form since the Middle Ages.
As the name states, a hall-and-parlor house generally had two first-floor rooms between a centrally placed chimney, with a fireplace in each. Second-story rooms reflected the plan of the first, each named after the room situated beneath it: hall chamber and parlor chamber.
If an addition was made to this basic plan, it was almost always a third room or lean-to built onto the back of the house, which was used as a kitchen.
In the 17th century, homes were meagerly furnished, by today's standards. Kevin Sweeney, a furniture historian, plumbed the probate inventories of the town of Wethersfield to document exactly what people did own in the way of furniture and accessories.
In 1639, Mr. Sweeney found, Richard Gyldersly of Wethersfield owned two beds, one chest, a box, a small cupboard, a table, a few chairs and some stools. The cupboard held some pewter and brass plates while a few pieces of iron cooking equipment were grouped around the fireplace. These sparse holdings were typical of the times.
One hundred years later a middle class was emerging and consumerism was on the rise. By the late 18th century, an average inventory included three beds, two sets of six chairs each, three to four chests, three or four tables, looking glasses, stands, costly forms like high chests of drawers and desks with bookcases, even tall case clocks with brass works.

Let There Be Preservation!
"Home is the definition of God," Emily Dickinson wrote in an 1879 letter, only three years after the Centennial exhibitions of 1876, a nationwide jamboree that celebrated the American Revolution of 1776 and jump-started an abiding interest in old houses and the people who lived in them.
This was the beginning of historic preservation in the United States, a grass-roots movement that saved hundreds of houses, thousands of artifacts and has helped historians and interested citizens understand the meaning of home across the centuries.
It is a rare Connecticut town that does not proudly support a historical society, frequently quartered in a house built in the 17th, 18th or 19th century.

Other items include: a rocking horse, circa 1805, at the Rockwell house in Winsted; fire buckets at the Stevens house that bear the owner's name; a daybed at the Deane house; and a Windsor chair designed for writing, circa 1790, at the Hale house in Coventry. HEADLINE: Bookkeepers 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DALEY 

 BODY:
"I'LL tell you something," Bill Goring said. He lowered his voice. "Books breed when you're not there. Leave any two books together in a room, and suddenly there are more of them."
 He estimates that he has probably 10,000 books in the house in Torrington that he shares with his wife, Debby, a medical secretary. 
 "I'm a bookseller," he said. "A perfect occupation for me." 
He is a "left-over hippie," he says, so his library is an esoteric collection of books about politics, the occult, religion, philosophy, combat, weaponry, socialism, and anarchy. He tries to keep them in the library, but they are also on shelves in rooms all over the house and in piles on tables and floor and chairs. "It's a big house," he said.
A not-so-big three-bedroom house in Guilford is home to Nona and Kent Bloomer. He is an author, an architect, and a professor at Yale. She works as a reference librarian at the Guilford public library. Together they own too many books. "We're not very disciplined," she said. "They're in piles all over the house. When we have people over, I have to clear off the dining room table so we can eat."
What to do with the books you own is a sweet problem. Cormac O'Malley is a lawyer who splits his 4,000-book library between his Manhattan apartment and his home on the water in Stonington Borough. 
"I keep all the history here in Connecticut," he said, "and the art stuff, I keep in New York." 
What about books that don't really fit in either category? When his wife, Moira, couldn't find a book entitled "Real Lace," she thought it was lost and bought a replacement.
"You should have asked me," her husband told her. "I knew exactly where it was." He walked over and pulled it off the shelf. "Right here in the Irish-American history section."
If the O'Malleys are challenged with 4,000 books, consider the Connerys: they have over 16,000. 
"A book becomes part of you," said Donald Connery, "and it's impossible to part with one." 
When the Connerys were married in 1950, they each had dozens of books. Then, over the years, he was a foreign correspondent, an author, a legal consultant. She was a special education teacher, a firefighter, and an emergency medical technician. They read books on foreign countries, international affairs, biographies, psychological studies, travelogues, books on sports, volumes of poetry, best-sellers, classics and junky paperbacks. They stored them on shelves, under tables, in boxes in their attics and basements and bedrooms -- and when they moved to their farm in Kent 30 years ago, they kept them in boxes in the barn.
But the tall fieldstone silo stood empty; a solid waste of space, they decided. In 1988, with the help of their son Eric, an architect, the Connerys created a lighthouse of a library, three stories tall, with a staircase spiraling through the center. Then they arranged their books on the shelves by subject matter. First floor: magazines, baseball, media childhood books, economics Broadway; second floor: Russia, Japan, China, India, Europe and American history; third floor: fiction and biographies.
Everybody one has a system. Leslie Singer and Ron Hook live with their two children in Westport in a big house stuffed with beautiful things and hundreds of books. "I tried to categorize them," said Ms. Singer, a designer of women's accessories. "And there is a sort of order to it all. Biographies here, art books there. Books that I use for work are in my studio, but really the books are arranged for the enjoyment of whoever's in the house."
This means a small stack of books carefully chosen for the guest room, according to who will be their weekend guests. It means changing the order of the art books displayed under the glass coffee table and keeping the children's books at a convenient height for six-year-old Andrew and eight-year-old Melina. "I rotate books to keep up with what we're doing or what people are talking about," she said. "Cookbooks, however, are Ron's department."
Ms. Singer's husband, Ron Hook, is a professional chef, formerly of the Doral Saturnia Spa in Miami, so the kitchen is his personal library, as well as his office and where he teaches cooking classes like "Survival Cooking for College Freshman" and private lessons for the more adventurous. Mr. Hook's favorite cookbooks and books and articles on culinary trends are piled up on the counter. Basics and the exotic are shelved in the kitchen bookcase.
Inglis Hale is a Woodbury antiques dealer. Her home is filled with French bowls, silver candlesticks, glass platters and deep-hued vases. Her primary bookcase is an unused staircase. "The encyclopedias are at the top of the stairs. You know, because encyclopedias are lofty. Then come the classics, which I like to reread, and then further down the stairs are a few books on relationships and self-improvement, and the bottom is chock full of quick reference and how-to books -- books I refer to all the time."
Craig Nelson confesses that his books are out of control. Mr. Nelson lives in Warren with his wife, Sandy, and their three children. They built the house about four years ago, and there is a formal library, but books are all over the house. .
His collection is an eclectic reference library on everything from Freemasonry to bird-watching, archaeology, cooking and railroads. It's information he craves, not books; so he has a lot of things that aren't books. There are town brochures and political pamphlets, stapled-together pages, articles from magazines, printed-up sermons, oversized books of maps and tiny paperbacks.
Much of it doesn't fit nicely onto bookshelves, so things are in drawers and file cabinets and boxes and they are piled and stacked and spread out on nearly every available flat surface of the house.
Improbably, he says he knows exactly where everything is. Local schoolchildren often use his library, but he accompanies them through the house because often it is only he who can find what they need. "And I am concerned they won't put it back where it belongs," he said, "because it doesn't look like there's a system -- but there is."
An antiques collector and dealer by trade -- he owns and manages the Village Barn and Gallery in New Preston -- he needs endless bits of information, dates and history.
"I use the Internet as much as I can," he said, "but nothing can take the place of a book. I like that printed piece of paper." Then he smiled and added:" And poetry. I have to read poetry from a book. You can't read poetry off a computer screen!"
Although some makeshift libraries, like Ms. Hale's staircase and Ms. Bloomer's dining room table, are inventions of accident or necessity, some are by design. David Paletsky, of David Paletsy Real Estate in Litchfield, says that he sees a decline in formal libraries in the houses that are selling today. 
"There may be a room which is designated as an office," he said, "but people change rooms to suit the way they live. They would rather create 'book areas' in many rooms rather than have all the books in one place."
M. J. Rose, author of, most recently, a suspense novel called "Flesh Tones," once rented a charming house in Greenwich, but oddly, there was no wall between the homely utilitarian kitchen and the living room. "So we built a bookcase to divide the space," she said. "It served a dual purpose, and we could take it with us when we moved."
Books on shelves, books stacked on the floor, books in baskets and leather boxes: they make a room warm and inviting. Decorators know this and make use of books in their work. 
"We often buy books by the yard to fill walls of bookcases," saidMary Foley, an interior designer in Bethel, "but we also create tableaus, like a still life, on tabletops and counters and shelves: a book, a silver bowl, a heavy round glass votive or a tiny vase of flowers. It's pretty to look at, and it's temporary. It looks like someone is using it, living there."
But what to do with books you have no room for? Books you read and didn't like or used and don't need? Duplicates? Besides the obvious quick-remedies like Goodwill, local libraries, and the book-exchange racks at the train station, book-lovers are getting inventive.
Mr. Nelson found a bookseller who will give him store credit for books for which he has no use. "It works for both of us," Mr. Nelson said.
Louis Mackall, an architect, created the Joshua Cove Book Club, an informal book exchange among the people who work in his Guilford office and a small circle of friends.
For book-lovers everywhere, there is www.BookCrossing.com, an ambitious book-exchange program, kind of like sport fishing, where people can "read and release" a favorite book into the wild. First register the book with www.bookcrossing.com and then release it for someone else to read by leavingit in a conspicuous spot, like a park bench, a restaurant or a coffee shop.
That concept doesn't work for everybody. 
"Oh, you can't get rid of books," Nona Bloomer said. "That's sacrilegious."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A silo, top, on Donald Connery's land in Kent has been converted into a library, holding 16,000 books. Bill Goring, above, says he has about 10,000 books in his Torrington house.; Ron Hook, top, and Leslie Singer use the stack method to store their books in their Westport home. That method includes putting cookbooks on the kitchen countertop and, middle, miniature books in the guest bathroom. Bottom, inside the Connery's silo library. (Photographs by Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)(pg. 11); Inglis Hale in her Westport home, where an unused staircase holds books. She keeps the encyclopedias at the top, because they are "lofty." (C. M. Glover for The New York Times)(pg. 10)
