HEADLINE: A Number Story 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
PERHAPS a remedial mathematics course would have helped. Or a sharper look at current events.
 Whatever the solution, the situation is this: New Jersey's public school enrollment is soaring at a rate even the state Department of Education did not predict when it last tallied the numbers in 1998. And with those numbers still growing and no increase in state aid this year, the concerns over crowded classrooms, a shortage of adequate staff and steeper property tax bills are putting the problems in sharper relief. 
 The numbers tell the story:
*When schools opened in Wayne Township this month, there were 8,701 students -- 2,100 more pupils than the suburban community had only seven years ago -- clamoring at the doors. 
*In Greenwich Township, in Warren County, an area that is quickly being transformed from a rural area into a suburb, there were about 350 students in kindergarten through eighth grade six years ago, far fewer than the 900 enrolled today. The school population is growing so rapidly that a week after a new school opened last year, ground was broken on an addition that would double its size.
*In Cherry Hill, where the number of students rose to 11,349 this fall from 10,245 in September 1997, a committee of educators and parents met all summer to figure out how to best cope with the growth in a district where numbers are expected to reach 12,000 in the next few years. Only three years ago, the district took a school building it had converted into administrative offices in the early 1980's and reopened it as a middle school.
*In Washington Township, Mercer County, voters approved a bond issue in 2001 to build a high school in the district, which now sends its students to nearby Lawrence High School. The number of students in elementary and middle school is 1,419, and growing by a rate of 12 to 13 percent a year.
*In Evesham Township -- where the student population in elementary and middle school has grown by 200 students a year for 12 years and is now at 5,500 -- several trailers were used as classrooms until a new school and additions were approved in 1999.
This year, the state estimated the number of public school students at 1,367,431, a jump of more than 30,000 from the 2001-2 school year and up more than 300,000 from 1989.
For the most part, the numbers seem to be going up in the state's suburban districts, where additions as well as entirely new schools are being built, and in the Abbott districts -- the 30 poorest districts -- where enrollment went to 288,318 in 2001 from 278,966 in 1997.
In July 1998, the state Department of Education predicted that enrollment would peak during the 2003-4 school years with 1,196,939 students and that by 2007, that number would drop to about 1.1 million.
"Obviously we're dramatically above those numbers now," said Rich Vespucci, a spokesman for the department. "Those projections are not holding. It's going up 20,000 to 30,000 students a year."
At one time, educators did not think the student population would rise beyond 1.4 million, Mr. Vespucci said. "Obviously if it keeps going like this, we'll exceed 1.4 million. In a state like New Jersey, there are so many variables and factors."
For one thing, there is the boomer echo. The baby boomers were born from 1946 and 1964, overwhelming the nation's schools in the 1950's and 60's. Today, their children are crowding those same hallways and filling new classrooms.
But there is much more. The biggest factor in underestimating the upswing was immigration. Dr. James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, noting that from 1990 to 2000, the state saw a net gain of 400,000 immigrants.
"That's where the projections went awry," Dr. Hughes said.
For now, Dr. Hughes sees the numbers starting to level off -- perhaps with some ups and downs -- and no drastic decline as in the late 1970's and early 80's that led to the closing of many schools.
While the entire state has been affected by immigration, several individual districts have seen their numbers rise because of new housing developments, a turnover of homes from empty nesters to families with children, and movement out of New York and Philadelphia.
Sarah Weissman, who consults with more than 30 districts in the state to help them project enrollment figures, says schools can be affected by new industry moving in the area or a "reputation bump" after favorable reports come out about a district.
Like Dr. Hughes, Ms. Weissman does not see a sharp decline in the number of students in the near future, but she does say that high school enrollment should peak in 2007 or 2008 and then begin to level off or slightly decline.
"The problem every community discusses is how to accommodate this birth peak and not overbuild," she said.
Many districts throughout the state are grappling with that costly calculation right now. Last Tuesday, voters approved $427 million in proposed spending for new construction, additions and renovations -- of which about 25 percent will be paid by the state. In the 27 districts where school spending proposals were being considered, 85 percent of the referendums passed. Since 2000, voters in New Jersey have approved more than $2.72 billion in school bond issues. In 2001, $970 million was approved by voters for school building projects -- representing a significant upswing from 1997 and 1998 when less than $500 million was approved in each of those years. In addition to the money approved last week, voters had already passed $708 million in bond referendums so far this year.
"One of our main concerns is that we don't overbuild," said Paul Harren, the superintendent in Washington Township Public Schools, in Mercer County.
Nonetheless, voters there last December approved a bond issue to build its own high school rather than continue to send students out of district. The high school will open in 2004 in a district that has a total of 1,737 students, with a steady growth of 12 to 13 percent a year.
Of course, like many other educators, Mr. Harren would like more help from the state to deal with the rapid growth.
"We could use a little more understanding in terms of state aid," he said. "It really leaves the burden to the local community."
The situation was so acute in Greenwich Township in Warren County that in December 2000, voters were asked to approve a bond issue for an addition on a school that was still under construction. The Greenwich School opened last September, and ground was broken on the addition one week later.
The district -- which is attracting parents who work in the state's pharmaceutical and software industries as well as those commuting to Manhattan -- has about 900 children in kindergarten through eighth grade and expects the student population to increase by about 300 over the next four years, said the superintendent, Dr. Kevin Brennan.
"It's been very concentrated enrollment growth," said Dr. Brennan. "We've gone as high as 28 to 29 students in a classroom."
The average size is now between 24 and 25, and he hopes to take that to the low 20's when the addition opens next fall.
"It's a horrendous situation for the local taxpayer," Dr. Brennan said. "People say, 'We can only pay so much.' It's a practical issue."
Dr. Brennan, who has been superintendent in Greenwich Township for seven years, put it this way: "It's overwhelming. You drive down the street in the morning, and in the evening there would be houses framed."
Traci King, president of the Parent Teacher Organization in the district, has three children in the schools there and has also witnessed the explosive growth over the past five years.
"You could see the influx of people moving into our community," Ms. King said.
She criticized the state government for freezing state aid at a time when student enrollment was soaring. "You go to the school and there are massive amounts of kids," she said. "The children are the ones who really get hurt by this."
The creeping size of classes has become a thorny issues in many suburban school districts in recent years. And with school budgets stagnant, many districts have had to reduce the number of teachers and classroom aides, resulting in larger classes.
"Right now, with the state budget situation, districts are in a tight bind in being able to afford staff," said Steve Wollmer, a spokesman for the New Jersey Education Association. "Teaching should never be an issue of crowd control."
That is precisely what happened in Haddonfield, in South Jersey, this summer, when parents went to the Board of Education after learning that fifth-grade classes in two schools would have 27 students in a classroom.
According to Dr. Joseph Serico, the assistant superintendent there, enrollment his district has risen to 2,300 students this year from 1,770 students in 1991.
For now the district is in the final stages of completing additions and renovations to its schools after passing a $26 million bond issue two years ago. In addition, the district has brought in a part-time teacher for math so that students can be broken into groups and a language arts specialist to help in the larger classes.
"I think obviously the best thing is small class sizes," said Molly Webb, a parent in the district with a fifth-grade child. 
But Ms. Webb, herself a former teacher, says she thinks it is possible to teach effectively in the higher elementary grades with slightly larger numbers if the students are divided into learning groups. 
"You need strong classroom management," she said.
There is no mystery why some districts are swelling. When a district has a good reputation, people want to be there. In Wayne Township, for example, enrollment has gone up by about 300 students a year for the past seven years for a current total of 8,701 students. 
"People want to come here," said Dr. Richard Linkh, the superintendent, noting that by 2007 he expects 10,000 students. "The real draw is the school system."
Like many districts, Wayne found itself closing school buildings in the early 1980's, and by 1989, the school population was under 6,000. Now the district has put additions on buildings and re-opened one of the closed schools that was being used for office space.
At this point, Dr. Linkh believes growth will level off by about 2010.
Andrew McIlvaine, a former president of school board in Cherry Hill, identified the problem there and in many districts as the "double whammy."
"We have increasing enrollment and aging facilities," said Mr. McIlvaine. "These problems are common to suburban schools in New Jersey."
In Cherry Hill, where the average building age is 35, the issue is not only a shortage of space but also a need to upgrade facilities to keep up with technology.
For now, there is one committee recommendation on the table there to open a third high school that could be a magnet school or a school that all students attend during some part of their high school years by creating flexible spaces to be used for different activities.
Districts going through dramatic enrollment increases will find that the biggest battle is over money for teachers as well as buildings. As Edwina Lee, executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, said, schools in the state are "reeling" from the current budget crunch even as they continue to face a growing number of students.
"We do everything before we impact the classroom, but ultimately the classroom will be affected," she said. "Dollars are just not available at the magnitude we need to do the job. It's extremely tough right now. We promise a free public education to all who show up at our door, but it doesn't mean we're prepared."

Schools Were 'Caught by Surprise'
IT is extremely difficult to forecast school enrollment. Just ask James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers.
Indeed, Dr. James said that the baby boomers -- the people born from 1946 to 1964 who are now 38 to 56 years old -- "caught everybody by surprise."
From 1965 to 1976, birth rates declined, in large part because of birth control, Dr. Hughes explained. In addition, more women began entering the work force and postponing childbirth. In 1957, he explained, an average woman had 3.8 children in this country, but by 1976 that number dropped to 1.7 children.
Then came 1977, and the baby boom echo began. It is not that boomers had so many children, but rather there were a lot of people in their child-producing years at the same time. The schools are now crowded with those children -- along with a large immigrant population that was not anticipated.
In New Jersey, 1.5 million of the state's 8.4 million people are foreign born. From 1990 to 2000, about 400,000 immigrants moved to New Jersey, and first-generation immigrants tend to have a higher birth rate.
But as Dr. Hughes sees it, the school-age population should begin to level off through this decade. "We don't expect the dramatic highs and lows that were seen in our state or the country since 1946."
"The cycles are being muted," he added. "The boom was caused by 15 years of trauma -- Depression and World War II."
Yet while models and patterns suggest that growth is leveling, it is not always easy for districts to predict exact numbers because there is no way of knowing how many empty nesters may sell their homes in a given year, he said.
Rather, he said, there is a better fix on where "the growth zones" are, and that should lead to more accurate predictions.
"There's always some uncertainty," he said. "We can probably do a better job than forecasting the weather."

Most Districts O.K. Projects
DESPITE an economy that is struggling, voters around the state approved 85 percent of the 27 school construction proposals placed before them last week, amounting to $427 million in spending, according to the New Jersey School Boards Association.
"Usually the economy has an impact, so we were happy to see the level of support remained consistent," said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the association. "I think the public understands enrollment has increased and schools are operating at capacity."
Since 2000, voters have approved more than $2.72 billion in new construction, renovations and additions. In the past two years, 75 percent of the bond issues considered by the voters have passed.
Members of the School Boards Association have said that a major factor in the passage rate is the Facilities Act passed in 2000, which provided state money for construction.
Here are some of the proposals voted on last Tuesday:
*In Bogota, Bergen County, voters approved $13 million for additions and renovations to two elementary schools. Of that, $3.8 million will be financed by the state.
*In Spotswood, Middlesex County, voters approved more than $15 million for additions and renovations, of which the state will pay $5.4 million.
*In Millburn Township, Essex County, voters approved $18 million for additions and renovations at seven schools, but rejected spending more than $1.3 million to install a synthetic surface on the high school athletic field.
*In Washington Township, Burlington County, voters rejected a $5.6 million proposal to build a new elementary school that would have included community multipurpose space.
There is another round of school bond referendums scheduled for December.

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: Studios: Many Plans, a Few Completions 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
IN Hollywood on the Hudson, studio development projects have been as ephemeral as images on a screen.
 There seems to be agreement that New York could use more studios. "You've got to keep productions here after the location shooting is done," said Andrew Stern, a senior vice president of the city's Economic Development Corporation specializing in media and entertainment projects. "Large, purpose-built modern stages are one of the missing links in the chain." 
 But the business is so transient -- even a phenomenon like "The Sopranos" operates on a year-to-year basis -- that developers have been unable to offer lenders the assurance of long-term tenants. Until recently, much of the talk about building studios has been just that. 
"There have been so many projects that have come and gone," said Bice C. Wilson of Meridian Design Associates, architects of studio projects that have come and gone, that may be coming and that have just arrived. "Studios look like a cool thing to do. But they don't make a lot of money."
Given the skepticism about studio ballyhoo, David S. Steiner and Douglas C. Steiner of the Steiner Equities Group have kept a fairly low public profile even while driving hundreds of pilings at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for the first of two buildings in their 11-stage Steiner Studios project. They see no advantage in raising expectations yet. "Most people's acceptance of the realization of a project is when the walls are up," said Lou Madigan, president of Steiner Studios. That should occur by the end of the year, he said, with the first stages available in late 2003.
What construction there has been usually involves reclaiming existing spaces for specific shows, rather than a general tenancy. On Sept. 18, for instance, CNN inaugurated its new street-level studio for the program "American Morning with Paula Zahn" within a former bank branch at the base of the Time & Life Building, on the Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street.
"CNN's always had a big presence here but I think it's great to have a new studio," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told Ms. Zahn at the start of the show, before he snipped a ribbon with oversized scissors.
There may be a few more ribbons to snip in coming years. CNN will build studios at AOL Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle for "NewsNight with Aaron Brown" and "Lou Dobbs Moneyline," designed by Kostow Greenwood Architects, who are also working on a renovation of NBC space at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
The Hearst Corporation may build a studio in the new headquarters it is planning at Eighth Avenue and 57th Street, which could be used by any of its 29 television stations as a New York location.
And Meridian Design is working on revised plans for the $350 million Studio City New York on 11th Avenue, between 44th and 45th Streets. This 15-story, 700,000-square-foot structure would have five permanent studios. More than half the building could be used as production support space, including offices. Richard Benowitz is the managing general partner of a development group that includes Lehman Brothers, Hines, Pacifica Venture Partners and the Picket-Benowitz Group.
As if to underscore the vicissitudes of studio development, however, on the same day the mayor cut the ribbon for CNN, the Economic Development Corporation cut off talks with investors planning studios at the former Navy home port on the Stapleton waterfront in Staten Island. The investors, including the actor Danny Aiello, Marlowe R. Walker and Robert E. DiMilia, had already converted a vast refrigeration shed at the home port -- formerly used by Arnie's Bagelicious Bagels -- into a 110-by-120-foot sound stage where the independent movie "Max and Grace" is being filmed. Recognizing that studios alone would not be profitable, the investors envisioned a larger complex, designed by Bastien & Associates.
"Our proposal is for hotels, shops, marinas, office space and restaurants to make money and support the studios," Mr. Aiello said as he led a tour of the sound stage a day before the city effectively upended the plans. Subsidized this way, he said, Stapleton could compete with productions going to nonunionized states and Canada. "One of my dreams," Mr. Aiello said, "is to relocate production back where it belongs."
The partners had secured a six-month occupancy permit for two buildings on the final day of the Giuliani administration. They said they spent $2 million to build the first studio, hoping this would persuade city officials to lengthen their term and expand their control of the site. The occupancy permit was extended under the Bloomberg administration but will lapse on Oct. 31, effectively evicting Mr. Aiello's group.
The city said only that it had ended discussions "based on information received from the Department of Investigation with respect to a participant in the negotiations." Mr. Walker volunteered in an interview that one of his sons, Marlowe R. Walker 3rd, had been convicted of conspiracy to commit stock fraud, while insisting that his son was not a partner in or owner of the project.
Instead, he and Mr. Aiello asserted that city officials were seeking an excuse to remove them from involvement in the home port. They said last week that they still held out the hope of enticing a Paramount movie production to Stapleton Studios before the October deadline and that its arrival might persuade city officials to extend their term. But at best, Mr. Aiello conceded, "We're in maybe a limbo stage."
City officials had no further comment.
WHETHER their particular development formula would have made economic sense may never be tested. But it acknowledged the inability of studios themselves to attract conventional real estate financing.
The Steiners, based in Roseland, N.J., are getting around this problem by paying for their $150 million development up front and getting financing later, Mr. Madigan said. They are leasing the 15-acre site for 70 years from the Brooklyn Navy Yard Corporation at a rate that steps up over time to $5 a square foot. The city is committed to making $28 million in road, sewer and other infrastructure improvements, which would have to be made in any case to attract large-scale development to the 264-acre yard.
Foundation work began in August 2001, was halted Sept. 11 and resumed in March, having survived a change in mayoral administrations and opposition from the Hasidic community of Williamsburg, which worries about the potentially corrupting influence of a movie studio in its midst.
The first structure is to have 285,000 square feet of space and six studios; one of which, at 27,000 square feet, is to be the largest sound stage in the Northeast, Mr. Madigan said. (That distinction is currently held by Stage E, the 26,000-square foot "Big House" at Kaufman Astoria Studios in Astoria, Queens.) The second building, which is to be developed a year or two later with 200,000 square feet of space, is to have five studios, one with 42,000 square feet, the largest outside Hollywood.
Design duties have been divided between Richard Dattner & Partners for the exteriors and Dennis Janson of the Janson Design Group for the studios themselves.
Mr. Madigan's vision extends beyond the four walls of the studio buildings and the acreage he already leases. He pictures the old houses on the grounds as writers' bungalows, the landmark Naval Hospital and Surgeon's House as movie sets. "It begs to be a back lot," he said.
Eric Deutsch, president of the Navy Yard Corporation, said of the Steiner project that "it creates a whole new economic dynamic" for the yard. Another tenant, the Hispanic Information and Telecommunications Network, is planning to build two small studios in an existing building, he said.
"The Navy Yard provides a secure environment where you can begin to replicate the kind of studio lot that people in production are used to in Los Angeles," Mr. Deutsch said. "Once you're in Manhattan, you don't have the studio lot feel to it."
Not for want of trying. Drawings by Meridian Design for Studio City show a small back lot -- a New York street scene -- on the one-acre ninth-floor roof deck overlooking Clinton. Below would be studios ranging from 10,000 to 17,000 square feet.
All told, permanent studios would take up only one-tenth of the floor area in the building, which the architect, Mr. Wilson, likened to a vertical studio lot. More than half the building, 400,000 square feet, could be offices. "We'll be able to lease a good amount of space for a long term to a Triple A tenant," said the developer, Mr. Benowitz. "We don't need the studios leased long-term in order to get a shovel in the ground, and that's what makes us workable."
Four years ago, Mr. Benowitz was planning the Hudson River Studios on the roof of the three-block-long St. John's Center at West and Houston Streets -- until tenants there balked at the prospect of construction overhead. After that fell through, the Economic Development Corporation awarded a 92,000-square-foot site in Clinton to the Picket-Benowitz Group and its partners. For zoning purposes, the city-owned property is being subdivided into a lot that will include the studio project and Public School 51-Intermediate School 51 at 520 West 45th Street. As part of their deal with the city, the developers are to build a new gymnasium and install new windows and air-conditioning in the old school building.
What the city likes about the Studio City project is that it combines every phase of production under one roof, said Robert Balder, executive vice president for real estate development at the Economic Development Corporation. "It's a very compelling building type," he said.
The architects of Studio City, Meridian Design, seem to be adept at squeezing lots of things into limited space.
They were responsible for shoehorning two CNN studios into the Time & Life Building, working with Guy Pepper of CNN. The 2,100-square-foot studio for "American Morning" has glass walls that overlook the Avenue of the Americas, Radio City Music Hall and William Crovello's "Cubed Curve" sculpture on the Time & Life plaza. There is also a 1,100-square-foot studio for "Connie Chung Tonight."
Walter Isaacson, the chairman and chief executive of the CNN News Group, promoted the studio idea while he was editorial director of Time Inc. "It's not just symbolism," he said. "It allows the journalists at the Time & Life Building to be more involved with the shows we do on CNN."
It also gives Ms. Zahn's program the same window on New York that the competition already exploits. "You need a first-class, lively, exciting facility to say, 'We're a newsy alternative to broadcast morning shows,' " Mr. Isaacson said. "It's harder to do that out of the old windowless studio. You want the excitement that comes from being eye level with real people."
This was not as easily said as done. To begin with, there was a column in the middle of the space. To remove it, a 36-inch steel girder had to be added above the ceiling and a 52-inch girder below the floor. Another challenge was posed by vibrations from the Sixth Avenue subway. The answer was to isolate the concrete floor slab on resin-hardened fiberglass pads.
And the walls are far more complex than they look: panels of eight-layered laminated glass, two-and-a-half inches thick, each weighing 3,000 pounds and fabricated in Germany, set precisely in openings tilted 7 degrees to avoid reflection. Between these panels and the exterior curtain wall is a cavity almost five feet wide filled with "zipper" signs and television monitors.
BECAUSE this space acts as a giant heat trap, it has to be aggressively air-conditioned. In fact, anyone standing in the cavity practically has to shout to be heard over the whoosh of the rapidly moving air, which can easily pick up the corner of one's jacket. There are also heat registers under the curtain wall that can be used to prevent condensation, which would fog the view from the studio to the street.
There was no way to fit in a control room, so that remains in the existing CNN center at 5 Penn Plaza, meaning that the Time & Life studio is "almost a permanent remote," said Antonio Argibay of Meridian.
High-tech as it may be, the CNN project actually honors a tradition going back to the earliest days of filmmaking, in which studios were carved out of existing buildings.
For example, Chelsea Television Studios at 221 West 26th Street, home of "Ricki Lake," "Judge Hatchett" and "Change of Heart," is descended from a studio that Adolph Zukor created out of an armory in 1914. It has been owned since 1989 by All Mobile Video. A new facade is being installed by Garden State Brickface.
"There is a need for this type of operation," said Eric Duke, president of All Mobile Video, "but it's very hard to duplicate what we have with the economics of Manhattan real estate. You'll look at a studio 40 feet high, 100 by 100 feet, and say, 'How many apartments could we fit in this space?' " (The answer is about four.)
All Mobile has acquired the former Unitel Video studios at 433 West 53rd Street and 515 West 57th Street and briefly held Unitel's leasehold in a studio at Ninth Avenue and 55th Street owned by the Educational Broadcasting Corporation. That is being torn down to make way for the Joan Weill Center for Dance to be built by the Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation.
Silvercup Studios in Long Island City, Queens -- a reincarnated bakery and steel factory that is home to "The Sopranos," "Sex and the City" and "Queens Supreme" -- planned a new studio on the waterfront below the Queensboro Bridge, as part of a project in which it would have restored the landmark headquarters of the New York Architectural Terra Cotta Company at 42-10 Vernon Boulevard. Those plans were derailed last year when the New York Power Authority built two gas-powered turbine generators on an adjacent property.
Stuart Match Suna, the president of Silvercup, said his company was continuing to look for potential studio and storage sites, particularly in Long Island City.
Kaufman Astoria plans to build a new 15,000-square-foot stage as part of a $10 million, 30,000-square-foot building across 36th Street from its main entrance. The architects are the Janson Design Group.
The project was announced two years ago but held up because of sharp increases in construction costs, said Hal G. Rosenbluth, president of Kaufman Astoria. Nonetheless, he said he hoped to begin building the new studio late this year or early in 2003.
"At this point, we don't see the market for us to be substantially more than that," Mr. Rosenbluth said. "It's still a business that needs to be justified on an annual basis."
From the city's perspective, said Mr. Stern of the Economic Development Corporation, there is room for Kaufman Astoria, Silvercup, Steiner, Studio City and more, as New York aims to compete on more of an equal footing with Los Angeles.
Compete with Los Angeles? What about the weather? "So far," Mr. Stern allowed, "that's the only thing that's bedeviled us."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 13, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 29 about studio construction credited the design incompletely for the CNN studios in the Time & Life Building and in the AOL Time Warner Center. The Production Design Group was responsible for scenic design.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Does the Law Of Gravity Apply to The Dollar?

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AFTER more than two decades during which the United States bought and consumed far more than it produced, has payback time finally arrived?
 A growing number of the bankers and finance officials from around the world who gathered in Washington this weekend for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank believe that it is near. And if it isn't, they suggest, then by golly it should be. 
 "The current gaps between growth in real domestic demand and real output cannot be sustained indefinitely," the fund warned in its latest review of the world economy. The imbalances in the American economy, it said, are now so big that they pose a "significant risk" to global financial stability. 
The American economy has seemed to defy gravity for years, running steadily bigger trade deficits almost every year for the past two decades. Yet because growth was so strong through most of the 1990's, the economy has also acted as a vacuum cleaner, sucking in hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign investment every year.
The upshot has been an impossible balancing act -- a huge need for foreign cash, yet an indefatigable domestic currency -- that has caused hand-wringing from foreign central bankers who can't believe the United States keeps getting away with it.
The current account deficit -- the combination of trade in goods and services and the balance of income payments -- totaled about $242.5 billion in the first half of this year and is on track to hit a record of nearly $500 billion for the year.
According to the fund, the United States now absorbs about 6 percent of the world's savings to finance its deficit. Japan, plagued by a stagnant domestic economy, has been exporting about 1.5 percent of the world's savings, much of that to the United States.
Economists at the fund and elsewhere worry that investors might abruptly sour on the dollar because prices have simply become too high or because they no longer believe the United States can grow faster than the rest of the world.
"After the stock market bubble and the technology bubble, the last obvious remaining bubble is the dollar," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
A steep plunge in the dollar would make foreign products more expensive in dollar terms, choking off exports to the United States and growth overseas. Exports to the United States have been among the world's most important sources of growth.
Mr. Bergsten believes that the risk of a collapse in the dollar remains unlikely, because the economic fundamentals of the United States remain sound.
But he argues that a correction is inevitable and that the Bush administration should act pre-emptively by intervening in financial markets to nudge down the dollar by an additional 10 or 20 percent.
"The dollar did come down pretty steadily and in a totally ordinary way in the first six months of this year, and there was no adverse effect on inflation," he noted. But since late July, the dollar has actually climbed slightly.
American manufacturers have been pleading for a weaker dollar for years. The high dollar is why manufacturing exports have been stagnant.
Indeed, economists for the Manufacturers Alliance, a trade association in Arlington, Va., argue that the American exports have fallen victim to exchange-rate manipulation by Japan and China. By keeping their currencies artificially low, it argues, those two countries have added $100 billion annually to the trade deficit.
BUT Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has repeatedly insisted that exchange rates be set by market forces, and he has even argued that the current-account deficit is a mere accounting abstraction that means little in the real world of business.
If foreign money floods into the American market and keeps the dollar high, that reflects only the comparative appeal of the United States as an investment target. "What exactly are we supposed to do about it?" one senior official asked.
Fund officials acknowledge the problem, noting that the "ideal solution" to the imbalance would be for Europe and Japan to speed up their own desultory growth by making their markets more flexible and open.
All that is even theoretically possible for the United States Treasury to do is to intervene in currency markets to help push down the value of the dollar. But Mr. O'Neill will have none of it. And because the United States has no need for money from the fund, he doesn't need to.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
As Baby Boomers Age, More Are Catching the 'Easy Rider' Bug

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
NEIL FALCONER first owned a motorcycle three decades ago, when he was in college, but he sold it after he landed his first job, in Chicago. Upon moving to Nevada a few years ago, however, his latent love of riding resurfaced -- with a vengeance.
 "You've got all these hills and trails and winding roads, and not a lot of people on them," said Mr. Falconer, chief of game engineering at International Gaming Technologies of Reno. 
 This year, Mr. Falconer, 54, paid around $9,000 for a Suzuki V-Strom, the third motorcycle he has bought in the last three years. He also owns a (bigger) Harley-Davidson cruising bike and a (smaller) Suzuki dirt bike, along with two Ford Mustangs. But the V-Strom is his favorite way to get to work, weather permitting. And Mr. Falconer, who dons a full-face mask helmet, gloves and a leather jacket for his commute, has an increasing amount of two-wheeled company on the roads these days. 
Motorcycle unit sales have tripled over the last 10 years, varooming in the last three years. And despite the sluggish economy, they rose 7.8 percent in the first six months this year, thanks in large part to baby boomers who find that they cannot experience the thrill of the road in a hulking sport utility vehicle or even a luxury car.
Hankering to join them? Before doing the "easy rider" thing, devotees and experts say, new bikers should grab some protective gear, study up and start thinking cc's.
In the last decade, motorcycles have attracted older, better-educated and wealthier customers, vastly broadening the market. Over all, more than 538,000 street bikes -- those that can be driven on roads and highways -- were sold in 2001, and three times that number of used bikes changed hands last year. The five biggest manufacturers, Honda, Harley-Davidson, Yamaha, Suzuki and Kawasaki, have 90 percent of the new motorcycle market, with other companies, including BMW, dividing the rest.
An increasing number of buyers in their 40's and 50's have raised the average age of a new-motorcycle buyer to 38, from 32 in 1990 and just 24 in 1980, according to the Motorcycle Industry Council in Irvine, Calif. At Harley-Davidson Inc., the legendary Milwaukee manufacturer known for its premium bikes, the average age is even higher, 45, and the average owner's income is $78,300, well above the $44,000 for all owners of street bikes.
About one-third of the Harley customers have never owned motorcycles before; the rest, like Mr. Falconer, are returning to the bike market or are adding to their stable. "Motorcycles are fashionable -- they're hip, they're in," said Gary Christopher, a spokesman for the American Honda Motor Company, which has the largest market share in the United States. He said women, a fast-growing market, now represent 1 in 10 buyers.
The buying is crossing more generational lines, too, he said. Many families now have fleets of motorcycles to go on vacations together.
Over all, more than 6.6 million Americans own motorcycles, according to the Motorcycle Industry Council.
John DiPietro, 40, of Culver City, Calif., said motorcycles give him a chance to feel the breeze and have a 360-degree view of his surroundings.
"You're much more aware of what's going on around you -- you don't have a CD changer, you don't have a cellphone, you don't have all the stupid distractions," said Mr. DiPietro, who owns a 2000 Yamaha V-Star 650 cruiser and is a road-test editor at Edmunds.com, a Web site that provides advice to consumers on car and truck purchases. "It is a feeling of nimbleness and freedom." (Sound systems are, however, available on a number of motorcycles.)
THE primary advice that enthusiasts and industry officials give to prospective buyers is to first enroll in a safety class. In many states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, passing such a course allows a potential cyclist to skip the road portion of the motorcycle license test given by motor vehicle departments. The courses generally cost $100 to $150 and include about 15 hours of instruction -- half in the classroom, half on bikes.
The Motorcycle Safety Foundation, a national, nonprofit organization sponsored by bike makers and distributors, offers its BasicRider course in all 50 states. Information can be found at www.msf-usa.org or by calling (800) 833-3995. Motorcycle dealers also can provide information on local classes by other groups.
Some companies, including Harley-Davidson, also offer their own instruction on how to handle their particular bikes.
Attention to safety has taken on new urgency because the number of fatal motorcycle accidents has risen 16.8 percent over the last two years. The increase caught industry and government officials off guard because the number of accidents fell in the 1990's even as sales were climbing, and all but four states had helmet laws and other regulations governing motorcycle safety. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, 92 percent of the riders killed in accidents during those years had not taken a safety class. (Other studies show that about one-third of all motorcycle owners take the classes.)
Mr. Falconer said the classes also help to weed out people for whom owning a motorcycle is just a fantasy.
Once the commitment is made, the next quandary is how big a bike to buy. According to Mr. Falconer, potential riders should start small, because spinouts are a common occurrence for new riders.
"You have to be able to lift it," he said.
Big bikes, however, are the biggest sellers. Motorcycles are measured by engine power, in cubic centimeters. Riders used to begin on bikes with 250 cc engines, Mr. Christopher said, but in recent years, even fledgling buyers have been demanding more motorcycles with 750 cc and up.
Those big motorcycles generally fall into two categories: cruisers, many of which are designed to look like the classic motorcycles of the 1950's, with much chrome and gleaming paint; and touring bikes, the closest thing to cars on two wheels, complete with features like antilock brakes, tiny trunks and even cupholders.
Bought new, these big bikes start around $12,000. Honda, long known for its plush Gold Wing touring bike, is about to introduce its most expensive bike, the Valkyrie Rune, outfitted with a 1,800 cc engine and expected to retail for $25,000. Harley-Davidson, whose bikes can cost up to $28,000 when customized, is bringing out a new line of motorcycles to mark its 100th anniversary and already has a waiting list.
Less popular, but more affordable, are sport bikes, with their loud engines and zippy handling, and standard bikes, which straddle the middle in size and power. The least powerful, fewest-frills bikes in these categories start at $3,000 and range up to about $6,000 new. The price is about half for used versions.
Just as with cars, deals can be scarce or plentiful depending on the availability or popularity of a model.
Paying for a motorcycle can be as easy as writing a check or paying with a credit card, as Mr. Falconer did with his three bikes. Alternatively, motorcycle loans are available at banks and other financial institutions, from Web sites and through the manufacturers. Interest rates tend to be in the same range as for conventional car loans, now typically around 6.5 percent, but the terms are usually shorter, 12 to 60 months, versus 24 to 72 for auto loans.
Motorcycle showrooms and company Web sites abound with low-interest loan deals and rebates, so it pays to shop and bargain hard. Insurance policies can be found the same way. Many insurance companies offer current customers with good driving records a discount on their motorcycle policies -- even for first-time bikers. Insurers usually cut their rates for people who have completed safety courses.
Most riders acknowledge that motorcycles provide less protection than cars, though that fact does not deter devotees like Mr. DiPietro.
"I'm aware of the danger," he said. "People hear that I get on a bike and say, 'you really shouldn't.' But I love riding."

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
Marty! Marty! Marty!

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR 

 BODY:
ON a recent workday, Brooklynites lunching near Borough Hall Plaza might have wondered why a small brass band was playing oldies and why tables with old-fashioned seltzer bottles and chocolate syrup had been set up in the sun. They might also have wondered about the portly, middle-aged man in a T-shirt and a baseball cap who was standing on the steps of Borough Hall.
 "Look at this crazy crowd, huh?" he said with a grin, his body tense with anticipation. "It's as crazy as I am. As crazy as I am!" 
 Then Marty Markowitz, Brooklyn's borough president, bounded into the crowd, picked up a microphone and welcomed onlookers to Brooklyn's first-ever Egg Cream Extravaganza, a friendly competition to determine which local restaurant reigned supreme in making that famous New York beverage.
"Other boroughs claim the egg cream was born in the Lower East Side," Mr. Markowitz boomed in his thick Crown Heights accent. "But the egg cream has always been Brooklyn's drink." (Loud cheers from the crowd.) "The egg cream and Brooklyn have always been entwined." (Louder cheers.) 
A former state senator who took office as borough president in January, Mr. Markowitz has spent the last nine months making sure the city notices both him and the borough in which he has lived his whole life. He cultivates a first-name-basis relationship with his constituents: his newsletter carries headlines like "Marty's on the Move." Along with the egg cream contest, he introduced a boroughwide weight-loss drive, an over-40 singles beach bash, and signs along Brooklyn's borders carrying slogans like "Believe the Hype."
Mr. Markowitz, who honeymooned at the Brooklyn Marriott, believes it. But what does Brooklyn think of Mr. Markowitz's cheerleading, his misty-eyed recollections of the Dodgers, and the baring of his belly on the steps of Borough Hall? Are some put off by such displays of down-home goofiness, or does his devotion to his borough cut across class and age lines as cleanly as a knife through the Junior's cheesecake he consumes so unabashedly?
Sipping free samples of egg creams, most spectators at the contest subscribed to the latter school of thought. "Everyone loves Marty because he gets out there and he does things," said Vince DiMiceli of Carroll Gardens. "He gets publicity for the borough, which the borough desperately needs."
But as people shouted answers to Mr. Markowitz's quiz about Barbra Streisand and the Dodgers, a man in a gray suit walked purposefully on. "This is the guy who wants to take down the picture of George Washington, our founding father," he remarked drily to a companion. The reference was to Mr. Markowitz's removal of portraits of "old white men" when he took office, a public relations disaster that prompted criticism from the mayor. 
Some wonder if a $135,000-a-year public servant with a $4.7 million operating budget should be playing matchmaker and touting local fountain drinks. Although events like the egg cream contest are financed mostly by corporations, Mr. Markowitz seemed aware of this concern. "In between all this," he told the crowd, "we do some serious work."
Charter revisions 13 years ago cut much of the meat off the job of borough president. David Nasaw, a history professor at CUNY Graduate Center, dismisses them as "irrelevant." 
"We pay them a lot of money, it's a total scandal, and nobody talks about it," Mr. Nasaw said. Of Mr. Markowitz's activities, he added: "He's got nothing to do, no way to let people know that he's there. So he's become a cheerleader who has to come up with ways to root for the home team." 
Claire Shulman, who was Queens borough president from 1986 to 2001, says borough presidents can still accomplish a lot. "Don't judge the office by one person," she said. "That's not fair."
But Kenneth T. Jackson, the historian who heads the New-York Historical Society, sees deeper meaning in Mr. Markowitz's antics, not to mention a spiritual link to Fiorello La Guardia, the mayor who made headlines by reading the funny papers on the radio during the Depression. "He was a showman, and certainly Marty Markowitz is a showman," he said. Beyond that, Mr. Jackson added, "He's bringing energy and innovation and pride to Brooklyn." 
Along with the rest of the city, Mr. Jackson pointed out, the borough is experiencing a renaissance.
"BROOKLYN looks better, it feels better, it's safer, and it has a sense that I think is new, that Brooklyn is the future," he said. "The borough president is both capitalizing on that and helping it to happen."
Mr. Markowitz, for his part, says that most of what he does centers on hard issues around which he campaigned, like unemployment, health care and housing. But, he added, "Then there's the other part of the job. The part that makes people feel better about where they live, the part that puts an extra step in their walk. If I can put a smile on the faces of Brooklynites, making them proud that they're Brooklyn and they're special, I'm doing my job."
A spokesman for Mr. Markowitz noted that many of his events were intended to raise Brooklyn's profile and promote tourism. And there's no question that the obvious enjoyment Mr. Markowitz derives from his position can be infectious. 
As the finalists for the best egg cream lined up on the stage. Mr. Markowitz sampled each one, smacking his lips and ignoring wisecracks about his diet. As the band struck up "Take Me Out to the Ball Game," his face creased into smiles.
"That's it!" the diehard baseball fan cried, beating the air with his fists. "I love it! Love it!"

WILD AND CRAZY
All Things Kings

Marty Markowitz has waged several campaigns to make Brooklynites feel good about themselves. Here are a few.

Lighten Up Brooklyn -- An eight-week campaign to encourage Brooklynites to lose weight. Mr. Markowitz lost 11 of his 194 pounds; the borough lost 82,655.

Life Begins at 40 -- A singles party, with straw hats and leis, for over-40 Brooklynites on the Kingsborough Community College beach where Mr. Markowitz met his wife, Jamie, in 1999.

Respect: Its A Brooklyn Attitude -- A campaign to get Brooklynites to be more courteousto hold doors open, cede the right of way in traffic and stop littering.

Butt Out, Brooklyn -- A campaign to prevent Brooklyn teenagers from smoking.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH -- Leland H. Faust; 
CSI Equity Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
DIVIDENDS have become increasingly important to Leland H. Faust, who runs the $96 million CSI Equity fund.
 "We view a company's ability to pay dividends as a floor for stock price decreases," Mr. Faust said from his office in San Francisco. "If the history of the company shows that management increases dividends or doesn't like to cut dividends, that can make it easier for the stock price to go up." 
 His portfolio companies yield 1.9 percent, on average, versus 0.47 percent for its category of large-capitalization blend funds, which own a mix of growth and value stocks.
Mr. Faust, 56, is the chairman of CSI Capital Management, the fund's adviser, and is a financial adviser to sports figures including Paul O'Neill, the former Yankees outfielder. CSI Equity, which started in October 1997, began offering two classes of retail shares in January 2002. Shares are available through financial advisers with a 5.75 percent front-end sales load, or sales charge, but no-load shares may be bought through Charles Schwab and other mutual fund marketplaces.
The fund's no-load shares lost 1.4 percent, a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, including the effect of dividends. That places the fund in the top 4 percent of large blend funds, which lost an average of 10.2 percent, annualized. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 11.4 percent, annualized, according to Morningstar Inc.
The fund was down 4.5 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 13.1 percent for its group and 13.8 percent for the index. The market capitalization of the portfolio folio companies averages $35 billion.
Some 70 percent of the fund is invested in North America, followed by France, 10 percent, and Britain, 5 percent.
To choose stocks, he looks for what he calls recognized industry leaders and focuses on sales and earnings growth.
In his analysis of financial statements, he reviews a company's debt -- the less, the better. In the sluggish economy, he said, he is concentrating on defensive stocks with stable earnings. For example, the fund has a 24.7 percent stake in consumer staples, versus 10 percent for the S.& P. 500.
MR. FAUST tends to hold stocks for the long term. The fund's turnover is 17 percent, compared with 91 percent for its group.
In July, he bought shares of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company of Chicago, the chewing-gum giant. The company has been a slow but steady grower in the last five years, he said, with dividend and earnings growth averaging 7 percent and revenue growing 5 percent, on average. Shares yield about 1.6 percent.
The balance sheet has no long-term debt, he said, adding, "Wrigley is an industry leader, and we don't see a whole lot of new competition coming in."
Although Wrigley was turned down in its recent bid for Hershey Foods, Mr. Faust said, the fund bought Wrigley shares "because of its existing business, not because it's in an acquiring mode." As for further acquisition attempts, he said, "It depends on the fit."
He has paid $56 a share, on average, for his Wrigley position; the stock now trades at $49.67. Its yield is 1.62 percent. 
In February, Mr. Faust began buying shares of the FPL Group, the electric-utility holding company based in Juno Beach, Fla. FPL's dividend growth rate has averaged 4 percent a year over the last five years, he said, and its five-year net income and revenue have grown an average of 6 percent. "In a troubled market, we think utilities are more stable," he said.
He paid $51 a share, on average, for the position. FPL now trades at $52.79; it yields 4.36 percent.
Mr. Faust also likes Toto Ltd., a Japanese maker of plumbing fixtures. It pays a 2 percent dividend, he said, and has substantial cash flow. Toto is a market leader and a major exporter, with significant sales to the United States, he said.
He bought American depository receipts of the company in May, paying $44, on average; they now trade at $40.00.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
For Sellers Of Food, Fewer Chairs At the Table

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE big companies that sell much of the food that Americans eat have huge appetites. In the last couple of years, they have been gobbling up one another.
 The consolidation trend was at least temporarily halted this month, when Hershey Foods rebuffed an $89-a-share offer from the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company. 
 Jaine I. Mehring, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, talked last week about the meat-and-potatoes section of the stock market. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. What is the logic behind consolidation in the food industry?

A. Normalized earnings-per-share growth is about 7 or 8 percent, but most companies would still tell you they are shooting for 8 percent to 10 percent. When I started covering the group five years ago, every chief executive told me it was 13 percent to 15 percent. Some companies have merged for cost savings to put more money into things like promotion. Some have merged because they wanted access to categories of food they didn't manufacture themselves. It also has to do with leveling the playing field with their retailers, who for a number of years were merging aggressively.

Q. Is the food business becoming an oligopoly?

A. Not by any means. The top 10 beverage manufacturers have more than 80 percent of that market, as do the top 10 household products companies. The top 10 supermarket chains have more than 50 percent of that market. But the 10 biggest food companies have a market share of about 20 percent. It is still an incredibly fragmented industry.

Q. Are there formidable barriers to entry in the food business?

A. They are high to achieve national distribution and get that product slotted on a store shelf. And there are some food businesses, like chocolate, that are more difficult to get into. But you see new ideas spring up in the form of small private regional companies all the time.
As far as the fundamentals are concerned, since the late 1990's they have deteriorated. 
Most importantly, pricing flexibility has been unwound. In the late 1990's, companies were pricing some products at two to three times the rate of inflation, and were also pulling back on reinvestment. You never know when that strategy is going to fail. 
Also, as retailers consolidated and as Wal-Mart emerged as the largest food retailer, the customer has been pushing back in terms of pricing. That takes away a big chunk of your earnings. And costs have gone up. Finally, over the last six to nine months, consumption volume has decelerated. That is strange, and is perplexing people. Most retailers are reporting that traffic in stores is depressed. When traffic is light, people buy staples, but not the impulse stuff.

Q. What is your take on the situation with Hershey Foods?

A. Well, the $89-a-share offer from Wrigley is still hanging out there. The situation is like watching someone rub two sticks together, and you are not sure if there will be a spark. It is either up to Wrigley to do something by pushing the issue, or to Hershey's board, who might pressure the Hershey Trust by claiming this was a very good offer that would benefit all classes of shareholders equally. Then you have the shareholders themselves. Where are they? Are they angry? The ultimate outcome will depend on whether there is activism. I think the chances are 50-50 that one or a combination of those constituencies will push for a deal. I am floored by how passive everyone seems.

Q. Do you consider any of the other big food companies takeover candidates?

A. I recently upgraded Campbell Soup and made the call that the valuation has finally gotten low enough to potentially attract the interest of someone trying to unlock value. The business has some discrete operations within it that have embedded value, like Pepperidge Farm and Godiva chocolates.

Q. Do you have other favorite stocks?

A. Kellogg is still very reasonably priced. It offers the best combination of earnings visibility, solid execution and valuation. Kraft Foods has been the best performer in the group this year, and I am still recommending it. And Hormel Foods, which is a different animal, is also recommended.

Q. Do you expect food stocks to suffer when the overall market improves?

A. The group has outperformed the market by 80 percent since March of 2000. Right now, the group is trading at 17.8 times forward four-quarters earnings, which is just about a market multiple.
When the technology bubble was peaking, the group got as low as a 55 percent discount to the market. In the 30 years before that, the biggest discount was 20 percent. 
When the stock market decides that happy days are here again, the food group will again underperform.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Frontier, Seeing a Chance in Denver, Elbows In

BYLINE:  By ALEX MARKELS 

DATELINE: DENVER 

 BODY:
DURING a coffee break from contract talks last June at the headquarters of Frontier Airlines here, a Teamsters negotiator, Douglas G. Whetstine, buttonholed the airline's chief executive, Jeffrey S. Potter, about its policy of charging passengers who switch their return flights. "You shouldn't make people pay both a change fee and the difference in the fare," Mr. Whetstine said. "It's just not right."
 Mr. Potter, 42, an affable man who dresses casually at work and prides himself on his approachability, recalled saying, "Maybe you're right." 
 A month later, Frontier eliminated the charge for the fare difference. "It was the right thing to do," Mr. Potter said recently, recounting the decision. "There's no reason to be alienating folks right now." 
As the nation's biggest airlines are reeling from the worst losses in a decade, Mr. Potter's approach is unusual -- and appears to be working. Frontier is expanding from its home at Denver International Airport. And, with a combination of eased ticket restrictions and discount fares, it has become a thorn in the side of United Airlines, the biggest carrier in Denver, which has been trying to avoid bankruptcy. 
"Frontier has a huge opportunity," said Michael J. Boyd, president of the Boyd Group, an aviation consulting firm in Evergreen, Colo. "They're in a position to poach a lot of traffic from United right now."
Frontier has also managed to keep its employees happy in an industry where layoffs and uncertainty are rampant. In July, negotiations with Mr. Whetstine, who represents Frontier's mechanics, yielded what he called one of the best contracts in the industry. And Frontier's relations with its flight attendants are so good that they recently voted against unionizing. 
Passenger unhappiness at other airlines has helped fuel Frontier's good-guy image. Recent random interviews with passengers at the Denver airport illustrated the depth of anger over the new penalties that many big airlines have imposed.
"They're outrageous," said James I. Michael, president of Alliance Power Inc., an energy company in Denver. When a United representative told Mr. Michael that he would have to pay $500 to switch his return flight from Los Angeles to Denver to a later time, Mr. Michael said, he was so steamed that he switched his company's travel business to Frontier. "They don't gouge us when we're stuck at the last minute," he said.
But Frontier's strategy of undercutting United on fares has come at a cost. Aggressive price cuts by United last spring -- and corresponding reductions by Frontier -- contributed to a loss for Frontier in the quarter ended June 30. It was the airline's first quarterly loss in four years.
Although Frontier weathered the downturn in air traffic better than larger carriers after Sept. 11 (it was the only airline to return federal grant money received for related losses), it applied for a $59.5 million federal loan guarantee in June, citing concern that loan guarantees to bigger carriers could give them an unfair advantage in lowering ticket prices. Frontier is awaiting approval of its application and is negotiating its first private line of credit.
 ALTHOUGH Frontier is a small fraction of United's total size -- revenue for the quarter ended June 30 was $111 million, about 3 percent of the $3.79 billion at United -- Frontier is a growing force at Denver International. Its market share there has climbed to more than 11 percent from 3.5 percent five years ago, giving it the largest presence there behind United, which has 62.4 percent.
Frontier has added nine destinations this year and now operates about 180 daily flights, about one-tenth of what United flies.
A partly nonunion work force and strict budgeting have kept Frontier's cost structure about 25 percent below United's. And a transition to a new fleet of more economical aircraft has helped Frontier reduce costs by more than 13 percent versus the previous year. Its new Airbus A319 jets, which Frontier is phasing in through 2005, have greater fuel efficiency and lower maintenance costs than the old Boeing 737's they replace.
Mr. Potter, a one-time aircraft cleaner and ticket agent who never completed college, has tried to be accessible to his employees since ascending to the chief executive's job last April. Everyone, including union representatives and rank-and-file workers, gets a hearing. Pausing during an interview this month, he fielded a telephone call from a Frontier mechanic suggesting a novel way to dispose of an old Boeing aircraft: park it on the office lawn as a museum piece. "Great idea," Mr. Potter told the mechanic. "But we lease that aircraft. So they're going to want it back when we're done with it."
He later held up a small cardboard box that holds flight meals. "There's some potential savings with these boxes," he said. "But I'm concerned about how the flight attendants feel about using them instead of doing regular meal service. So we're asking them before we make any changes."
The approach is directly from the playbook of Mr. Potter's predecessor and mentor, Samuel D. Addoms, 63, a corporate turnaround expert who helped found Frontier in 1994, reincarnating the name of a Denver-based airline that went bankrupt eight years earlier. Although legendary for his frugality (he shunned cellphones and insisted that workers receive his permission before using the color printer outside his office), Mr. Addoms, who remains Frontier's chairman, has diligently consulted with employees.
Perplexed by the standard industry practice of paying flight crews by the hour, he worked with employees to create a salary-based system that allows flight crews to team up for a month at a time, rather than switching from flight to flight. Managers say the change has made labor costs more predictable and improved employee morale. "It helped build a family type of relationship," recalled John W. Todoverto, president of Frontier's pilots union. "Management's door has always been open for us to sit down and chew the fat, which makes everyone more willing to compromise."
Mr. Addoms was motivated to do exactly that after Frontier's initial strategy of building a regional feeder to larger carriers failed in 1995, when Continental Airlines eliminated its Denver hub. That left United dominant in Denver and unwilling to team with Frontier. So Mr. Addoms converted his fledgling operation into a discount airline, adding routes to major cities like Los Angeles and New York while pricing Frontier's flights below United's. An unrestricted Denver-to-New York round-trip ticket on Frontier, for example, costs $736, versus $1,506 on United.
Frontier's Denver base, a natural crossroads, has made it relatively easy to build a hub-and-spoke system like that used by larger carriers. While it is not the most efficient system, Frontier has made it work by pursuing low costs and appealing to price-conscious business travelers with lower short-notice fares and eased travel restrictions, like forgoing Saturday-night stay requirements on most fares.
Mr. Potter, who as the company's vice president for marketing directed its pricing, has followed closely in Mr. Addoms's footsteps. "Our strategy remains unchanged: price below United and continually focus on a cost structure that's less than theirs," Mr. Potter said.
Although the discounts have undermined profits, industry analysts say Frontier's strategy remains sound. 'They're doing an excellent job of flying just below United's pain threshold," said Andrew Watterson, an aviation specialist at Mercer Management Consulting. "It costs more for United to fight them than to leave them alone, which has allowed Frontier to get great margins and flourish in a market that United dominates."
Mr. Watterson said United has little incentive, for example, to match Frontier's fares from Denver to Los Angeles, because Frontier runs only a few daily flights on that route, compared with a dozen by United.
 IF United goes into bankruptcy, however, Frontier's success against it could be imperiled. "Once United declares bankruptcy, it can get its labor costs under control," said Michael E. Levine, a Yale University professor and a former executive at Northwest Airlines. "The day it does that, Frontier's zone of protection goes away."
But for the time being, United has bigger problems to worry about than Frontier. As it tries to cut $2.5 billion in costs and increase revenue, United has recently followed an erratic pricing strategy that has pushed down leisure fares but kept business fares up to twice as high as Frontier's. "We've kept an eye on Frontier, but our focus is on the business customer and they're more focused on leisure customers," said Sean Donohue, United's vice president for sales in the Western region, who noted Frontier's recent plans to add flights to three Mexican resorts.
"When it comes to pricing, we're very, very competitive," he said. "And at the end of the day, we offer things that they don't, like a first-class cabin."
Frontier executives say they are happy to concede such luxury services to United. "They're boarding three classes of service and three different levels of frequent-flier status, and half of those people are up in their club getting loaded on United's liquor," Mr. Addoms said. "If United wants to do those complex things, that's fine with us. They're good at it. They have nice clubs."
